best tomb raider my pp has ever seen

Tomb Raider is the first installment in a reboot of three other classic Tomb Raider the games that reconstruct the games lore and the protagonists origins, with "Rise of the Tomb Raider" and "Shadow of the Tomb Raider" following the rebooted trilogy after. Tomb Raider follows Lara Croft, a young and ambitious archaeologist who travels with a crew to the island of Yamatai in search of the islands lost kingdom. Along the way, Lara and her crew are stranded and meet a overzealous cult that try to kill them.

I won't elaborate on the plot to save spoilers, but I definitely enjoyed this games story. Lara is notable for being one of the few female protagonists in the gaming industry, and has since become a significant figure in popular culture; very likable. Good voice acting, soundtrack, and pretty visuals overall among other nice details.

The game play is enjoyable and progresses well with the story as Lara unlocks new skills, gadgets that help her transverse the islands environment, and weapons to aid in combat. I had no technical issues, bugs and all while playing and was surprised at how well the game ran for being over a decade old at this point. Exploration and parkour are an emphasis while adventuring through the island to raid tombs and collect items around the map, with fast travel also being in an option to aid with this. My two favorite things about the game-play might be how Lara automatically takes cover without needing to press a key, and how dying is extremely forgiving. When Lara dies, there is no game-over screen and instead a quick loading one which places her basically right where she was when she died.

Overall, a short and sweet action-adventure game worth the price!

Before purchasing, do note two things. Firstly, the multiplayer mode. It is the only Tomb Raider game with multiplayer apart from the sequel "Rise of the Tomb Raider" and, while it is functional and offers a fun and unique third-person shooter experience, no longer has an active player base. Consequently because of this, it is virtually impossible to gain a chunk of the achievements in this game multiplayer related. Secondly, in my experience, I found that the single-player mode was impossible to complete 100% due to a missing ornament in the "Sun Killer" challenge, which at best left me with the option of getting 68% achievements and 99% single player completion.
good jobs

Wow. Just wow! Talk about an adrenaline rush! I had just completed Rise of the Tomb Raider (I bought that one first, so unfortunately I’m doing the trilogy out of order) and was prepared for a bit of a letdown when I started playing this game. Graphically it’s not as polished (as expected for an 11 year old game), but honestly, it still holds its own. But man, this game is intense!  I played ROTR on ‘Tomb Raider’ level, which is #2 out of 4 difficulty levels, and this game on Normal difficulty. I’ll have to go back and play ROTR on one of the higher settings to see how things change, but here are some comparisons of TR vs ROTR:

[list]
[*]TR has much more sheer action. ROTR is a bit more puzzle-oriented
[*]Many cutscenes that morph into you having to control Lara again, mostly stuff like sliding out of control and having to dodge items and/or jump at just the right time
[*]Lots more combat. Lost count of how many times I’d round a corner or drop into a room and there were a bunch of enemies waiting to kill me
[*]Possibly more enjoyable? ROTR was great, but it seemed a tad more tame and structured compared to this one. All the elements of puzzle solving and acrobatics are in both, but the amount of variety, cutscenes and just edge-of-your-seat craziness are more than ROTR. I found myself laughing out loud during scenes bc of how bonkers the action was.
[/list]

The one thing that would take away a star is that I encountered a few bugs (playing on a Mac M1 w/Silicon chip). They were during the transition from cutscene to when you start playing again, and a few times things just sort of froze and I had to quit and restart a few times. Eventually the game would work through it, but very annoying when it happened. This happened a handful of times throughout the game. That being said, this is still a great adventure game overall and an easy recommend, even today!

I've never changed my mind on a review once i posted one but after playing through another full round, i found it rather frustrating in terms of playabliity. game kicked me out to win three different times, locked up once which i had it kill the game through steam.
the crazy pitfall jumps where the ledge is just too far away for the char to climb ax into was what finally did it for me. after 20+ times trying to jump only to miss the ledge on a main mission then by blind luck, the ax finally clung into the rack face. 
the tomb of flooded fault, had to finally let that one go due to the long jump of death. must have tried that one 30+ times before finally giving it the middle finger and moving on. youtube, game guides, walkthroughs all showed the ax in hand as they jumped. nope. fell to my death 100% of the time on this one. 
i gave one of the other tomb raiders a negative review for this same thing, jump over impossible pitfall and simply would not allow me to catch hold of other ledge. very frustrating

Never played any of the Tomb Raider games before picking this one up on sale. I was pleasantly surprised at how well you could maneuver through the open world and interact with the settings. Overall I would give it a 9 ½ out of 10. Other than learning how to maneuver quickly then aiming before able to fire any weapon, I really enjoyed this game as a whole.

Really liked the instinct mode

Cons:
A few places the game play wasn’t very intuitive

I know this game has got a lot of good reviews on steam and most people will just straight away disagree with me, but this game is just disappointing. This game has taken a different direction, too far for me.The game does have some good action scenes and very nice graphics but it's missing something, something that made tomb raider games so good and popular. 

What happened to the actual tomb raiding in these games? Tomb raiding is an afterthought....

Stick a tomb on the side of the linear path, can't miss it. Enter the tomb to only find some of the most uninteresting tombs ever found in any of tomb raider games. Once inside, your puzzle is very simple, very dull and all of this is over and done with in only 5 mins, on your first try without using the MAGIC BUTTON, that holds your hand lighting up your area giving you clues ............

The game is mostly about the over the top action scenes, very much like a hollywood blockbuster. Lots of cutscenes and endless hordes of enemies to kill, plus plenty of QTE'S. No real exploring in this game, no real tomb raiding, shallow gameplay, with way too much hand holding.

This tomb raider game lost its soul.

There are A LOT of Michael Bay 'Splosions in the cutscenes and gameplay, like everything is wired with C5  that magically doesn't kill Lara but every one else and well  this is a prime example of Peak Shaky Cam Game Development that will at times make you want to vomit your lunch or just have problems understanding where and what you are even doing, which isn't great in some of those timed sequences. And perhaps we should even use this as an example to Creative Students in the future of what NOT to do when filming and editing to avoid mass seizures and epilepsy. BUT when the cutscenes and parts where they were legit trying to make a movie instead of a game, stop and calm down for a minute and they let you just *play the damn game*  its fun. The combat is easy but fun and the exploration is again easy straight forward, but fun and its a decent action game to play over a weekend, a nice if overly graphics focused reboot even.
However the team in charge of cinematics really needs to calm down and sit in a quiet room with no access to caffeine for atleast 10 years before doing any future projects...Chill bro its ok, everything doesn't have to explode all the time and Lara CAN just calmly approach an objective without falling about 1000 ft to just hold her side as if winded after bouncing off 12 trees before then being forced through another unskippable sequence where she screams Jonah repeatedly as the camera quake ensues. (This applies to all the following reboot titles as well but the director of these games I'm glad to say has long since moved on, probably to make even more on rails insta grat camera shake nonsense. So i doubt they are reading this or caring about anything Tomb Raider Fans say anymore.) One thing you can take from this trilogy is they absolutely weren't interested in making a genuine classic Tomb Raider puzzle explorer, they just wanted to make a CoD/Farcry game called Tomb Raider to appeal to the lucrative, populous but lazy casual shooter crowd.

I really love this game. 

I'm an old school Tomb Raider fan, so when this reboot got announced I got excited and cautious. I wasn't that big of a fan of the new Lara, she's too short, too whiny, too much of a princess. The original Lara was taller, sexier, more confident. However I quickly grew very fond of new Lara. I still prefer the original, but this new one is cool as well. She yells a lot in a very high pitched annoying shrill voice, but nevertheless, she's sweet, strong, smart and attractive. She becomes much more annoying in following games and much less attractive for some reason. And considering Phoebe Waller-Bridge has taken over the franchise, that trend will exacerbate considerably sadly.

The game is basically a rip-off of Uncharted, but it's a good formula, so I don't mind, in fact I prefer this over Uncharted. I love that this is semi-open world; play through it once, then come back when you feel like it to finish up the collectibles and challenges. Those challenges aren't really original, but they weren't outstaying their welcome. Peppered throughout the game are optional tombs, which are very short in comparison with other TR games, but fun nonetheless. And the light metroidvania elements add some welcome layering. The skill systems and weapon upgrade systems are superficial, yet slightly engaging.

The combat is fairly standard, the bow is quite satisfying, the other weapons aren't amazing, but they serve their purpose. Melee combat is very primitive; the dodge window is large enough to park a car in, in fact I find that the timing is a bit off, if you dodge the moment the sword hits, there's no option for a counter attack.

Jumping, climbing, swinging, etc... is all great, in fact a lot better then in Shadow of the Tomb Raider for some reason, I was incredibly frustrated by the numerous jumps I missed in that game, in this one, I only missed jumps from wall to wall for some reason. The dodge button is bound to Shift on PC, which is odd because I had the reflex to dodge every time I wanted to sprint, considering there curiously is no sprint in Tomb Raider.

The game is nicely paced, in my 100% run I had collected everything at the very end of the game, which also coincided with me getting all weapon and skill upgrades towards the very end of the game. Nicely done!

The story isn't bad, being trapped on an island, boats and planes unable to leave due to some supernatural force, that's all quite good. You stranded there along with a very diverse cast of characters, as if cast by Netflix. There's the white girl, the Asian girl, the black girl, the useless white guy, the sleazy white guy, the  Polynesian guy, etc... I didn't have a problem with any one character, Joslin was a bit too bossy and arrogant for my taste, but these days a character like that is a must. I really liked Roth, I wished her relationship with Lara was fleshed out a bit more, that would make his loss a lot more gripping. He was the only character that seemed to know what he was doing, everybody else was too feeble for my taste. Also I really think half the actors pronounce Lara's name Laura.

Anyway, apart for the band of groupies, I like the story quite a bit.

I've played through the game now 3 times, I'm working on getting the multiplayer achievements, but considering I'm not getting a match, as it's 12 years after release, I doubt I'll ever get my achievements completed. Thanks CD for bringing Multiplayer into the achievement mix... sigh.

Pros - 

Visuals : Game does look very good, certain areas are beautiful. The weather conditions are well portrayed and overall the atmosphere is realistic

Music : The orchestra used is almost perfect for most scenes, changes tempo and rhythm to show oncoming threats, but also parts of happiness and exploration. It makes you invested into the game.

Story-line : Easy to follow, maybe too much and cliche. This may be more of a pro than a con.

These are pros which mainly revolve around the visuals and atmosphere built through the music. Then we move onto the cons, which sadly are extensive.

Cons - 

Lara herself : Lara gets absolutely victimised in this game, and somehow survives every single time. I thought it was quite funny towards the end of the story, Reyes has one gunshot wound on her arm and states that she almost died, and Lara is worried and runs to assist. Meanwhile, Lara has survived concussions, drowning, burning, shootings, stabbings, stomach impalement, hypothermia, severe starvation & dehydration, fatal insomnia, attacks from wolves, fractures, caught in bear traps, torched alive, a multitude of falls, probably every rib cracked, plane/helicopter crash and falling through trees. It is almost hard to believe that she could ever die because she "just about makes it" every 5 minutes.

Camera shake : Far too strong and unnecessary. The screen just wobbles when Lara walks so imagine when she uses a zip-line, or any other torture form above. 

UI : UI not rendering at 100% scalability, for some reason the corners are cut off despite being set at native.

Game's mechanics : Shockingly repetitive. Spam to pry open. Duck / walk, get spotted/heard. Lara proceeds to murder 100+ people. Move on, repeat. Survive another near death experience, barely survive, find a gun and kill another 100 people. Discover something new, (maybe that her crew are all useless and actual liabilities which are part of the reason why she almost dies every half an hour), continue fighting.

Puzzles : Or lack of puzzles. The couple that were there were so easy they don't count, most of the time there was just one route or option, and that was enough to get you through.

It's good, but it felt like a chore to finish the game. This honestly could have been far better without majority of the fighting, less clumsiness and belligerence from her crew, and her not having to "barely survive" so much.

玩完11来玩9，本来以为是降级体验，没想到大部分是升级体验。
11虽然各方面都“优化”，但是就是没9爽。

比11好的地方：
1.（手柄）正常的武器键位，不像11的逆天切武器2重键位还有bug
2. 弓的手感比11强
3. 整体品控强不止一点，非常顺滑（虽然后期有些崩）。11的品控一言难尽。
4. level design水准高了一个档次。11的level就像初学者做的。
5. 音效，氛围，台词，人设，运镜高了一个档次。11除去战斗部分玩得想睡着。

不如11的地方：
1. 枪的手柄辅瞄奇怪。但是强辅瞄很若只，11就是这样，所以11重刀战和潜行，枪强辅瞄限制子弹，9这点“不如”11。
2. 野外摘草除了加经验没啥用。11就变成了嗑药。
3. 实际上攀岩解密都不如11复杂。但是11品控不过关，解密也没新意，只堆复杂度，所以反而成了9的爽点。
4. UI不如11。后期竟然还有UI对不准的情况。
5. 主角人设复杂度和微表情不如11。但是颜值比11更靓丽。

I bought this years and years ago and have ignored it until recently. What a wally I was for doing that, it's fantastic! 

The outline of the story is good, voice acting is serviceable but the mysteries/mysticism in the plot keep you invested. Some really threatening enemies and some surprisingly dark/violent moments that occur but without stealing away from the adventurous/Indiana jones tone that you'd expect from Lara. 

Gameplay is slick and modernised (sorry no backflip duel wielding a pack of wolves anymore). as you'd expect, over the shoulder with weapons wheel and utilities. Plays just fine and the bow is really satisfying. Enemy A.I can be decent, lots of flanks and areas for enemies to surface, but sometimes they're dull as dishwater and you can cheese them despite the open environments that a lot of the battles take place in. 

I mean damn son, what else do you want? I'd say when it comes to reboots/remakes this is upper echelons, like maybe even top 5 who knows.

[h1] The Amazing Beginning Of Lara Croft! [/h1] 
Tomb Raider is a 2013 action-adventure video game developed by Crystal Dynamics and published by Square Enix's European subsidiary. It is the tenth main game in the Tomb Raider franchise and is a reboot of the series, acting as the first installment in the Survivor trilogy that reconstructs the origins of Lara Croft.
 
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]For a 2013 game, this is mighty impressive. The environments are absolutely incredible and filled with life (and death). If you love bones, this is your game. The caves and tombs are filled with environmental storytelling and they look so filled with detail. The lighting is also incredible in this game, especially in the cave sections. Lara looks incredible and the animations are really well put together and immersive.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]Gameplay mechanics are top tier here. You can unlock skill points to make Lara even more of a killing machine, upgrades for your weapons to make them really powerful. The progression in this game is so well done and keeps you wanting more and more. The puzzles were pretty good in this game. Some puzzles really make you think (which is hard for my little brain) but they are really satisfying once you pass them. The difficulty is pretty good. I was playing on hard mode and I had some difficulties but mostly because I'm slow. The gunplay is actually really good and engaging. I will say that I had to switch to keyboard and mouse because the QTEs (Quick Time Events) were really inconsistent for me and it was hard to figure out what key to press. It could just be on my end though. Besides that the game feels really good with a controller so no problems there.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]I never played a Tomb Raider game, but this game was truly special in terms of story. Lora Croft is such an interesting and badass character. By the end of the game, I got so invested and was bummed out that it was over. The story is amazing, and truly worth anyone's time. Your goal is to find a way to escape this cursed island and while you try and find a way out, you find so many amazing historical artifacts and tombs that really got me invested. The Villain was really interesting to me and the side characters were really likable as well. There is so much to talk here about the story, but all I have to say is wow. This story really got me invested and I wish I had amnesia so I can experience it all again for the first time.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]My playthrough was 12 hours of playtime. If you are a completionist, expect around 30+ Hours of playtime here.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]The sound design is amazing! The voice acting is incredible and really believable. The music is settled and fits the game really well. Also the music is settled and feels relaxing when it’s in the background (kinda like ambiance). The gun sounds are punchy and satisfying and the enemy dialogue is good.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]You will find some funny glitches. For example items floating and I had an enemy do donuts around a table which was odd. The out of bound areas can be kinda odd especially near cliffs but those are very far and between.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]Tomb Raider has really good performance even with everything on max settings. I have a decent PC so you should be perfectly fine with similar specs.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✔️Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Masterpiece story
[*]Gameplay is really good
[*]Progression system is really well put together
[*]Combat is satisfying
[*]Likable side characters
[*]Environments are beautiful
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Some minor bugs
[*]Keyboard QTEs are inconsistent
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]10/10
This game is worth every penny. It’s a maserful experience and I don’t regret spending the full price. I would say it’s a steal![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]Tomb Raider was a Gem of an experience. I never thought I would be into Tomb Raider games but wow was I wrong! I would recommend this to anybody that is wanting to try a different experience. It’s an emotional experience with amazing side characters. I’m so happy I was curious enough to try this game.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀「 𝐼𝒩𝒯𝑅𝒪 」
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀୨୧  ・┈┈・୨୧・┈┈・୨୧
╭・☆₊
﹕୨୧ˏ₊꒰
╰ ⊹₊˚ ໒  Though one could say I have formed somewhat of a bias for this game, I must disagree a tad. It holds a special place for my heart, but I was open to exploring the descendants too. However, after playing through the entire remake trilogy, I, in fact, realised I have a bias. And also, that this game simply cannot be beat. ✧˖°.

 ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀જ⁀➴「  𝒱𝒾𝓈𝓊𝒶𝓁𝓈:」

╰ ⊹₊˚ ໒ The other games lacked severely in atmosphere. Graphics were beautiful, but I was irked by the change of Lara's character design. In this game, she looks human, sleek and gorgeous. In the following games, she looks completely different, almost plastic and, in my opinion, way less attractive. Though attractiveness isn't an important aspect, I felt like I lost my wife, so it did affect me quite a lot. It didn't feel like the Lara I knew, since I played this one so many times before moving onto the other ones. I love the graphics of this game. Whilst they are not as amazing as the other games' were, they're charming and still make me feel like I'm right there, struggling with Lara. ✧˖°.

 ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀ જ⁀➴ 「  𝒮𝓉𝑜𝓇𝓎 𝓁𝒾𝓃𝑒:」

╰ ⊹₊˚ ໒ As for the atmosphere, this game completely encapsulates you in the story. It is self contained, moves at the perfect pace and I didn't need to skip any cut scenes, since I was genuinely interested in watching them. The story of Himiko was very interesting and I was eager to learn more about it. 
The main thing for me was, that I didn't have to hear the word "Trinity" even once. 10/10.
(In the other games, you'd hear them say that word at least once in every single cut scene. Perfect for if you want to find a reason to kill yourself that night or blow your ear drums out.) 

Which brings me to my next point, Lara's personality and likeability. ✧˖°.

⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀જ⁀➴「 𝐿𝒶𝓇𝒶:」

╰ ⊹₊˚ ໒ In this game, I could feel empathetic towards Lara, her voice acting was perfectly executed, you could feel her emotions and sympathise with her. Her morals were still in the right place, even though she was killing many enemies but was considerable towards innocent people. (In shadow, Lara's ignorance towards the people who were killed in the apocalypse she caused almost made me uninstall the game right then and there and set my computer on fire.)
When using survival instincts she wouldn't repeat the same thing over and over, or practically tell you what to do, even on easy mode. (MASSIVE dig at the following games.) ✧˖°.

⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀જ⁀➴ 「 𝒮𝒾𝒹𝑒 𝒸𝒽𝒶𝓇𝒶𝒸𝓉𝑒𝓇𝓈:」

╰ ⊹₊˚ ໒ The side characters were interesting, (Live laugh Roth.) and not once did I hear myself go "I don't give a shit." or "Speed it up." when they'd be talking. (This happened a lot in the other two games.)
When they'd interact with Lara, I could feel the connection they'd have and the conversations felt genuine and personal. Didn't feel myself zoning out even once, bravo!
I really liked Alex's character, and I was sad when he died in the Endurance. Wish it was Reyes instead. (Sorry.) 
Matthias wasn't a particularly interesting character, more of a bald annoyance but I think it was necessary for you to absolutely hate someone and enjoy watching them die. (Speaking of which, where the fuck did Lara's double guns go in the following games after she killed Matthias with them?)
My only problem would be that they killed off my favourite side characters. (Roth & Alex.) ✧˖°.

⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀જ⁀➴「 𝑀𝒶𝓅 𝓈𝑒𝒸𝓉𝒾𝑜𝓃𝓈:」
 
╰ ⊹₊˚ ໒ I liked every place in the entire map. Maybe my least favourite would be shantytown, only because it would confuse the hell out of me. The forests would also get a bit confusing, but I did like them nevertheless. 
Finding caches was a pain in the ass, but it allowed for thorough exploration that really expanded on the game. As well as finding relics, that was my favourite. ✧˖°.

⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀જ⁀➴ 「 𝒯𝑜𝓂𝒷𝓈:」

╰ ⊹₊˚ ໒ I wish there were a few more tombs, maybe ones a bit harder to find, but I did like them. They weren't difficult to complete, but some had me screaming into my pillow. However the rewards were worth it as it allowed for quite a few modifications. Though I do feel that there wasn't nearly enough of them, and there should've been more in the main story line, instead of "optional". ✧˖°.

  ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀「 𝒪𝒰𝒯𝑅𝒪:」
╭・☆₊
﹕୨୧ˏ₊꒰
╰ ⊹₊˚ ໒ Overall, I believe this game could be even better, had it had the same amount of mechanics from the other games and more tombs. This one is the best out of the trilogy and I will die on that hill. ✧˖°.

[h1] Tomb Raider. [/h1]
[h3] Before she raided tombs... [/h3]

This is Tomb Raider 2013, another of a series of alternate universe reboots for the Tomb Raider ip. This is a fantastic game! And, surprisingly, an excellent tech demo for a physics model as well as a great bench marking tool for gaming PCs up until ~2017.

[h3] +Pros [/h3]
+Excellent action and game play mechanics. If you have played the original 'The Last of Us' on PlayStation 3, at or around the time of this release, then you have essentially played this game.
+Excellent story about Lara discovering her purpose in life after a traumatic event.
+Excellent setting, the story takes place on an abandoned post WW2 area mixed with weird sci-fi religious themes.
+Good combat. Scavenge and survive!
+Fantastic graphics for the time, and they are pretty good now as well.
+Excellent spatial awareness in the sound design, with very clear cues for just about everything. The sound scape is also masterfully dynamic with the way an environment warps sounds.
+Story focused character upgrades, with a side of additional equipment unlocks that you don't need to grind to achieve. This skill tree is very similar to classic Assassin's Creed, ergo Brotherhood and Revelations.
+A good balance between exploration and backtracking, which is quite difficult to master. Finding everything in this game is achievable, and even though that aspect is busy work at its core, its at the perfect balance.

[h3] ~Neutrals [/h3]
~Not a fan of the physical aspect of the setting. At the time, I was playing quite a few games that had either a tundra setting or a desert setting, and it was a period thing. In 2012-2014, games were trying to pioneer new tech and work with Vulkan and DX11. The forefront was getting the game to run smoothly, at the expense of details. This game unfortunately fell into this category. Not a con due to the fact that lately, this setting and theme are quite unique, but back when this released it was part of a dozen.

[h3] -Cons [/h3]
-The borderline torture of Lara really goes overboard in some of the action sequences, and somehow she just troops through it. I understand this is a game, but getting impaled right at the start of the game and then literally sleeping it off on a freezing mountain top cliff isn't something I believe anyone is capable of. That is coming from me, someone who has overcome being crippled and paralyzed from a motorcycle collision.
-Very serious adult themes are shown and illustrated in this game without warning. I understand that shock media is effective at portraying the story, but I was very surprised to see some extreme themes SUDDENLY.

Despite the negative review, I actually enjoyed the game quite a bit. That being said I would not recommend this game to a lot of people. 

This game suffers from a lot of "old game moment" especially on the PC, there are tons of game breaking bugs such as freezing and broken cutscenes that hinder the experience quite a bit. Along with this, you're dealing with clunky movement through the environments, and a camera with effects that give you VR esque motion sickness, leading me to drop the game and take a break considerably often.

Despite these complaints there's quite a bit I liked about the game as well. The story was engaging and the environments were a joy to explore and find goodies, (even with the clunky movement) especially shanty town, which was an absolute treat to explore. The absurdity of the damage she can take also never gets old. All around I'm excited to play the next installments in the series :3

Gioco oggettivamente mal sviluppato: a distanza di 10 anni la versione nativa per linux ancora non si avvia e tramite proton soffre di uno stuttering terrificante, anche gli utenti windows sono costretti a giocare con un client beta a causa di un bug che sposta fuori dallo schermo alcuni elementi di UI, mi é capitato inoltre di dover ricaricare piú volte la partita durante le mie 10h di gioco a causa di bug che non mi permettevano di avanzare con la storia; mi ha riportato con la mente ai tempi del buggatissimo Tomb Raider: The Angel of Darkness. 

[SPOILER]
La storia discreta, ma totalmente orfana di colpi di scena e di idee particolarmente originali non riesce a compensare alle gravi mancanze narrative: il contesto di trama viene ficcato forzosamente tra le prime fasi di gioco in maniera sbrigativa il che sbilancia il ritmo della narrazione non permettendo ai personaggi di avere una finestra decente per essere presentati; dovrebbe essere un reboot quindi si dovrebbe partire da zero, ma sin dall inizio l equipaggio sembra in gran parte composto da cheerleaders che fanno il tifo per Lara con un entusiasmo quasi infantile, fastidioso e totalmente ingiustificato; i dialoghi sono noiosi, pieni di frasi vuote e il voice acting di basso livello non aiuta a far emergere personaggi la cui scrittura piatta e costruita su cliché visti e rivisti centinaia di volte risulta stucchevole giá durante la prima sessione di gioco. Il risultato é che la morte dei compagni di Lara non suscita mai nessun tipo di emozione o trasporto, sono arrivato alla fine del gioco stanco e incapace addirittura di godermi il richiamo, presente nel finale, alla Lara iconica che brandisce due pistole. Unica nota positiva sotto questo punto di vista é stata l evoluzione di Lara nella scena finale che apre le porte per i capitoli futuri.

A great title for those who are newcomers to the franchise.It is just a bit short but other than that I loved it till the game was finished.

It will work well on most modern systems with a integrated graphics card as well,I know so because I own a lower spec'ced PC.

Pros:
+ Graphics and audio design don't pale in comparison to much newer games. Textures are really well done and objects look smooth.
+ I've read people saying the puzzles are easy, but to me they were suitably challenging.

Cons:
- UI takes some time to get used to - especially the map is clunky to use.
- Due to an unfixed bug, the UI elements are often off the screen.
- There is no manual save option, only automatic. It's not possible to back to earlier parts of a playthrough. I would have liked to cancel a weapon upgrade or watch cutscenes again, but I couldn't.
- The game does not explain some of its features at all (for example, what is GPS Cache?)
- Although the game is open world, it feels linear - there are no side missions or any remarkable action outside the story.
- In stealth situations, enemies do not often react even if Lara is within their view. This obviously ruins the immersion.
- The environments feel empty and unrealistically quiet when not in combat. But when in combat, the game is often too intensive and overwhelming (especially the melee combat). The balance is not good.
- Travelling between different sections of the island is only possible via camp fire (why not mountain passages, caves or rivers?)
- It feels like the weapon upgrades do not have much effect in the game.
- Some inconsistencies / confusing things in storytelling.
- Stereotypical characters (especially Alex and Grim).

Summary:
The game looks and sounds good even in 2024, but sadly has many problems.

Replayed the game recently cause I was planning to finish the trilogy. 
I remember it being pretty good back in the day but playing it right now is just giving me a massive headache.
The camera sway? Who even came up with that idea! EVERYTIME I MOVE THE CAMERA SWAYS!? I even turned off video effects and other settings but it just wouldn't stop. After every session I ended up having a massive headache. 
The story still holds though, even the gameplay is quite fun. There are quite a lot of technical glitches though. Even though my aspect ratio was set to native, it was pretty much overflowing and I missed out on a few things. The boss fight in the ship was annoying af. I had to restart it like 20 times cause my screen would get stuck (I was playing on ultimate graphic settings). Fix was to reduce it to low and then play it. 

But real question is, was it worth the trouble? Yep, definitely. I enjoyed the game back then and still do. If not for the camera sway and occasional bugs, the game is 100% worth playing even in 2023.

Super fun game with a well told story set on a beautiful mysterious island that I had a blast exploring. It depicts Lara's origin story, how she became the badass archeologist we all know and love and this is one helluva epic depiction.
The game looks, sounds and plays great. I also really like the UI and the music, it's ambient, epic and emotional, felt appropriate for this "A survivor is born" journey. Adding to that the acting is stellar and the animations are incredible. You can "feel" the weight of what she fights through here because it's masterfully presented, I often found myself clenching my teeth and recoiling from the shit Lara had to go through.
Special mention to the horror music bits, man those moments I was gripping my controller like my life depended on it

Tomb Raider by Michael Bay. This gotta be the dumbest, most over the top iteration of Lara Croft ever to be put on game. I almost hated everything about it, except for the gameplay, which is fun. Actually it was fun enough for me to 100% it, and that has barely even happened to me with any other game! But the story, oh man, the lame throwaway characters and Lara. Oh Lara, what have they done to you? From a strong silent female icon into a whiny and annoying teenager with psychological issues who never shuts the f*** up and keeps endangering her companions over and over again. The plot points are quite absurd; everything explodes and watching Lara stab someone in the head with an arrow, or falling down to a pit filled with spikes and impaling herself, or watching her rise from a pool of blood and gore (really, it happens) doesn't quite fit the Tomb Raider style, and I'm saying this when I barely even touched the originals! Am I playing Tomb Raider or god damn Resident Evil here!? 

Anyway, despite all that, the game is enjoyable, and playable. It's dumb downed lame action clichés of the 2010's era of gaming, the absolute worst of it, but it's ok. After all, I finished it completely. Thankfully, they made the sequel to be much better, subtle and way more alike the classic Tomb Raiders.

3/5

I actually enjoyed playing this game and appreciate it for what it's trying to achieve. I can look past the cheesy voice acting and dated combat; graphically, I think Tomb Raider has held up pretty well for its time. However, I can't, for the life of me, play it for more than 30 minutes without it crashing, making it almost impossible to get immersed. I have pretty modern hardware, disabled certain graphic settings, updated all my hardware, and disabled any conflicting programs like my antivirus and MSI Afterburner. But nothing seems to mend this issue, so unfortunately, I can't recommend you get this game in the state it's in. If you feel like taking the risk and buying this game, you may not have the same problem. I'd just make sure you refund your game if you have similar issues before Steam's refund policy runs out.

Even 10 years after its release this is a great game. Personally I love this style of game, story rich, adventure, puzzles, some combat. I'm sure they were inspired by Uncharted, and it also reminds me of the Resident Evil games. I wish the multiplayer were still available, but that's kind of a given that its gone after a decade. The 2nd installment in this series is my favorite, they really hit their stride in terms of gameplay flow and story, whereas the 3rd game was too long and too woke. I'm playing on an Apple with an M1 Pro processor, which leaves me with limited available titles, the Tomb Raider series and Resident Evil games are the best available in my estimation (also loved Metro Exodus), and I prefer the story and more responsive controls in the Tomb Raider games. All the games run really smooth as well (I do have a pretty decent MBP though).

I have never played a Tomb Raider game before. But being a big fan of the Uncharted series, and the Arkham series, which were both starting out around the same time (or just grown massively), I wanted to give this a try. This game was phenomenal, the combat is extremely smooth, climbing, transitions, cut scenes, all very smooth and well done. I give full appreciation to the detail in this game, and how the quality feels very similar if not the same as an uncharted game, and the game play of the Arkham games. Also kept par with graphics for 2013. For a good 10 hours of gameplay for the story, worth it 100%. But considering it is only 4 dollars when on sale, you can't get much better for 4 dollars on Steam.

I beat this on Playstation, so ignore lack of hours on here. Amazing game; Lara Croft saves her girlfriend from Demons and Cultists on an island in the Japanese Archipelago.

Amazing game, still looks and plays great for something from 2013. Played on Xbox when it came out and still holds up fairly well today, especially considering I got it for 80% off. Unfortunately plagued by a few of the bigger industry-wide issues of the time, with sometimes excessive QTEs and being a cover shooter, but if you can tolerate that you'll have a great time. However, later in the game there is a sequence with an undeniably ridiculous amount of extreme screen shake I had forgotten about, which was almost too much for me to tolerate even as someone who doesn't experience motion sickness all that often, especially not from gaming.

Hello!
I want to say that overall, Tomb Raider 2013 appealed to me, even though it's an absolutely awful game in the sense that gameplay is practically absent here. I can't call shooting bots and climbing painted walls gameplay. It's not even platforming. It's just pressing or holding down a single button. The crafting here is also very primitive, involving collecting one type of component throughout a level, then upgrading your weapons at specific upgrade points.

On the positive side, the action scenes are very well executed. There are many of them, and at some point, they become interesting to watch. Another positive is the combination of various types of action scenes into one prolonged cut scene. The impact of shooting bots is executed quite nicely; it's fun to shoot tin cans in the head. That's all the good stuff here.

There are sooo many bugs. There could be a gameplay cut scene where Lara stands in the forest telling some story, and in the background, due to a bug, a deer could just suddenly knock her down. It was very funny. Sometimes, a door that a bot kicked got stuck in the doorway, and I couldn't progress through the story, so I had to reload from a save. Sometimes Lara would fall from a rope in a gameplay cutscene. In short, there are many bugs, but overall, it's playable.

The story. If you've ever read at least one book in your life, any classic, you'd be astonished by how primitive everything is here; it's on the level of cartoons for children not older than 10. I'm not kidding; there's a moment when Lara loses a friend on a mission and returns to her camp. They ask her where her friend is, and she says he's dead. At first, they start criticizing her, and then a guy says, "Shh, shh, I can't make decisions on an empty stomach, let's eat some fish." And after dinner, another person says at least there was some positive moment today. So, their friend died 5 minutes ago, they sat down to enjoy dinner, and they already forgot about him. That's some amazing drama, I must say...
There's a moment where bandits bring Lara to their camp, leave her there, and say, "Just don't run away," and then 20 seconds later, they're yelling that she escaped and searching for her throughout the camp. It's incredibly absurd.

My conclusion: It's a terrible game, a terrible story, but with very cool action cut scenes. And I'm even considering buying the next part.
ist super

This is my first 3A title and my first Tomb Raider game, so take my opinion with a grain of salt.
Pros:
+ Absolutely stunning graphics.
+ Lara Croft looks gorgeous.
+ Numerous cutscenes with excellent animation and voice acting.
+ Cinematic gameplay with linear narrative.
+ Well optimised and has very few bugs (which are non game-breaking and disappear when reloading the save).
+ Intuitive control with an Xbox controller.
+ Well designed auto-save system. It even automatically saves mi-puzzle or after finding each collectible. So the penalty of death is only one or two minutes of retrying.
+ Four weapons to choose from. Bows are such a pleasure to use!

Pros or Cons, depending on your taste:
+ The player is very well guided. Some examples are given by the three next points.
+ “Survival instinct” allows you to see enemies, interactable objects, climbable walls, places to advance the story, and collectibles in your surroundings.
+ The world is mostly linear, so it is not too difficult to find your way through the map, even though the texture of objects from the same location is very similar and not that distinguishable. In fact, usually you just keep moving forward, which is the only possible direction because the other three are blocked by insurmountable objects. On the other hand, exploration is very limited since paths are mostly prescribed.
+ Puzzles are very light-weighted, including those in the optional tombs. Besides, Lara gives you verbal hints about how to proceed.
+ Metroidvania influence. Some places or collectibles are only accessible when you have the necessary gears. So getting new equipment also unlocks more ways to explore the map.
+ By well-balancing and interspersing puzzles, free roaming, action events, and cutscenes, the game keeps players engaged.
+ Depending on how much time you spend on collectibles, side quests, and option tombs, a typical first playthrough takes 10–20 hours. IMO, this is just the right length to avoid being dragging or repetitive.
* Your skills and weapons can be upgraded. You will be fully (or almost) upgraded at the end, even without much farming.
* Very few side quests.
- Quick-time events are such a pain, even on Easy mode. And some puzzles also require jumps with good timing.
- The plot is meh and contains supernatural elements. But I like the depiction of how Lara grows from a feeble lass to a strong and independent [strike]mass killer[/strike] tomb raider.
- You are still free to roam after the end. However, apart from collectibles and optional tombs, there is not much else to do, and enemies rarely spawn. The whole island feels empty, bleak, and lonely.

Serious Cons for completionists:
- Highly missable achievements that require a second playthrough to get.
- Tons of difficult-to-find collectibles necessary for certain achievements, some have no sense at all in the background setting of the game (I am looking at you, [spoiler]GPS caches![/spoiler]) some are even not shown on the in-game map.
- 30% of the achievements are related to the multiplayer mode, which is dead on arrival and not even available on macOS.

Final words:
Tomb Raider is a great game. Its story, gameplay, design, characters, graphics, all go very well together to give you a leisurely enjoyable experience, even for newcomers to 3A action games. Provided that you are not a completionist, I would say that it is a no-brainer to pick up this game. Besides, Tomb Raider is the first title of the second reboot (aka the Survivor Trilogy) of the Tomb Raider franchise. It has modern graphics, aesthetics, and gameplay design. So this is also the right starting point for anyone new to the franchise.

PS:
None of the DLC is actually useful. So if you want to save a few bucks, just buy the base game instead of the GOTY version.

Just not fun, at all.

The QTEs are immensely annoying and serve no real purpose. You would think QTEs are to emphasize player control, but they often take your control away and dump you in a cutscene immediately after. The first 30 minutes are basically alternating between QTEs and cutscenes. 

Then you get your first fetch quest. Oh hey we've hidden these dumb boxes really far away to make this tedious. Of course we could let your starting axe open the third door you attempt to pry with it, but let's not be reasonable here. But hey you can hit LB, destroy the immersion and any challenge, and beeline for your required items. Not fun.

And then we get the stealth section where I quit. And thank god too since looking at forum posts there are over 20 more stealth sections I have zero interest in.

If you like QTEs, fetch quests, and bad stealth, then this game is perfect. Not sure how most people can look past this or how this game came to be regarded so highly.

Tomb Raider (2013) is easily one of the greatest games of the genre. Its gameplay has very clear similarities to Uncharted, with the action-TPS platforming adventure aspect. There's plenty of exploration, gorgeous graphics that still hold up really well today, and a very compelling story that I found myself extremely invested in. Buy this absolute masterpiece of a game!

For me, it has game-breaking camera issues on PC: it wobbles when running straight, and when looking around while moving, it constantly auto-centers the view.
It actually makes me feel unpleasant VR-like motion symptoms, which is a first for a PC game :)

Good game, 14 hours, 31/50 achievements. 

My negatives:
1. Text would constantly display OUT of my display. No option to fix this, only workaround is to manually go into your GPU's settings and adjust for dead zones (I am not doing that lol)

2. DLC Tomb WILL glitch out if you complete in any unintended order

3. There are multiplayer achievements; this is an issue due to MP servers being taken offline..for many years. 

4. Handful of times I had to reload checkpoint in order to proceed due to map glitching, placeholders being..out of place..

That being said, I'd replay it. Awesome single-player story driven narrative, good combat sequences, fun exploration, deep lore.

As someone who doesn't play a lot of games (especially action) I was quite hesitant to purchase the game, however, for less than £3, I'd be silly not to! I absolutely loved this game! The pace of it is perfect, allowing you to learn combat and different things as you go and the story is very easy to follow. I love the side quests and the fact that you are able to explore areas by finding items; really adds to the story and how immersive it is. 

Considering it's not a new game, you really get the emotions behind the characters and easily make bonds with them. The graphics are really good, even for 2023 so I can only imagine how amazing it was 10 years ago. 

Honestly, for the price of the game I got it for, you really can't complain! Win win scenario indeed.

Gameplay is generic and derivative, average at best. But my god, the writing is ATROCIOUS. If they lent into it a little more it could have almost been so bad it’s good, but as it is it’s just bad. Up there with the worst writing I’ve ever seen in a game.

Add to that a crash to desktop bug near the beginning, a terrible ending sequence where death puts you back to just before an unskippable cutscene, annoying QTEs, and a bizarre save system where checkpoints can save before campsite save points, but when loading the save the game gives you a warning, gaslighting you into loading an earlier save.

On top of that despite all the media and messaging saying that Lara isn’t sexualised, she is still incredibly sexualised. At least the original Tomb Raider knew what it was doing and was honest about it.

All in all, I cannot recommend this game in any capacity, and it is in my opinion an irredeemable piece of utter trash. I’m astounded that it has overwhelmingly positive reviews, and I wish I never purchased it based off those reviews.

[h1] Tomb Raider [/h1]
Graphics (★★★★☆):

Tomb Raider boasts breathtaking visuals, showcasing detailed environments and character models. The island setting is both lush and dangerous, creating a visually stunning backdrop for Lara Croft's adventure. The attention to detail in animations and the dynamic weather system contribute to an overall immersive visual experience.

Gameplay (★★★★☆):

The gameplay in Tomb Raider is a strong blend of exploration, puzzle-solving, and action. Lara's character development from a vulnerable survivor to a capable adventurer is well-executed. The platforming sequences and puzzle design are engaging, providing a good balance between challenge and accessibility. The combat mechanics, while not groundbreaking, are solid, making firefights and stealth sections enjoyable.

Story and Characters (★★★★☆):

The narrative in Tomb Raider is a standout feature. The story of Lara's origin and transformation into the iconic adventurer is compelling and emotionally charged. The character development is well-paced, and Lara's vulnerability adds depth to her journey. The supporting cast complements the narrative, making for a memorable storytelling experience in the rebooted series.

Sound and Music (★★★★★):

The audio design in Tomb Raider is exceptional. The sound effects, ambient noises, and voice acting contribute to a rich and immersive atmosphere. The musical score enhances the emotional impact of key moments, creating a cinematic experience. Lara's grunts and gasps during intense situations add a layer of realism to the overall audio presentation.

Replayability (★★★☆☆):

While the story-driven nature of Tomb Raider may limit its replayability compared to open-world games, the inclusion of collectibles, challenge tombs, and alternate paths in the game world encourages exploration. The sense of discovery and the desire to uncover every secret may entice players to revisit the island, but the linear structure may deter some from multiple playthroughs.

Overall Rating (★★★★☆):

Tomb Raider successfully revitalizes the iconic franchise with a gripping narrative, stunning visuals, and a well-balanced mix of exploration and action. The character development of Lara Croft and the emotional depth of the story set it apart. While the linear structure may limit replayability for some, the overall package delivers a thrilling and memorable gaming experience for fans of action-adventure games. Lara's origin story is a triumph, and Crystal Dynamics' reboot sets a strong foundation for the future of the series.

Simply loved this game and was one hell of a Tomb Raider. There were many ways they could've messed up, but I believe they made a really interesting story with many interesting little parts to it like the journals and artefacts you can pick up. I'm disappointed about what I heard about the sequel, but if they don't want my money then sod them.

This is well worth it, especially on a sale!

Edit: The game is a reboot of the whole Tomb Raider series where Lara Croft goes to investigate one of these mythical locations, theorised by her father, with her friends in the hopes to find a lost archaeological discovery that has eluded people for generations, but instead they found that mythology has a lot more basis in reality than they ever realised!

With this situation and Lara being put into the most intense of situations, she goes from merely a smart rich girl, to a bad-ass survivalist who ends up with a lot of blood on her hands of both animals for survival and humans in regards to defending herself, her friends and saving others.

In all, this is meant to have been a origin story for a reboot of the Tomb Raider series and I feel that they had certainly achieved this whilst creating a fun new story too.

Man oh man,
This game was an absolute blast to play. Seriously, the story was interesting with unique characters that have pretty decent depth and it definitely had me invested. The voice acting is believable, the soundtrack's pretty awesome, traversal is fun with decent freedom and engagement, and at times, the platforming makes you feel like an absolute boss. Also, the way this game is structured and with the cinematography is quite engaging, giving you the feeling of really being on this ride with Lara. The environments were varied and absolutely stunning and the atmosphere was pretty fitting and immersive. The puzzles were fun and sometimes elaborate though mostly pretty easy. Also, the graphics have held up really well considering it's an almost 9 year old game, mostly with playing it on PC. The combat is also quite well thought out and just really fun.

Coming to the combat, this game has some pretty darn good variety, allowing you get a bit creative from time to time with the way you approach a given combat scenario. And while the AI isn't the smartest, it's also not the worst either, depending on the difficulty, they really do force you to keep moving and employ tactics to take them down. The enemies clearly are trying to kill you and they're pretty good at it. The stealth isn't actually as bad as I had thought and was pretty fun and the upgrade system for your character and weapons felt genuinely substantial, leading to satisfying player progression.

The amount of content in this game is just awesome (took me about 25 hours to beat) and I really did just have a blast all the way through. Even the side missions were fun, which, by the way, take the form of tombs that you can explore (the same goes for the DLC), solving their puzzles to uncover their hidden treasures. The collectibles and journal entries (which are all voiced) were actually interesting and uncover a lot of lore surrounding the history behind the places you're visiting (as well as info and backstories of some of the characters) and it gave me a pretty good reason to find them other than just for achievements. and concerning the ending, a lot of foreshadowing was actually made through the collectibles and journal entries. Lastly, the online is actually surprisingly fun, which is why it saddens me to see it pretty much dead.

Overall, I wholly recommend this game. I found it to be a great experience with great storytelling and I had tons of fun with it and plus, I got this game with all the DLC's for 6 bucks CAD on a sale which is an absolute steal and worth every penny. Of course though, this game isn't perfect and I do have a few gripes with this game including some of the achievements, which, were honestly quite ridiculous and super annoying to get and that the AI wasn't the best (though still totally adequate and still better than a lot of other triple a games **Ahem Far Cry 5**).

This game definitely deserves a [b]9.5/10[/b]

Please give it a go, you won't regret it.

Adventure found me.

'Tomb Raider' is the reboot of the beloved series of adventures featuring the fearless woman Lara Croft. In this game however.

Lara is NOTHING like she used to be, she is weak, scared, unexperienced and had just graduated. She does not go out raiding tombs and treasures, because she wants to, she just gets thrown into this life by destiny. When she and her comrads sail to the island Yamatai to film it and discover some 'treasures' for money, their ship gets caught in a mysterious storm and everyone gets seperated. Now it's up to you, to find your friends and escape this island. Throughout the game you need to learn how to hunt, fight, craft new weapons, survive... and sometimes raid tombs... in order to get out of there alive. Lara quickly learns, that the island and it's presence is her greatest enemy. The animals are not the only ones, that want Lara dead, but also an ancient army (which I'm not gonna go into more detail here) and fearsome hunters who inhabit the dangerous island.

Tomb Raider is a solid singleplayer third-person action adventure with a catching story, great gameplay and beautiful visuals. 

The gameplay does remind alot of the 'Uncharted' series, which is not a bad thing, considering the games are both similar. A multiplayer mode, similar to 'The Last of Us' multiplayer is also included, but not a big highlight and definately not needed. If you think of buying the Game of the Year edition, there's no need in doing so, since it only comes with one 5 minute tomb and TONS of useless multiplayer skins, which noone needs anyways.

I strongly recommend 'Tomb Raider' to everyone who likes action adventures like 'Uncharted' and games with great gameplay and graphics.

Quality and polished adventure action game. Solid all around.

If you're coming from the previous Tomb Raider games, don't expect the same game. It's a completely different game. Far less puzzles and no annoying, stiff camera that makes you want to drink bleach. There are some puzzles and stuff that makes you use the old brain but nothing that overstays its welcome - thankfully - if I wanted to use my brain I'd go back to school. The previous games were ALL just one big headache - constantly battling the camera and failing jumps you should realistically have been able to make. In this game, there's none of that. Everything just works. Everything makes sense. It's fluid and just lots of fun. If you're like me and were never able to stomach the previous games then yeah, I 100% recommend this.

Pros and Cons

[b] Pros [/b]

+ The graphics are amazing - blood, dirt, grime and injuries appear on Lara over time. There's hair physics! The views are pretty breathtaking and the world is just awesome to run around in. 
+ Nice soundtrack.
+ Character movement and climbing is user friendly and precise.
+ Semi open world with fast travel.  
+ Fun collectables including relics which you can inspect and manipulate for a closer look.
+ Fun and diverse combat with optional stealth - the stealth is a bit meh but works well enough. You can go guns blazing with the assault rifle or snipe your enemies from afar with the bow or use a silenced pistol Splinter Cell style or even sneak up behind enemies and kill them that way or by using the environment - and so much more!
+ Lots of epic moments - an action packed, adrenaline fuelled adventure - imagine if Michael Bay directed a Tomb Raider movie! It'd be this game.
+ The weapon upgrade system is cool with weapons becoming more fancy over time as you upgrade them.
+ An actual story - a story of survival. But there's also plenty there to sate you appetite for adventure and discovery - learning about the island and its history through journals, relics, exploring tombs and so on.

Yeah, sometimes I felt like I was playing Assassin's Creed or something!

Another good thing is that after you beat the game, you can go back and collect any collectables you might've missed so don't worry about them too much. Enjoy the story! Relax. I enjoyed it so much I beat the game over the course of 2-3 days and 100%'d the single player.

[b] Cons [/b]

- There's a lot of QTE's and I blame them for 99% of my deaths. Sometimes they just don't work or don't really make it clear what you're supposed to do or what button you're meant to press. I guess the camera (in these situations) can still get in the way.
- The game can be a bit buggy at times with collectables not appearing until you leave and reenter the area (that's a little pro tip - what worked me anyway - same with that glitched DLC tomb).
- There's no new game plus.
- The multiplayer appears to be dead.
- There's no player vs AI bots mode in multiplayer.

Those last two would've been nice and could've added some more hours of gameplay I think.

I recommend playing with an Xbox 360 controller. The QTE's are easier to understand then and well, in my opinion, it just feels a lot more natural.

Overall, absolutely worth it and a bargain if you get it now while it's on sale. £10 or under - 100%!

[b]Hey gamers, let's delve into Tomb Raider (2013), a game that reimagined Lara Croft's origins and brought us an adventure that's both captivating and visually stunning. Here's why this game's a true gem:[/b]
[list]
[*][b]Rebirth of an Icon: Tomb Raider (2013) marks the rebirth of Lara Croft. It's like witnessing the evolution of a legend, from a vulnerable survivor to a determined, kick-ass adventurer.[/b]

[*][b]A Masterpiece of Beauty: This game is a very beautiful game... amazing graphics 10/10! The island vistas, the lush environments, and the intricate details - it's like exploring a living, breathing world.[/b]

[*][b]Gripping Storytelling: The narrative hooks you from the start. It's like reading an adventure novel you can't put down, with unexpected twists and moments that keep you on the edge of your seat.[/b]

[*][b]Character Development: Lara's transformation is portrayed brilliantly. It's like witnessing a butterfly emerge from its cocoon - she grows stronger, braver, and more resilient with each challenge.[/b]

[*][b]Action-Packed Gameplay: From climbing cliffs to intense combat and puzzle-solving, the gameplay is a perfect blend. It's like a rollercoaster ride with moments of adrenaline-pumping action and quieter, more reflective segments.[/b]

[*][b]Visual Spectacle: The game's environments are breathtaking. It's like being in a postcard-worthy setting at every turn - and let's not forget the stunning weather effects that add to the immersion.[/b]

[*][b]Immersive Exploration: Exploring tombs and uncovering secrets feels incredibly rewarding. It's like being an archaeologist on a grand adventure, discovering hidden treasures and unraveling ancient mysteries.[/b]

[*][b]Legacy of Lara Croft: Tomb Raider (2013) pays homage to the legacy of Lara Croft while carving a new path. It's like respecting the past while stepping boldly into the future.[/b]
[/list]
[b]In summary, Tomb Raider (2013) is a testament to the franchise, delivering an emotionally charged, visually stunning adventure. It's a must-play for gamers who appreciate a blend of captivating storytelling, immersive exploration, and jaw-dropping visuals. So grab your gear, follow Lara's journey, and get ready for an unforgettable adventure![/b]

[h1]The Gameplay: [/h1]
A fast paced third person shooter mixed with a touch of QTE that feels just right. The game understands pacing so as much action as it dishes out, it knows when to take a break so you can process what's happened. The gunplay is solid and responsive. There are better iterations of this, but this is a solid take that will take you through the entire game. Navigating through different areas with the use of different tools to navigate areas is a very nice touch and will scratch a lot of itches when it comes to exploration. The leveling system feels just right and avoids using silly damage numbers in a non-mmo game.

[h1]The Story:[/h1]
The story is engaging with characters that are interesting and believable. The pacing mentioned earlier plays a big role here, it is done in such a way that carries the narrative without actually moving too fast or too slow. It even incorporates a bit of mystery which is a nice touch. All the characters are developed enough to understand each one of their motives and even grow to like or hate them. The use of diaries from different time periods makes the story of what's happen feel like the world exists outside of what Lara does in it. They even hinted at some history that would make a great game/movie on it's own with her dad. Perhaps one day we will see Father Croft, Roth and Grim bring a bunch of badasses. 

[h1]The Visuals:[/h1]
This a visual theme park and actually still looks great even by today's standards. It's often been used as a benchmark for how good a computer runs, so I would say they had to do a good job. The enviorment is both a visual spectacle and very iconic, where I can tell what part of the game someone is at by a mere glance.  Most important is the attention to detail on Lara herself. Much like in the batman Arkham series, Lara will gain wounds through out the story and they will show. This slow but sure battering of your character is adds to overall experience. 

[h1]The Sound:[/h1]
The music is a real winner here, they made a custom track that would carry the entire story and even the series itself. The effect this has cannot be overstated, it's one of the often overlooked pieces where some games just slap on some decent music that feels disjointed from the game. This on the other hand with it's music feels like a unified experience. The voice acting of all characters, major and minor are absolutely pivotal. Lara's voice actor in particular had done an incredible job.


[h1]The Experience:[/h1]
Once upon a time I had mildly enjoyed the old Tomb Raider, although it was mostly because I felt like I had to play it due to the marketing. In all honesty the experience was alright and as such any new game that came out just immediately fell under the radar. This particular reboot in how the gameplay is modernized and brought to a state of semi realism did wonders. Instead of the graceful dual wielding 7 star heroine, we find someone who struggles, feels pain is hurt a lot but bears through all of that. A complaint some detractors would have is that she complains too much - I would like to see them go through half of that without muttering a single gripe. The super human gets boring, this new Lara is how I will remember Tomb Raider, we need more like this.

I was an avid gamer back in the original days of Tomb Raider in the 1990s. I played and enjoyed them all.  They were revolutionary back then. So after many years away from gaming, one of the first franchises I returned to was Tomb Raider. This entry from 2013 (a decade ago as of this writing) put everything I remembered about the franchise to shame. I was blown away by the quality of the graphics and of the storyline. 

The essence was the same, mind you, the spirit of the original was still there, not the execution, the tools at the developers disposal and the finished product were absolutely mind blowing. I am so glad I came back to gaming after almost 20 years. This game alone made the return and even the years away worthwhile. 

Whether you’re a tomb raider fan of old, a new addition to the franchise or not a fan yet at all, this game will draw you in and make you feel satisfied. I highly recommend it
best game

"Throughout the game, you're tasked with solving elaborate puzzles and taking on sporadic groups of enemies; in addition to plenty of platforming and exploration. After you finish Tomb Raider's long-winded tutorial, it easily rivals the best Uncharted has to offer--and that's not a claim made lightly. Where Uncharted props itself up on Nathan Drake's charm, platforming prowess, and ability to shoot dudes in the head without getting bummed out, Tomb Raider's foundation is one of excellent pacing, and an ominous story of survival." - Gamesradar, 2014

Tomb Rider is  the game that turned my girlfriend into the Lara Croft of our living room while I played the supportive sidekick fetching snacks. It's like watching an action movie, but with more controller button mashing and fewer complaints about my popcorn distribution skills.

The graphics are a glorious upgrade from the pixelated past, where Lara's every move looked smoother than my attempts at impressing her with dance moves. It's like witnessing the evolution of Lara from triangular adventurer to a polygonal powerhouse—still with a knack for defying gravity.

The gameplay is a hilarious rollercoaster of jumps, falls, and the occasional "Ouch!" that makes every death a comedy act. It's like an improv show where the main character has a penchant for plummeting off cliffs, and the audience (me) gets a front-row seat to the spectacle.

The story is a nostalgic journey through Lara's rebooted origins, where my girlfriend embarked on a digital quest that rivaled Lara's own adventures. It's like being a side character in a blockbuster film, where the real hero is the one holding the controller.

In conclusion, Tomb Rider is not just a game; it's a time capsule of laughter, a reminder of Lara's evolution, and a testament to my girlfriend's virtual badassery. So, salute to the queen of tombs and get ready for a trip down memory lane that's more entertaining than any Hollywood reboot.

[h1]Peak Tomb Raider[/h1]
[u]9/10[/u]
I have played every Tomb Raider since the last 2 reboots (Legend, Anniversary, Underworld, 2013,  Rise, Shadow) and without a doubt in my mind, this is the best one. Story is great, gameplay is very fun and enjoyable and for once, you actually feel like a Tomb Raider in these games. Strongly Recommended if you haven't yet played the last reboot (2013, Rise, Shadow.)

The only Tomb Raider game where Lara is a scared-clueless woman with innocent excitement - gotten into such an adventure where almost everything goes downhill for her. She knows stuff, for sure, but has to figure out what to do in what order, which sets an environment for her to demonstrate what she can do to what degree and evolve into a leader and survivor along the game.

Compared to the other two games, this game is about seeing her confusion about her surroundings. Constantly asking questions, facing tough decisions, learning, changing, being a beginner, survivor, and a leader to survive on the island.

I would have liked to see that in the other two games as well - maybe I'll cut some slacks to the RORT, but SOTR is no excuse. You'll know what I mean once you play them.

The gameplay is very nice and fluid, with great mechanics. The map has places integrated into the story where you find yourself in a bloody ditch or a cave, fighting floods, exploring the island, or climbing up the clouds. It's just perfect.

If you're like me, love to play long series, explore how the characters change, and want a bit of fighting and looting, this game is perfect for you. I hope you like it.

I tried playing this game previously. Years ago. I do not remember why I abandoned it then.
Recently I decided to revisit it and explore what the game has to offer.
Typically when I'm playing a game I lean heavily into exploration: leaving no stone unturned and trying to explore every corner of the map.
With Tomb Raider it is pretty difficult to do. Levels feel corridor-like, limiting and constricting the exploration. That is especially so with prologue when you need to battle bad dudes in a burning building.
Maybe this is essential for a puzzle-focused game. But for example Talos Principle does not feel that claustrophobic even despite also being puzzle-focused. Even Portal despite de-facto being incredibly restrictive and devoid of exploration feels more airy and spacious.
Controls also don't feel as well thought out as they are in other games. I am finding myself mildly annoyed by the need to double-tap the space bar in order to perform a wall climb.
The plot so far is ok, but I did not get far to judge the entire story.
Eventually I decided not to force myself to finish the game just because I started it and to follow the fun.
As for graphics they are OK. I have seen games from the same period that aged significantly worse in terms of graphical fidelity (ahem FarCry 3 ahem).

I'm still making my review a positive one, since it is a good quality game and I may be biased to underappreciate it because of its genre or rather sub-genre.

The first game in the reboot of the series and it is showing its age, both graphically and gameplay wise. The gameplay loop is fun, you do some platforming, some combat and you traverse a well build island you got stranded on by a storm, searching for a way off the island while simultaneously uncovering its secrets. The gameplay loop does get repetitive really fast. The devs tried to combat this by slowly opening up new ways to traverse the island, but it is not enough to save you from boredom. This game is best played in sittings of 1,5 to maximum 2 hours at a time.

Then there is a lot of early 2010's gaming quirks that you need to ignore in order to not lose the immersion because you can easily ruin the immersion by asking why, who and when. Why are there ropes around this beam? Who put these ropes here and why did they put the ropes here? The answer is always simple and it is the ropes are there so you can shoot an arrow with a rope into it, the devs put it there and they were put there during development. There is no other reason for the ropes to be there, same goes for a lot of other stuff.

This is still a fun game, and if you intent on playing the entire trilorgy I would certainly not skip this. I've played about 8.5 hours so far and the in game menu says I have completed the game for 50%. Going by those numbers I estimate 15 to 20 hours to finish this game, depending on how many of the challenges and secrets you want to do.

A different take on the Tomb Raider formula from the original and reboot series, this one tells the story of a younger Lara who is just starting to go the way of the badass we all love. The setting is quite interesting and the backstory slowly revealing itself follows the tone of the older games, with the supernatural slowly being introduced through the course of the story. 

It is a more linear experience, which is in no way a bad thing. Rather, the interconnected areas give incentive to explore them thoroughly and find the hidden relics, salvage etc.

A great game and solid intro to the Survivor trilogy.

Good gameplay. Meh story. Okay graphics.
(Play the games in order otherwise you will probably be disappointed)

[h3]Important Screen Fix:[/h3]
If you have screen clipping issue like I did, right click on the game in your library, click properties, go to betas and select "build 743.0 - TR Build 1-01.7430." Now you will be able to see the whole screen.

Oh and many achievements are from multiplayer (which is dead unless you organise it), so [b]if you're an achievement hunter looking for a game to perfect, this is not it[/b] unless you have friends or find willing participants. If there's a Discord for this please leave the link in the comment to help other people out and I'll ediit the post accordingly.

[h3]The Review:[/h3]
Dunno who will read this review. Recommended? The game on its own is not that bad, but I did not enjoy it, truthfully, so no. I was fed up several times and took days to pick it up again. Here are the details for playing on Hard:

The story, the characters and the combat is just so, soooo cheesy it's borderline annoying. Story going-through is convenience after convenience.

Lara Croft, a young adult with no real combat experience is handling weapons like a professional... with no background of handling weapons. That's a problem. She reloads faster than John Wick and is knowledgeable about weapons enough to "upgrade" them. Ph. Okay. In the end she has bigger body count than Rambo too. Way to go girl!

Enemies just run at you. Hiding behind a cover? Look at that head peeking out, BOOM headshot. Someone came close? Headshot. Dodge+finishoff or swap to shotgun if you wanna save ammo (you'd think), swap back to gun/bow and continue on the fire while barely taking any damage unless you expose yourself to someone with an automatic rifle (reason for all of my few deaths). After combat you loot most of your ammo back... Is this supposed to be Hard? No higher difficulty? Come on...

A young woman that does not workout can take on big men. Mhm. Yup. She's acting like a well seasoned climber without putting it in the backstory (again). Strong cold winds tear at her and Lara is climing the ice almost half naked. Yeah sell us the boobs! /facepalm

[b]AND I GET IT THAT ITS A VIDEO GAME![/b] And true, not all of the enemies you meet are with military background, but come on... Character Sam likes to record, and we don't have a single recording of Lara working out to keep in shape or some shooting range fun of any kind. That alone could've fixed Lara's character and I would not have as much of a problem, honestly. Or a flashback of her father or someone else teaching her how to handle weapons. ANYTHING really.

[h3]Tombs:[/h3]
And that's for the story and the shooting part of the gameplay. This is stil Tomb Raider, right?

Tombs are like this: walk straight, get a puzzle for a five year old, get "treasure" and exit via a shortcut. All of them. "Tombs" don't have labyrinths of any kind, no traps, no elaborate puzzles, no challenge whatsoever. Only one has something hidden but its also obvious, just maybe not in the heat of the battle.

[h3]In a nuthsell...[/h3]
While this is a negative review please understand that it is not that bad of a video game! Buy it if you want to explore the series like I am right now. It's 15€ game so its not a big purchase. Atm its on 80% sale for 3€ too, so buy it if you're interested.

I just know that I won't replay this. It's too easy and linear with no challenge and the story is very cheesy. It has its good and interesting moments but its too rare for me to enjoy. I hope the next game is designed better.
