Having had the privilege to be able to play all three games of the so-called 'Survivor Trilogy' back to back, I'm best placed to review this one both on its own merits and in relation to the others. My only other reference point in terms of the wider TR franchise is really [I]Legend[/I] (2006).

Of course, that latter score seems the least fair here. [I]Tomb Raider's[/I] scope certainly doesn't match that of the later games in the series, but it's still a fundamental must play as an introduction to the trilogy and a very new and different Lara. Gone is the sassy, assured woman in her late 20s/early thirties, and in her place is a much younger Lara. A Lara who also feels a lot more real in her responses to the narrative. Lara runs the full gamut of fear, sympathy, loss, grief, rage and despair as she tries to see the crew of the [I]Endurance[/I] safely off the island of Yamataï where their expedition becomes shipwrecked.

Indeed, that crew is one aspect of the game to have aged less well. Contrary to the depth of characterisation here for Lara, many of the [I]Endurance's[/I] crew members feel one dimensional and in service to key plot points - and it feels like there are a lot of them as well. To widespread fan dismay, perhaps the most narratively promising of Lara's relationships, that with Sam, is disappointingly under-explored.

What has aged well (and indeed continued to mature from title to title) is the Metroidvania gameplay, with a steady drip feed of weapons, items and moves enabling Lara to access more and more of the island and strip away those 'gear needed, come back later' prompts that bar you from areas you want to access. [I]Tomb Raider[/I] plays well, like all my favourites, with verticality, and the shimmying, climbing and jumping are fantastic. Star of the show is of course the now-iconic bow, although in this entry it definitely feels less assured of its place, being relegated in my playthrough to a utility item while the pistol and assault rifle did the heavy lifting. On that former note, stealth is incredibly enjoyable even in this title, a mechanic that again matured greatly in future titles.

The game also feels really nicely paced - a head-scratching tomb explore here, an absolutely hellish transition to the next set piece there (let down a little by QTEs, it must be said) and then a big combat set piece next. All the while, Lara accrues experience and salvage to feed into perks and weapon upgrades. Both feel positively sparse in comparison to later titles, but players less appreciative of such systems will welcome the lighter touch here. I still admit to being unable to fathom when and how the game drops the pieces for weapons that change them into entirely better models, and the seeming randomness of this was frustrating.

There is no doubt in my mind that the later games did many things better. I preferred [I]Rise[/I]'s combat and [I]Shadow's[/I] scope and exploration, but I'd say that this has the tightest storyline of the lot, being less offering as it is of side quests and distractions. Those that there are in the form of challenge tombs do feel at times that they lack distinction.

It's an excellent starting point, and definitely the most pure and functional iteration of the formula.

Tomb Raider (2013)

I am a big Tomb Raider fan. Curiously enough, this is what makes it difficult for me to review this game. Let me say first that 'Tomb Raider (2013)' is a great game and an easy recommendation. As a game per se my vote is a 9/10, it is extremely fun to play. Despite having its fair share of flaws it is an immensely enjoyable ride. But - but: This is not a 'Tomb Raider' game, and 'Lara Croft' is not Lara Croft in this game. These are just labels tacked on.

The Good
- Great gameplay: Exploring, fighting, upgrading your avatar - all these are perfect.
- Fantastic level design, borrowing the 'hub' mechanics from no other title than 'Dark Souls'. After exploring different areas of the island, you always find ways back to earlier areas, interconnecting different parts and making it a real big whole world built in a very clever way.
- Interesting and engaging avatar. S.b. for more comments.
- Great objectives: Lara has to go through a series of challenging and constantly life-threatening chores, it is really a 'big adventure', just like the prologue says.
- Awesome soundtrack which even employs an instrument specifically built for this game.

Neutral
- Lots of explosions and over-the-top action sequences. It is a big spectacle, but don't expect any subtlety. Appreciating the aesthetics of Michael Bay definitely helps.
- Underwhelming ending and boss fight. Well, you can't have everything.
- Tomb raiding is moved to the background with 'optional' 'tomb' areas. This is the most blatant indicator for this game heavily borrowing from the 'Uncharted' franchise in the first place and then considering how to transmogrify the thing into a 'Tomb Raider' instalment.

The Bad
- Side characters and the antagonist a shallow cardboard pieces serving as mere placeholders for real characters. This is a big problem: Why should the player care about them? As 'Legend' and 'Underworld' already indicated, this game proves Crystal Dynamics is really not up to writing good characters.
- Crystal Dynamics cannibalizes the franchise with some badly written dialogue ("You're a Croft" and other items like these). Given that this is an origin story, it is rather out of place. Lara and the player are supposed to earn this rather than being told before actually doing anything. It's funny that this is as bad as the companion feature film (the 'Tomb Raider' atrocity with Alicia Vikander) which treats us to gems like "You are a real Tomb Raider". Phew.
- Bad dialogue between the companions in general: Nobody can give a straight answer. There is much quarreling when they should be interested in forming a survival community above all else. Story design isn't Crystal Dynamics strength, either, although it is not as bad as the characterization department.

My personal beef: 'Tomb Raider 2013' isn't 'Tomb Raider' anymore
- While the gameplay is great, there is no resemblance to former platforming and puzzle solving anymore.
- Lara gets a new biography, a different set of characteristics and a more realistic appearance. You may hail this as progress, I do not.
- This is a hard reboot that changes almost everything with respect to earlier instalments while keeping some elements to cash in on former accomplishments. In my opinion, this game would have been even better, if they had moved it out of the franchise and gave the protagonist a different name and biography.
- To me Crystal Dynamics' approach is an unpleasant rumination of how US-American developers think a heroine from the British aristocracy should look and act like. Core Design managed to make Lara Croft tough, cool and sympathetic while letting her do things that were often anything but lady-like. For me that was one of the biggest appeals - and now this is quite irrevocably lost.

So i have given it a third Try, since i am right now on a Tomb Raider hype Train for some Reason (a Coincident that the Remaster of the first three was announced). 

This Game has some Flaws, especially the Quick Time Events, it was really hard to overcome this Issue, as you have to do the Stuff again and again and again. 
It seems it is even broken with Keyboard and Mouse, but you are mostly "fine" with a Controller. 

The second Elephant in the Room are the Characters, they aren't really good writen and it is a pure Embarrassment. 
The overall Scenario isn't bad, but it is a cringy Fest. 

What i also dislike is that the Physics of what Lara can reach and not is often lacking any Logic. 
She jumps and stops falling to dock onto were she is supposed to Land. 
The older Games, as TR1, feel here more logical and realistic.

To the Good:
The Graphics are really really really good and Laras Animations are outstanding.
The Game isn't as demanding, my 6700 XT is pretty quite and also my older 580 Pulse wasn't really under hard Pressure. 

The Gameplay also brings much Joy, especially when you are in Areas were you can decide if you go full Rambo or you bring the sneaky Death to your Enemies. 

It is also cleverly made that your Weapons have a second Mode that gives you something as the Granate Launcher.

In the End the Gun Play and the Presentation are overweighting the Quick Time Events and the weak Characters.

This specific Tomb Raider is a canon event for me. Up until then, I had played only casual games that didn't involve combat or shooting. The first hour had me doubting my choice, it was tough. The combat was a struggle, and QTEs during fights? Don't even get me started.
But...I couldn't get it out of my head. I just kept coming back for more. With each playthrough, it started to click. The more I played, the more I loved it.
When I finally reached the end, I knew this game had secured a spot in my personal top five games of all time.
Thank you, developers, for making Lara Croft one of the most iconic female protagonists in the world of video games. She emerged as a powerful, independent, and capable figure who redefined what a female gaming protagonist could be.

The saves on my steamdeck are like `profile.dat` `save1.dat` `lastcamp.dat` and on  my macbook they are the same name, but the extension is .macdat. Especially now that the game is $15 normally and currently on sale for like, three, it's definitely solid. It's definitely a product of the time, doing something with Tomb Raider:Uncharted::James Bond:Jason Bourne. You can also tell how old I am by casually using analogy format. Anyway, Tomb Raider had been on the decline for a number of reasons, while the more "cinematic" and action-y Uncharted was on the way up. Also there were a lot of reboots and origin stories going around. 

So this is the game that took the aristocratic busty british adventuress and made her a post-grad student off as a junior member in her first major expedition. And man, they are not nice to her. She gets broken, hurt, tortured and just generally put through the ringer- and that's not even touching on the death animations. All of this, though, makes the character arc pretty satisfying for when she's on a rampage at the end. There's also the Katniss Everdeen "girls with bows" thing going on. 

Really, if you're considering the reboot Tomb Raider games, this is pretty good and is easily the budget choice. HOWEVER, if you're only going to get one, get Rise of the Tomb Raider. Without getting into specifics, Rise is the best combination of gameplay and story- especially with the side content. All three games have essentially the same plotline with mild variations, including the same character arc for Lara.

Tomb Raider honestly got me pretty good. I went in expecting something like Uncharted but with a different coat of paint. What I got was an adventure game that felt more and more like something straight out of the Indiana Jones movies. 

The entire game is full of mystery and adventure. I had some good guesses as to what was going to happen next, but I was never able to get my guesses right on the money. The story, while a bit all over the place at times, holds up well. I was able to understand the events unfolding before me without any issue. I really enjoyed watching the emergence of the Croft name in Lara throughout the story. With every new tool, skill, weapon, or event; a little bit more of the Croft name appeared in Lara. This added a beautiful evolutionary tale to the game that I really enjoyed watching unfold. 

The game plays wonderfully. Nothing felt too convoluted or frustrating. In my eighteen hours I only came across two bugs. Of which only one was during the main path. Neither of which were game breaking in any way and were actually quite funny; one was even helpful. I really love the weapon uses and upgrades. The skill paths also do a lot for unlocking new ways to play. I found myself discovering all new ways to take out enemies even at the very end of the game. All of the combat was incredibly fun. Every encounter left me wanting more. The one thing I wish was used more was the instinct system. It's such an interesting part of the game and unfortunately is best used during optional parts of the game. 

The extra activities provided in the game are more than just wonderful. It's your usual collectathon type of thing so don't expect too many new things from it. The tombs are short but sweet, each one being memorable and none being too similar to another. The activities in some areas are my favorite part of the optional content. They all follow the same hide and seek rule set, but shake it up in different ways to keep things fresh. I can only count two as being too similar to each other. This is where the instinct mechanic shines the brightest. There were two of these though that did become more annoying than fun even with the instinct mechanic in play. One had me looking for something small that was obscured at ground level and the other had me looking somewhere that you'd never think to look. The latter being almost impossible to see without instinct. These are the only two I had to look up, but the rest were all fairly simple and fun to find. 

Tomb Raider has become one of my favorites that I've played this year and was enjoyable all the way through. I recommend it to anyone who's into action adventure games. If you're into the Uncharted series then this is a different, yet similar take on that formula so I definitely recommend that Uncharted fans check this one out.

So what can I tell you here that a hundred thousand people have not said already?

I bought Tomb Raider and completed it with the intent of enjoying a blockbuster cinematic interactive experience and I got EXACTLY what I asked for... :)

My last experience before this with Tomb Raider was when I played Tomb Raider III on PS1, which I completed, and then I played just a little of the next one, The Last Revelation... I was aware of the critical reception of all the subsequent titles. I can summize that they did a great job in bringing Lara into a new era.

If anything, some of the story-telling elements relied on some obvious tropes to convey an emotional message but for the most part it is what story-telling surmounts to ultimately. 

It is the extravagance of the story with suspension-of-disbelief fully engaged that makes the story a memorable and enthralling experience.

The gameplay is of course fluid and the movement and pace feels natural and there are a lot of rewarding gun-play segments and variety of set-pieces and locations that naturally progress with the story to then explore through and overcome, which all supplements to the emotional investment and immersion with the character itself, in essence what makes the player feel like its their journey as much as it is the character's to finish.

Price Paid: About 2 Dollars

This game is such a beautiful reboot. The grandness of the adventure that they managed to fit onto one island is absolutely wild. I never felt bored while playing the story through, set piece to set piece. The game gives you a great sense of progression and incentive to explore. This is one of the only games I've ever 100% finished (apart from achievements, some of which are now obsolete lol). I highly recommend this if you love narratively driven movie games that aren't just QTE and choices. While yes, there are QTEs in this game, they don't intrude too much to the point where you're only watching a cutscene and pressing some buttons. The cinematography, speaking of, is superb. Thank god there's two more games to play in this fantastic reboot for such a classic franchise.

TL;DR: This game is dope asf, go play it.

That's enough said, but if you're interested, here's a super long explanation for why I like it so much (very minor spoilers ahead):
It helps that my expectations were pretty low going into it. It was the same thing with Daredevil and Mission Impossible so that probably helps me like things more. But I was just like "oh, hot chick shoots a bunch of bad guys, might be okay"
I started the game and I liked how it got straight into the action. I hate when things start out really slow. I liked that about the Dark Knight, too, and I think it really helps with the immersion imo
and you see all the characters yelling at each other on the beach and I thought that drama was kind of fun
And the first area of the game there are puzzles which I like
There's a lot of quick time events and the game borderline plays itself for the first section, but I still liked it because it still managed to be exciting (and it still is, even after years of playing)
And then you're introduced to some platforming and I thought it was really well done. To me the most important part of a video game is how pleasant the movement is. It's why I love Sly Cooper and partly why I love Marvel's Spider-Man, 2 of my favorite games
and the first area where you go along the cliff with the rain coming off the rocks is when I realized just how pretty the game is
to me, it's the perfect blend between realistic and stylized
And right before you get the bow, you go through a short box canyon and to the right there is a gps cache that shines white and it looks just like a moment from Darkest Faerie, another of my favorite games
When it opens up to that forest area, I was so impressed with how big it felt and yet it was clear everything was made by hand and with purpose and there are soooo many little details to find, I didn't think we'd have that technology. It reminded me of a dream game I came up with in 9th grade which was also a single player adventure game where you are stuck on an island fighting bad guys with an emphasis on platforming, it was like my dream game came true
And the cutscene where you kill the deer is where I started really getting intrigued because I love heroic characters and I'm a bit of an animal lover so the fact that she feels sad about something as simple as killing a deer to survive is something very interesting to me
All my expectations were already subverted which was fun
I love the optional tombs, it reminds me of the dungeons from Skyrim, another one of my favorite games, except all the tombs are better than any dungeon
I love the weapons system, it's very similar to Republic Commando which is another one of my favorite games and the combat is just as intense
By the time I reached the radio tower, it was already my favorite game but that's only 25% through so it was an incredible length I feel, even if it's short compared to the average game
I like that Lara's character stays a guilt-ridden idealist, my favorite archetype. I thought the villain was good because he exploits this several times, luring her into traps and yet the fact that she still comes out on top at the end is cool because it shows that morality has a place in survival. Spider-Man also had some positive messages like that. so I really like the story
Not just for the themes but also for the novelty. Lara as an archeologist comes across an island that has collected all kinds of artifacts, documents, etc. from people all over the world that date back centuries, millennia even. It's the perfect playing ground
And there's this weird feeling I get with certain scenes in movies but I felt it in many places throughout this game where it's almost like deja vu but more powerful. I see certain things and I get this feeling that I had always known about it. In that sense, I kind of feel I have some spiritual connection with the game, too
And looking back on it, another reason I like the game so much is how emotionally diverse it is. It's like, every emotion is there and it kind of combines into some weird new feeling
I also like the ending where she says she's not going home, it reminds of me of TDK trilogy. It's like she embraces the fear and trauma to strengthen her passion for life and academics.
The whole game really inspires me to be a better person in every aspect of my life, I think it's made me a much much better person in general
I left out a few things such as how the movement inspires my own exercise. IRL I want to run as easy as it is for me to hold a joystick forward and jump as easy as it is to press a button. Also, at my most motivated I always want to travel and I can play out that fantasy a little by playing the game. Also also, there were little things here and there that I wasn't expecting and who doesn't love a good twist? Things like being able to grab ledges that I didn't think I'd be able to or seeing how she climbs along ropes for the first time. I had never seen anything like that before; it was actually a little educational.
and that's why I like the game

I made this review after having played through the game when it initially came out, and after playing it again in September 2023, having achieved a completion of over 95% both times on Hard difficulty.

The graphics are still pretty good. Even though the engine might be dated by today's standards, the performance is excellent at maximum settings and gets even better on modern PCs. More importantly, the art direction of the game results in very good looking characters and environments so it's pretty timeless.

Gameplay is... good in some ways. The basic progression mechanics for levelling your character and for improving weapons still hold up. The bow excels during moments of stealth, but I tend to use firearms once things get loud. The bow does get a late-game perk to allow for armor penetration to keep it relevant, though. The pistol's probably my most favorite weapon due to its accuracy for headshots, followed by the assault rifle, and finally the Shotgun, which I always felt lacked impact, even when fully upgraded.

However, the screen shake is kind of awful (you can get an aftermarket Yamatai patch to get rid of it), and what is really annoying is how the third-person camera auto-turns while you strafe. I also think that when you're not aiming, that having Lara in the center of the screen isn't exactly ideal, and while you can switch shoulders during aim mode, not having the side you were last using "remembered" is troublesome during tense fights in close quarters. Also, switching between first-and-third person views tends to nudge the camera around in ways that disrupts aiming. These problems are like little rocks in your shoes that disrupts an otherwise beautifully crafted experience and makes it hard to enjoy the gameplay experience they set out to present.

In the early game there are also a couple bugs, one requiring that you reload a checkpoint (a scripted sequence fails to trigger when trying to reach for the bow), and another involving having to shoot wolves that doesn't function well on an ultrawide display (so I had to switch to a 16:9 aspect ratio to get past that), and there are numerous quicktime sequences that I simply didn't enjoy because they used somewhat cryptic icons to distinguish between Melee and Use buttons. Also, if you need to turn on the spot, I suggest doing that while Aiming rather than trying to do that with walking. There were also a few instances where enemies would infinitely spawn until I either fled from an area (and they mysteriously stopped spawning) or I got overwhelmed and died, and upon respawning, the encounter was gone. Again, I must stress that these are just a few pain points that disrupt an otherwise pretty good experience.

Story-wise, it's passable, with a few clumsily-handled parts where a cutscene shows Lara having difficulty in situations that I would've otherwise had little trouble shooting my way out of. I get that the game is a bit like an interactive movie in these situations but I still found them jarring.

I suppose all in all, that I would give this a 8/10. It's fun, you can tell they really tried, but it's a little scuffed here and there which keeps it from being a really memorable masterpiece.

People praise this game as an Uncharted clone but the mechanics are handled so poorly that it doesn't come close. The climbing is floaty and disjointed, there's qte about every 10 minutes, and the combat is slow. Enemies will shoot you from off screen most of the time, and taking damage gives you a ridiculous knockback so every firefight is mired in frustration. You'll start to take aim but an enemy will shoot you from off screen which leads to a chain of damage as the enemy you were aiming at will follow up with a shot. 
The writing starts off hilariously bad and progresses into a soupy boring mess. 
The items you collect are somewhat interesting, but finding all the sets is tedious and quickly gets boring. 
Finally, none of the upgrades or perks have a significant impact on gameplay. It doesn't feel like you are leveling up with each one, just getting bloated with useless actions. 
You can tell it was made by a bunch of bros who didn't like Uncharted's exclusivity with Sony but also didn't want to put the time in to design a fun game.

[h1] In Brief: 6/10 [/h1]
First things first if this game had no bugs it would be a 8/10 immediate recommend. Unfortunately that's not the case, and I want to make it clear that you will encounter at least one bug if not many if you play this. I have left my initial reaction to this at the end of the review as it was very frustrating, particularly at the beginning. The story is amazing and whilst the game is very simple compared to it's sequels, if it worked how it was meant to it would be an amazing intro to the reboot series. However, this 10 year old game was patched as recently as 2022, yet it still contains many game breaking bugs including a cut off HUD, glitching and therefore impossible QTE's, and multiple areas where the only solution is to reload the checkpoint and hope you don't have to redo the section. Luckily there are many solutions to the many bugs in the forums, although you may have to try multiple solutions before finding one that works. Also you'll likely need to use the 2013 beta version to make it work. Also this game was designed to be played with a controller, and at times this really, really shows. It's possible to complete on keyboard (I did) but it is annoying that it doesn't work the way it should, especially when it comes to mouse movements and scrolling. 

Despite these incredibly frustrating bugs and flaws the story is annoyingly worth it, and I enjoyed the development of the characters. It is still a basic  concept, and I did have to wonder at Lara's stupidity for not understanding what the big bad was going to do until right at the last minute. It is incredibly gory, more so than Shadow (which I played first) and the optional tombs are really, really disappointing. They are so small that by the time you've got the hang of the mechanic it want's you to use you're done. Literally they're almost all one room in and out and done, not like the sequels. The multiplayers dead in the water, as is to be expected with an old game, but it's annoying that about 50% of the achievements are almost impossible now because they are part of the multiplayer.  

[b] Buy if: [/b]
- You like Shadow and/or Rise and want to know how it all started.
- It's in one of those mega bundles of every tomb raider game ever.
- You don't mind working around a lot of bugs to see the beginning of Lara's journey. 

[b] Don't buy if: [/b]
- You don't like bugs in games.
- You want to try out the revival. Try Shadow or Rise first, trust me. 
- You feel strongly about 100% achievements, as multiplayer pretty much prevents this. 

[h1] Additional Details [/h1]

---{Difficulty}---
I had to play on easy combat due to QTE bugs, but the puzzles were on the easy side of average without being to simple or challenging. The main problem I had was trying to figure out if my solution was wrong or if the game had bugged out. Again.

*Original review left at 6.5 hours* As a warning to those thinking of buying this game, it is buggy as hell, has really annoying QTE's (where the solutions are buy a controller or turn the graphics down to low or up to ultra?!), and honestly I'm glad it looks like it's going to be short. Yes this game was made in 2013, but the most recent patch was in Sept. 2022. Did this patch help? NO! 10 years later and they still haven't patched out game breaking bugs, despite many updates. I've had to revert to an old beta test version just to make the HUD visible and re-do areas when a game breaking bug stopped my progress. I've been stuck for hours on a QTE because the prompts lag. And I've only done the first few areas. Also the multiplayer (and attached achievements) are dead, but that's to be expected on a 10 year old game.

When you step into Lara Croft's shoes and realize you're in for an adventure hotter than a volcano...

🔥🌋 "Lara's on fire, and so is this game!"

📖 Story: Epicness Unearthed! 📜
The story's like a rollercoaster, and Lara's driving the hype train! From shipwrecks to ancient mysteries, it's a narrative that'll make you say, "Sign me up for the next ride!"

⚔️ Gameplay: Lara the Legend! ⛏️
Gameplay's smoother than Lara's acrobatics. You're an action hero in cargo pants, and the world's your playground!

🗺️ Exploring: Raiders of the Lost Amazement! 🏺
Exploring's like a treasure hunt on steroids. Every nook and cranny hides secrets, relics, and more goodies than a pirate's treasure chest.

🧗‍♀️ Platforming: Leapin' Lara! 🏞️
Platforming's like a high-stakes game of "The Floor is Lava." Lara's leaping, climbing, and swinging like a rockstar, and you're just trying to keep up!

🎶 Music: Epic Score, No Tomb Left Untouched! 🎵
The music's like a symphony of ancient mysteries and heart-pounding action. It's the kind of soundtrack that makes you feel like you're in an Indiana Jones movie.

🏛️ Level Design: Architectural Masterpieces! 🏰
The level design's like walking through history class with Lara Croft as your guide. It's so detailed, you'll feel like you're exploring real ancient ruins.

🧩 Puzzles: Brain Teasers Without the Baldness! 🧠
The puzzles are like a crossword on a Sunday morning—challenging, but not hair-pullingly frustrating. Lara's got you covered with hints, too!

🔥 Ultimate Hotness Alert: Lara Croft Edition! 🔥
Lara's not just hot, she's on fire! This lady's got more guts than a chili-eating contest and more smarts than a room full of rocket scientists.

🌟 Overall: Legendary Lara Awesomeness! 🌟
"Tomb Raider (2013)" isn't just a game; it's an adrenaline-pumping archaeological expedition! With a story that keeps you hooked, gameplay that makes you feel like a legend, and a Lara Croft that's hotter than a supernova, it's a treasure worth every adventure. 🔥💎🎮

🌟 Overall Rating: 9/10 🌟

A pretty young adventurer Lara Croft sets out on her first expedition aboard the ship Endurance, intending to find the lost kingdom of Yamatai. By her suggestion and against Whitman's advice, the expedition ventures into the Dragon's Triangle. The ship is struck by a violent storm and sinks, stranding the survivors on the isolated island. Lara is separated from the others, on a godforsaken island, full of dangerous animals, extreme weather and an armed fanatic cult of a group of scavengers living in a mountainside village… Now, you should save everyone, find the tomb and then escape from this perilous island, but at what cost! Solve riddles, get skills, grab your bow (or any other kind of weapons, there’s plenty of it) and explore the places of an inhabited island!

To be honest, the graphics are so well-done here and the game itself works fine even now, but sometimes the game can crash (well, it crashes in the multiplayer for the most of the time).

In addition, there is a multiplayer (currently dead), where you can play some matches with your friends or random people to get some achievements or just have some fun.

[u]Total: 9/10[/u]
good story

It's nothing like the OG Tomb Raider games, but if you're not looking for such experience, then that's fine.

The reboot is an excellent 3rd person adventure game. I had a ton of fun getting into every corner of the map which only gets unlocked over time as you get new gear. Sometimes, the levels were a bit too linear in my opinion, especially in the beginning, but most of the time it's fine.
You have the possibility to go stealth on enemies or go straight into Rambo mode. Depending on your gear, you can also use your environment to take enemies down or hiding yourself. The game encourages you to use your skill set.
I also like the character progression here. As you level up, you get skill points which you can spend them on buffs or new abilities.
The story is also entertaining enough to motivate you to finish the game.

Back in the days, the game was visually stunning. Nowadays, the magic a bit gone but still the graphics in this game are very good.

Compared to the OG Tomb Raider games, this one is very easy and relaxing, so the complete opposite. 

Performance-wise, I had solid 60 fps with an GTX 1060.
You can get this game for dirt cheap, I bought it for 2,99€ a few years ago.

I recommend it for anyone who is looking for a relaxing adventure exploration game with a solid story and visually appealing graphics.

Tomb Raider 2013, the tenth entry in the series, is easily one of the best reboots ever produced and also one of the finest titles to close out the seventh generation. It takes the franchise in a visceral new direction, planting a young inexperienced Lara into a vicious kill or be killed fight for survival. You'll tackle this desperate struggle by making your way across the island of Yamantai, slaughtering those who get in your way, running to safety in some explosive set pieces and taking on the occasional side quest in a tomb.

Almost all of it is immensely gratifying and cathartic with the game's heavy focus on combat and skill upgrades making the biggest impression. TR 2013 never lets up with its rip-roaring pace and a plot that really pulls you in to Lara's transformation from terrified archaeologist to hardened survivor. It does have issues here and there, most notably with the weak side characters and heavily simplified puzzles but the overall experience is rugged, intense and unrelentingly brutal. I can see why so the franchise earned so many new fans after this entry. As an former Uncharted fanboy, this game really pulled me in; I highly recommend it at any price. (Though multiplayer is completely dead at this point)

My extended retrospective on the entire Tomb Raider franchise can be viewed here: https://youtu.be/M2g51e1ZyhU?si=Wr8nADDL1G3HFFqI

A great cinematic action game that kicks off the Tomb Raider trilogy by Eidos-Montreal.
This (and the trilogy collection) go on sale for 80% off all the time. 

PROS:
-Core Tomb Raider gameplay (clean action run n gun)
-Looks good
-Great cinematic / cutscene sequences
-Great rigging (Eidos Montreal is usually solid at this)

-NEUTRALS:
-If you've played a lot of their games, you may recognize some animations (they reuse/reskin sometimes but its well done and you wouldn't know if you aren't familiar with their games)

CONS:
-Although the core gameplay loop is solid, it stays the same throughout the game.
-Multiplayer is dead
-No replay. Once you beat it, you move on to the next one. 
-Fairly short.

Tomb Raider Review

Review is after completing the main story missions, all side missions, finding all collectibles, clearing the entire map and achieving 100% completion on single player mode. As a side note: never cared for multiplayer.
[hr][/hr]


[b]Story[/b]
My previous introduction to Tomb Raider was Tomb Raider Anniversary and Tomb Raider Underworld. I wasn’t able to finish those games for reasons I don't remember now, but this game was hard to put down in comparison. The opening sequence was shocking and impactful. It gave a strong sense of mystery and fear of the unknown. Lara’s survival story is well crafted and very satisfying to play through.


[b]Gameplay[/b]
Game progression was smooth and well paced. The game made me excited to explore every nook and cranny of the game to get at all the collectibles. The level design enabled the natural exploration of each level. The mechanic to rotate and admire the collectibles was a highlight. Lara is given a variety of weapons but the bow and arrow are the best as it encourages that stealth archer gameplay that I like. Excellent platforming sections. Camera adjusts near perfectly depending on how you move Lara across the platforming sections. Seamless cutscenes and quick time events that blend flawlessly to the gameplay. The game has a fitting crafting and upgrade system along with hunting and scavenging. I got the definitive edition that had really cool outfits for Lara. None of them were skimpy clothes which made the game playable with family traffic. Dynamic cover system makes combat smooth. Lara’s fail animations are brutal, I was compelled to keep her alive because I didn’t want to see Lara suffer like that. Tomb exploration was fantastic and was something I looked forward to. Poor Lara gets ragdolled a lot in the game. 


[b]Graphics[/b]
Exquisite details in the main characters and the same can be said about the backgrounds.


[b]Controls[/b]
Played using the Xbox controller attached to the PC. Gameplay was smooth and responsive. 


[b]Side Missions[/b]
There are a few side missions in the game and I completed all of them for the sake of seeing everything the game had to offer.



[b]Music/Soundtrack/Voice[/b]
Excellent voice acting from the voice actress for Lara. The supporting characters were also well voiced. Soundtrack was just as good and together they created an excellent tone in the game world.


[b]Performance[/b]
Experienced no crashes and the game ran smoothly on my PC (which is a mid-range PC). It did not cause undue heating of the CPU and GPU.

I'm mixed. a 5/10. 

Combat was... fine.  It was on the easy side, but I didn't expect it to be CoD or anything.

Quick Time Events (QTE) are the bane of this game. There's mash E QTE and the game is not registering all the mashes if you are a fast masher, so you'll lose often. Heck, on the very last QTE, I failed like 20 times before I slowed down enough for it to register everything and I finaly won.  I would rather just NOT have QTE and watch the cutscenes play. It's either watch the scene and fail, or focus on button popups and fail to remember what went on in the cutscene.

Puzzles were either quick, or frustrating. But I suppose that actually on brand for Tomb Raider.

Story was decent, much more so than the rest of the game. In fact if felt like the game was a tag along to the story, like it was an after thought.

Skip the DLC, it's buggy. Or don't, but it's still a buck or two for a tomb, and in this game, those are one puzzle long and generally small.

Overall it's a 8 hour game with 12 to 20 hours of things to collect while playing. At this point I only recommend buying the game when it's on sale like I bought it. But if you hate finicky QTE  that you'll most likely get wrong simply because it doesn't register key presses right, then pass on this hard. It put me off enough that I just can't be bothered with buying the sequel games.

I never was a huge fan of the Tomb Raider series because I really did not like the character of Lara Croft. Neither how she was designed to be a sex symbol nor how she came of as arrogant. Regardless of gameplay, I never really connected with the series.
This here is a lot better. Lara of course is still a super attractive woman but at least in the rebooted series she has human traits which makes it much easier for the player to connect with her. From a gameplay standpoint Crystal Dynamics obviously played the Uncharted series and took some inspiration here and there, which is okay, since Uncharted followed in the footsteps of the original Tomb Raider genre. Controls are fluid and responsive (playing with a controller).
Talking of Nathan Drake: Characters, writing, humour and music are still superiour in Uncharted, but Tomb Raiders gameplay and bombastic presentation are pretty much on the same level as the top (naughty) dog. For a 2013 game the graphics are simply fantastic (hair physics are amazing for that time) , performance capturing and camerwork very dynamic and the main voice actress does a great job as Lara. Other voice talent is consistently fine but their characters lack depth and so they don't really have a chance to shine. Lara is seriously missing memorably characters like Sully, Elena or Chloe from Uncharted.
Yeah, I made it pretty clear, that I prefer the former Playstation exclusive competitor but Tomb Raider is also a very good game, that I can recommend without any issues.
A final thought: I find it refreshing, that the tombs to be raided are this time in a Japanese setting. Another Aztec/Mayan adventure would have been very boring. So good decision of the developers to mix things up a little.

Hey, gamers and adventure seekers from around the world! 🎮✨ Guess what? I used my gaming magic to jump to 2024 and play the famous Tomb Raider game from 2013. And oh boy, it's like finding treasure that never loses its shine!

I know what you might be thinking – "But it's 2024! Shouldn't the game feel old?" Nope, my friends. The controls are as smooth as butter on warm bread. I'm climbing cliffs, shooting arrows. It's like the game got a magic touch that keeps it awesome forever.

And the story? Oh my, it's still as captivating as ever. I'm hooked on Lara's journey like it's the best show on TV. The surprises in the story hit me like a fun surprise party, and the characters feel so real that I almost expect my cup of tea to start talking.

But that's not all! The atmosphere and exploration are just as exciting. I'm wandering through ancient ruins, solving puzzles that make my brain do flips, and sometimes accidentally falling off cliffs because I'm too busy admiring the scenery. Oops!

But you know what's even cooler in 2024? Sharing my epic fails and wins with the world. It's like a global gaming party where everyone's invited, and we're all here to have a great time together. So, if you thought Tomb Raider 2013 was old news, think again! It's like a favorite book that you can read over and over, and I'm giving a thumbs-up to this timeless gaming gem. 🎉🎮🏹

[b]PROS:[/b]
+ cool action story
+ good visuals
+ great atmosphere
+ level design
+ skill upgrades
+ weapon upgrades
+ lots of collectibles

[b]CONS:[/b]
- Steam cloud / server profile issues
- couple of crashes to desktop
- really hard to find someone to start a multiplayer game
- very few, simple and short tombs to raid
- maybe gory close-up deaths of Lara are not for everyone(?)

[b]Comment:[/b]
Finally a less clunky and more action oriented Tomb Raider game. While third person shooting is almost a cliche nowadays it really fits well here. So while many people who were fans of the previous games might get disappointed this new approach breathed life into the franchize. Yeah, the story gets a bit cheesy later on when you compare the fragile beginnings where everything can hurt Lara to the grandiose Rambo-like ending. But I still love it because at no point did I not have fun. While sometimes the game is QTE heavy I prefer it's linear approach. It gives focus on the fact that Lara is trying to survive, find her friends and escape the island. An open-world setting might have ruined that aspect. The tombs are okay but rather short and simple for a game called [u]Tomb[/u] Raider. Apart from tombs there are lots of collectibles which make your explore the scenery a bit more. These are not just for show as they help in your XP progress to level up your skills or to get salvage. The skill system helps give the feeling of Lara getting stronger as she progresses. There is also a weapon upgrade system where, if you collect enough salvage, you can improve them. That being said, the bow and arrow is the most satisfying for most of the game. You need four people to play a real multiplayer match. So nowadays it is really difficult to have one. Combined with DLC maps it is even tougher, so disable those if you wanna up your chances. Also expect to meet cheaters as there is no anti-cheat protection. The game has flaws, sure, but these all fade compared to the really fun and action-packed experience. Definitely worth checking out!

[b]P.S.:[/b] The GOTY Edition is not really needed as most of it is multiplayer stuff, six skins for singleplayer (Demoliton, Mountaineer, Sure-Shot, Hunter, Aviatrix, Guerilla) and the one extra tomb (Tomb of the Lost Adventurer) is still bugged.

[b]P.S.2:[/b] There is a [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/237450/Tomb_Raider_Japanese_Language_Pack/]Japanese Language Pack[/url] available but this DLC is negatively reviewed for a reason. It used to cost quite a lot of money for something that should be a normal part of the game. It was also unavailable in some regions. The language pack itself is nice, the voice over sounds good and complements the English version. Get it because now it's free and there is little reason not to. But to withhold a language pack behind a paywall was just plain dumb.
------------------------------------------------------------------
[b]If you liked this review you can find more on the [/b][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/28638055-Subjective-Reviews-Corner/][u]Curator page[/u][/url][b] or in my [/b][url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/srcorner][u]Review Corner[/u][/url][b].[/b]

An Iconic Adventure Reborn: Unleashing the Thrills of Tomb Raider

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Tomb Raider, the iconic franchise that has stood the test of time, returns with a gripping reimagining that revitalizes the essence of adventure and exploration. With its stunning visuals, immersive storytelling, and the transformation of a young Lara Croft into a legendary heroine, the game offers an exhilarating and unforgettable journey into the heart of adventure gaming.

The visual design of Tomb Raider is a visual masterpiece, immersing players in breathtaking landscapes that range from lush forests to treacherous tombs. The attention to detail in the environments, character models, and atmospheric effects creates an immersive and captivating experience.

At its core, Tomb Raider reintroduces players to a young and determined Lara Croft, taking her on a harrowing journey of survival on a mysterious island. The game's mechanics blend exploration, puzzle-solving, and intense action sequences to create a multifaceted gameplay experience.

The character development and emotional depth of the narrative are standout features, as players witness Lara's transformation from an inexperienced adventurer to a fearless heroine. The sense of empathy and connection with her struggles and growth adds a layer of engagement rarely seen in action-adventure games.

The gameplay seamlessly transitions between intense combat sequences, environmental puzzles, and exploration, creating a balanced and dynamic experience that keeps players engaged from start to finish.

The game's emphasis on exploration rewards players with hidden tombs, artifacts, and collectibles, encouraging them to delve deeper into the world and uncover its mysteries.

However, the game's more action-oriented approach might differ from the puzzle-heavy gameplay of the franchise's earlier iterations. Some players who loved the classic Tomb Raider puzzles might find this evolution a departure from the series' roots.

Certain moments in the game might be intense or violent, which could be unsettling for players sensitive to such content.

In conclusion, Tomb Raider is a triumphant revival of an iconic franchise, breathing new life into the adventures of Lara Croft. Its stunning visuals, immersive storytelling, and the evolution of a beloved character create an experience that's both nostalgic and fresh. While the shift towards a more action-driven gameplay might not resonate with purists of the original series, those who appreciate a blend of intense action, exploration, and character-driven storytelling will find themselves immersed in the heart-pounding world of Tomb Raider, where every step is a testament to the enduring legacy of adventure gaming.

By far one of the most thrilling and enjoyable adventure games you could buy on steam. I've never written a review for a game before but felt guilty not giving this game the props it deserves. The story isn't as deep as you'd hope it to be, but is still rewarding. The style of the game is one of a kind and an amazing entry into the trilogy, which seems to be the main emphasis of the game. The world(island?)-building is astounding and there are fascinating lore entries scattered throughout the game for you to find. The main cast are unfortunately very surface level, but do offer some fun dialogue and interactions throughout the course of the game.

One major and frustrating downfall is the online achievements. I actually would love to make this my first 100% game, but the online achievements do make this absurdly difficult/impossible to do.

This game is pretty amazing. Really fun and intuitive quick gameplay, as well as amazing cinematic production. it is really well optimized, it can even run on older machines with moderate graphics options, talking about graphics, the game looks amazing, especially on Ultra. The story is fantastic and really interesting as you explore the mysterious island you are deserted on. I was never bored playing this game and it was worth the purchase for sure.

Gameplay was very intuitive by being simple yet rich, and keeps on getting freshened up as you play all the way until the very end. Not only that but it wasn't overly complex nor very simple, but the perfect balance for quick and really fun rewarding gameplay.

This game was a cinematic experience. Some of the vital parts of the story were purely baffling with outstanding cinematography. and the rest of the game kept on giving stunning views and vistas all throughout.

This is a very well optimized game and it will probably run well even on old integrated graphics, but of course its best when its on ultra, and even on that it ran smooth as butter.
I did experience a couple of bugs during gameplay, but nothing gamebreaking or annoying.

The pure graphics were really great for the time this game was released in, maybe some of the best graphics at its time. The graphics did age fairly well, you can see the slight roughness compared to newer games, but mixed with the stunning cinematography, and the good lighting this game offered, it all bundled into an amazing viewing experience.

The story is pretty cool, fairly unique but with some cliches, but it was interesting with fairly good characters throughout. It is nothing groundbreaking, but also it is not a forgettable story. It was very interesting to unravel the mystery of the island you're on, while being mixed up in many other problems and conflicts.

Playing this game, especially if for the first time, you will not feel an inkling of boredom at any point. I urge you to explore every one of the semi-open locations you visit in-game as thoroughly as you can, and to loot as much as possible, it isn't boring this way, quite the opposite, because doing this will basically unlock much more quicker gameplay advancement, and you'l still have stuff to unlock by the end, so you wont even run out of things to advance in.

I heavily recommend buying this game if you have not played it already! it will be very well worth the purchase!

[h1] An open-world Uncharted™ adventure [/h1]
[i] "If you love Uncharted or Open-world games, this game is a must have." [/i]
[hr][/hr]

While playing the game in whopping [i][b] 800 x 600 Resolution with very low Graphics [/b][/i], I won't complain much, but with my epic [i][b] Intel Pentium with Intel HD Graphics [/b][/i] or I could just say potato PC, this one runs well and still looks graphically awesome, like I'm playing in console.

It's a wonderful, astonishing, adrenaline rush of an action and stealth shooter. The cinematography is wonderful, the characters, enemies, and so on. Everything is what I can say a great game. An open-world experience, in 14 hours of my time, I manage to complete my first play-through with an overall 100% game completion (well, the weapons don't count on completion which is a good thing, trust me).

It's not a linear progression with just action, it's an open-world exploration action game. You're free to do anything as you wish, but for me, getting that 100% overall completion is enough. But if you're that dedicated, feel free to get achievements too.

Story wise, it's tense, mysterious, and astonishing. Attention up to the small details, reading documents are great to read since they can give more context to the characters, location, and story. 

Overall, a great game. But one important advice, Don't buy those Singleplayer DLCs especially those involving skills or weapon mods, those DLCs are just [b] official cheats [/b] makes you get things earlier, you can get all skills or even get everything needed and complete all without these mods. The extra Tomb DLC is up to you, I haven't tried it either, I only have the vanilla.

Tomb Raider is a solid game, if not for a couple missteps by the developers.  What mistakes?

First and foremost is the severe case of shaky camera syndrome it has.  Imagine watching a Jason Bourne film while in a Soviet-era Lada going 60+ km/h over moguls, and you'll get the idea.  It is so bad that it literally gives me motion sickness while trying to play it, so I had to limit myself to short stints just to get through it without throwing up.  I can't name another game that has done that to me, though other games let you turn it off.  Not so in TR.

Yes, you can hold down right-click (aim) to prevent the shaky cam, but this kills your movement speed.  It also won't work for anything more complicated than walking around, and as you can imagine, there's a lot of running/jumping/climbing/etc. in this game.

My second, and only other major gripe, is the presence of QTEs.  It's not just one or two of them, either, as they're thrown in your face at basically any opportunity the game can.  If this were the only major problem, I might recommend it, but combined with aforementioned camera issues, there's just no way.

It's a shame, really.  The rest of the game is pretty good, but the omnipresent camera shake is a constant reminder of how one little detail can totally ruin the entire experience.  It's prevented me from buying the other two games in the series as well.

This was my first 3d game aside from minecraft, so take this with a grain of salt. Also my computer exceeds the minimum requirements for Mac. 
I came across a bunch of glitches throughout the game, with the best being minor problems such as an NPC being stuck dangling from a ledge in trying to jump off, and the worst being the camera that follows the player completely spinning out, only fixable via restarting everything. That last one made the game unplayable whenever it occurred, which was several times in my play-through. I get the game was made in 2013, but I tend to expect an 'overwhelmingly positive' game to be pretty bulletproof.
In terms of gameplay, the starting tutorial was pretty poor, with long cutscenes and minor gameplay consisting of "mash f", "mash left and right", and "hold e". Not very fun. Afterwards, it got better, though having to crank things by mashing one button still was a bit odd to me, not sure if it's the norm in 3d games. I also didn't really enjoy the wall climbing with the pick, even after getting the hang of it (pun intended). Just personal preference, not really anything significant, just something to add to the pile. 

I also expected more adventure in the game, like with a bit more choice in where to go. It was mostly just a first-person-shooter, with the secret tombs being part adventure, part puzzle. Maybe this one is down to inexperience too, but thought I should add that in.

having grown up immersing myself in the world of tomb raider video games, spanning the timeline from tomb raider legend to the shadow of the tomb raider. a void exists with my time with the tomb raider video games, a lacuna unfilled by the 2013 tomb raider instalment. amidst the latest trilogy, it stands as the sole game which is often overlooked by me due to the adoption of a darker and grittier tone that initially failed to resonate with my interests from a tomb raider game. my opinions have appeared to be misguided.

the 2013 entry within the tomb raider lineage heralded the advent of phenomenal trilogy that would unfold in its wake. this installment steers it’s narrative compass towards uncharted territories. this time around, the persona of lara croft is of a youthful and decidedly novice in contrast to the fearless and independent portrayal that is usually seen. you experience lara’s mixed emotions and the tension built through out the game as you progress further. the game also follows a much darker and gory tone in certain areas suffusing the surroundings with a unconventional colour palette bouncing around the shades of gray.

imbued within this video game lies a narrative tapestry of remarkable texture punctuated by satisfying combat with seamless gameplay mechanics. if this game’s languishing within your library, perhaps freely claimed or picked up at sale for dirt cheap. I definitely do recommend giving it a chance.

There are games I love that I wouldn't recommend, and games I hate that I would - because my taste is my own, and sometimes deviates from what I know is popular. 

In 2013, a LOT of what was popular is just not my taste, and thankfully a lot of it is going away in games - for example, Quick Time Events. 

So with that, I would recommend this game to someone who really likes the style of bullet sponge wonky combat, QTEs, illogical climbing and grabbing and jumping, and overall kinda poor gameplay. 

If you like it, or at least, can tolerate it, the rest of the game, of which there is a bit, is rewarding. The island is fun to explore, when everything isn't exploding, and I do mean everything - "watch out for that exploding sand, look out, an exploding mountain that isn't a volcano,  for some reason." 

My issue with the game is that what it offers, that I do enjoy, it offers very little of. Exploration, gathering, crafting, survival - all well executed but barely implemented. 

The things I don't like, terrible combat, and I can't emphasize that enough, and poor gameplay with overloaded QTEs, well, that's about 60-70% of the game itself. 

So with that, I got the game for $3, and would say it was easily worth it, because the high points were really high, albeit not many. But enough to get me through the game. 

I've heard the sequel is better, and I can see how a great sequel could come out of this, if they expand on the exploration, gathering, crafting, etc... and fix the ridiculously, comically terrible combat. 

Question to the devs, how did 47,000,000 soldiers all end up on one small island, and even more mind-boggling, how did they all end up with the same voice? No joke, every enemy you fight has the same "batman thug" voice, and they maybe say 3 things "where is she?" "there she is" "get her!". So get ready for hours of hearing one man's voice say that 47,000,000 times, as you shoot them 5 times in the face with a shotgun, only for them to stumble a little then kill you with an arrow. 

So, get it on sale - deep sale.

Beautiful Game!

Graphics:
This wows with stunning visuals, especially considering the release year. The game's environments, ranging from lush forests to intricate tombs, were meticulously designed and featured impressive attention to detail. Character models, especially Lara, were remarkably lifelike, showcasing expressions and emotions that enhanced immersion. The lighting and particle effects added to the realism, making exploration of the island a captivating experience.

Gameplay:
The gameplay marks a significant departure from the series' previous entries. It blends exploration, combat, and puzzle-solving seamlessly, reflecting Lara's transformation from an inexperienced survivor to a resourceful adventurer. The addition of RPG elements, such as skill upgrades and crafting, allows to tailoring the experience to different playstyles. The island setting provided an open-world feel, encouraging exploration and discovery beyond the main story.  Unfortunately the game's reliance on quick-time events (QTEs) during key moments occasionally disrupted immersion. 

Story:
The narrative focused on a young Lara Croft stranded on a mysterious island after a shipwreck. The story's progression was engaging, chronicling Lara's evolution from a vulnerable survivor to a capable heroine. The emotional depth and character development made Lara a relatable protagonist. The island's secrets, steeped in history and mythology, intertwined well with the overarching plot, creating a sense of intrigue and urgency.  However the occasional dissonance between Lara's character development and her body count, as she transitioned from a survivor to a combat-savvy adventurer is jarring. 

Sound:
The audio design played a crucial role in the game's immersive atmosphere. The ambient sounds of the island, along with the orchestral score, heightened tension during intense moments and underscored emotional scenes. Voice acting, particularly Camilla Luddington's portrayal of Lara, was top-notch, delivering authenticity and relatability to the characters.

Presentation:
Tomb Raider's presentation excelled at immersing players in its world. The UI was intuitive, providing easy access to inventory management and objectives without feeling intrusive. Cutscenes seamlessly transitioned into gameplay, maintaining the flow of the story. The game's pacing struck a balance between action-packed sequences and quiet moments of introspection.

Rating
The 2013 Tomb Raider game successfully reinvigorated the franchise with its captivating graphics, dynamic gameplay, engaging story, immersive sound design, and polished presentation. Despite some minor flaws, it managed to revitalize the iconic character of Lara Croft while delivering a satisfying modern gaming experience. This reboot set the stage for Lara's continued adventures and demonstrated the potential for growth within the franchise.  I would rate this 9/10.  Great

[h1] The (re)birth of Lara Croft [/h1]

[b] Overall [/b] : 9/10

Tomb raider is a very good reboot of the Lara Croft saga, by focusing on the birth of the adventuress and how she became the world famous tomb raider.

A definitive must-have for any fan of adventure game, with a rich story and strong characters! 

[b] Gameplay : 9/10 [/b]

The game has a rich mix between exploration, puzzles solving and combat phases. Very nice animations overall, and the gunplay is very satisfying for such a genre. Kudos to the devs!

[b] Graphics: 8/10 [/b]

I discovered the game only now (2021) but considering that it's actually from 2013, I must say I am impressed. The engine performs very well, and deliver some very nice environments and effects. Lighting, FX, textures are all excellent for me. And it scales quite well to 4K.

[b] Story : 9/10 [/b]

I actually appreciated the fact that the reboot tried to move away from the bimbo akimbo style, and actually tries to shape the story of how Lara became who she is. You will actually see her grow through the events and challenges, and the overall story is very well delivered with little to no down-time. Bravo!

[b] Achievement hunting : 4/10 [/b]

For the hunters out there, this one will be troublesome due to the online ones. Very hard to get people online unless you get a group of hunters. And 2 will require hours of grinding. The solo part is well designed and integrated within the campaign progression.

A Beautiful Adventure with Lara Croft

Since I started using Steam, I've always enjoyed creating my own reviews for games that I truly liked. I must admit, I'm not the best at providing detailed reviews, and when it comes to Tomb Raider, I find it a bit challenging to put my thoughts into words. However, I feel compelled to share my thoughts on this amazing game.

As someone who never had the opportunity to experience the old Tomb Raider series in its prime, I wanted to start with the second-generation games but never got around to it. From what I know, the old Tomb Raider games focused heavily on puzzles while also delivering a captivating story. I have a fondness for puzzles, so I was expecting to encounter some challenging ones in the game. However, it was quite the opposite. While there are optional tombs to discover by exploring the map, the puzzles in Tomb Raider are not as intricate as one might expect from a Tomb Raider game. This aspect was a little disappointing, although it's certainly not something that detracts from the overall enjoyment of the game.

Despite being released in 2013, Tomb Raider still boasts impressive graphics, stunning visuals, and a detailed atmosphere. Everything about the game is visually gorgeous.

The story kicks off with the beautiful archaeologist, Lara Croft, aboard a ship called Endurance, belonging to Roth, an old friend of the Croft family. They embark on an adventure to find the mythical Kingdom of Yamatai in a place known as the Dragon's Triangle. Despite warnings from the chief archaeologist, Lara convinces the crew to take the risk. As most of you may know, an adventure with Lara Croft can never begin like that of a normal human being.

There are a few gameplay aspects I wish were more prominent, such as a survival mechanic. While there are animals to hunt, it serves little purpose beyond needing to eat something at the beginning of the game. The hunger mechanic is virtually non-existent. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, as it would have been pointless to introduce a mechanic without fully utilizing it. That being said, the gameplay itself is satisfying. You can choose to be stealthy and complete objectives without being detected, or you can dive headfirst into the action.

I've never been a fan of searching an entire area to find collectibles without any hints. In Tomb Raider, you can find treasure maps that reveal the locations of treasures you need to collect. This is a great option for players who don't want to painstakingly search every nook and cranny. Even if you're not a fan of collecting, I would still recommend collecting journals if you want to learn more about side characters and their stories.

[h1]★★✰✰✰[/h1]

Tomb Raider 2013 is your typical "cinematic" AAA experience - linear gameplay, B-movie-level writing, many many explosions, and... a surprising lack of tomb raiding.

Most of the "ancient dangers" are wooden structures so old that they fall apart the moment Lara touches them, and "tombs" are reduced to little side rooms with a physics puzzle inside. Your enemies will be your fellow humans for a whopping [spoiler]95[/spoiler]% of the game (not counting wolves, who appear about [spoiler]4[/spoiler] times total).

The story focuses more on Lara herself... in a 'torture porn' kind of way. Lara is put through a lot of abuse to show us how much she "grows" as a result, but the facepalm-worthy writing makes this hard to take seriously.

As a whole, the game is just competent enough to be entertaining but does not excel or innovate in any way. If you buy it on sale - you're basically paying the price of a burger for a burger-level enjoyment.

- LINUX USERS BEWARE. The 'native' build of the game has atrocious performance problems. You will have much better time playing the Windows build running via Proton. 

- Make sure you're playing the right version from the start, because save-games are [i]not compatible[/i] between Windows and Linux/Mac builds.

- There is a bug where some UI elements are displayed off-screen. To fix this, right-click on the game in your Steam library, go to Properties -> Betas, and select "build743.0 - TR Build 1.01.743.0".

A great story, an exciting adventure that does not let go for a moment.... I would have said, if in my time I had not played the inspiration for this game - Uncharted..... and didn't have a game with its own problems. What were Lara's adventures about before? About mysteries of ancient civilizations, about mystical places and their no less colorful inhabitants, about conspiracies to gain power over ancient artifacts. What do we have now? A lonely gray (literally) Japanese island, without a couple of characteristic temples on it, I would never say that we are in Japan, a cult of an ancient sorceress, an army of terracotta undead samurai (that climb under bullets like kamikazes), a bow, a pistol, an automatic rifle and Lara covered in mud in the middle of all this ugliness. The open world turned out to be as boring as possible, not predisposing to exploration. All action scenes are dynamic, but they are far from new, especially remembering the same Uncharted. The plot is weak and full of randomness. The characters are rather flat, because of which even the moment when they try to beat a pitiful tear out of us, it turns out badly. Alas. A weak and boring reboot. Only 5 Lar in evening dress out of 10.A great story, an exciting adventure that does not let go for a moment.... Introduction:
Tomb Raider is an exceptional action-adventure game that captivates players with its enthralling storyline, stunning visuals, and immersive environments. Developed by Crystal Dynamics and published by Square Enix, this game revitalizes the beloved Tomb Raider franchise, providing an unforgettable gaming experience that will leave players yearning for more.

Engaging Storyline:
One of the most remarkable aspects of this game its gripping storyline. As players step into the shoes of a young and inexperienced Lara Croft, they are thrust into a thrilling narrative. Stranded on a mysterious and perilous island, Lara faces not only the harsh elements but also a menacing cult. Witness Lara's transformation from vulnerability to unwavering determination, as she uncovers ancient secrets and fights for survival. The game's twists, turns, and unexpected revelations ensure that every moment is a thrilling adventure.

Stunning Visuals and Immersive Environments:
Tomb Raider boasts breathtaking visuals that transport players into a visually stunning world. From lush jungles to crumbling ruins, each environment is meticulously designed, creating a sense of realism and awe. The attention to detail is impeccable, with stunning lighting effects, realistic character models, and intricately crafted landscapes. As players navigate through treacherous terrain and ancient tombs, they are fully immersed in this rich and immersive world.

Intense Gameplay and Exploration:
The gameplay is a perfect blend of action, exploration, and puzzle-solving. Players will engage in thrilling combat sequences, utilizing Lara's growing arsenal of weapons and her agility to outsmart enemies. Additionally, the game encourages exploration, with hidden tombs and collectibles scattered throughout the island. Solving intricate puzzles and deciphering cryptic messages rewards players with valuable treasures and insights into the island's mysteries.

Conclusion:
Tomb Raider is a true masterpiece that revitalizes the iconic franchise. With its gripping storyline, stunning visuals, and immersive environments, the game offers an unforgettable adventure from start to finish. Whether you're a fan of the series or new to the world of Tomb Raider, this game is an absolute must-play. Brace yourself for an epic journey filled with danger, discovery, and the indomitable spirit of Lara Croft. 10/10

A great full-length game that blends combat, climbing, and interactive cinematic action sequences into an experience that will have you hooked. The first couple hours felt very limited in regards to your character's abilities, but god damn does it ever ramp up with constant unlocks and progressively more difficult challenges. The puzzles aren't too difficult, but made me stop and think through my decisions a few times. The voice acting and character interactions left something to be desired.

[h1] [b] Bottom line: It's my favorite game [/b] [/h1]

I greatly enjoyed TR. It's got a driving story and lots of extras if you enjoy achievements or side challenges. I finished the story around 20 hours, but it could be finished sooner in a speed run. I like to explore and upgrade as I go.

I enjoyed the challenges and achievements, but some of them seemed glitched, so that was annoying. Once I looked up some community help, I was able to complete them.

This game is very combat-oriented and less focused on the actual "tomb raider"/puzzle aspect of Lara's story and character, with her even saying "I hate tombs". Ironic. Keep in mind that this is supposed to be her origin story, so it focuses more on her drive to survive. She still takes interest in the artifacts and the decoration of the tombs, so that's nice that her archaeology degree isn't negligible. However, I saw someone's review that it's less "Tomb Raider" style than the older games and far more geared towards combat. I'd agree that this game doesn't quite fit the franchise perfectly.

I would have liked to see more puzzles, but I got my fun out of the game :)

The biggest issue I had was motion sickness. It was horrible until I adjusted some graphic settings. There was no specific "motion sickness" setting though, so I had to play around and look for community solutions to the common problem.

[h1][b]Positives: [/b][/h1][list]
[*]Strong Story
[*]Lots of Achievements
[*]Fun Combat
[*]Easy to Learn
[/list]

[h1][b]Negatives: [/b][/h1][list]
[*]Tombs are a fraction of the gameplay
[*]Horrible Motion Sickness
[*]Lacks Puzzles like the older games
[*]Some glitchy achievements
[/list]

[h1][b][i] How does it compare to the Survivor/Coming-of-Age Trilogy? [/i][/b][/h1][list]
[*] Most enjoyable
[*] Weakest tombs
[*] Tied for Story with Shadow of the Tomb Raider
[*] Great for busting heads
[/list]

Tomb Raider 2013 starts out pretty strong and then hits a great stride until about 1/3rd of the game. After that things really nosedive. Some stellar parts, but overall hard to get through and unsatisfying.

The good parts - this game is gorgeous. The environments are stunning and the animations are world class. The way that the camera weaves through the action for the quicktime/platforming is amazing. The stealth sections are really good. The controls are generally great. The combat feels pretty good and has some surprising nuance with cover and counter mechanics.

The bad parts - my god this story is dog. It is patchy, jumps around, characters are terrible and basically teleport in and out for no reason. The combat is overdone and tedious. There are too few enemy types. While the guns feel good, combat isn't interesting enough to carry the game. The level design is very inconsistent and ranges from excellent to total garbage - leaning bad. Platforming is fun in places, but the same tropes are thrown at you time and time again. Puzzles are slow and boring. Lara is a literal ragdoll who is pure scar tissue by the end. She wins the award for most falls in a single game, good lord.

Rebooting a franchise that was 17 years old is no easy feat. You have to please old fans while also bringing in a new audience, a quite daunting task, but one that Crystal Dynamics have pulled off. As a new player to the franchise, Tomb Raider has gotten me quite interested in the history and future of Lara Croft, and I hope this game will have the same affect on you,

But why? 

For me Tomb Raider gave me the right amount of action and exploration as well as a mechanic I wish more games would include, optional puzzles. Combat provides a nice and well paced break from the endless amount of exploring this game has to offer, trying to hunt for a difficult to find collectable only to have my mind refreshed with a brief but enjoyable combat encounter gave me the will to power through and find that one collectable.

Story wise, I have no real complaints, it's well paced, well told and quite interesting, especially to someone like me; I thought that Tomb Raider was going to be very grounded, but to my surprise the included many fantasy elements, most of which I enjoyed.

Overall, this game is 100% worth it on sale for anyone, and if you like action-adventures, I would also say it's worth the full 20$.

Listen... I'm an Uncharted kid, I never played the og Tomb Raiders nor did I ever sought them out purely because I thought Uncharted had better graphics at the time... I was a dumb kid. Anyway, I still am not gonna play the og Tomb Raider games as it just does not look appealing to me in the slightest, so I decided to get this 2013 remake/ reboot and I gotta say it is a solid re-imagining of the series and as an Uncharted fan, this all felt pretty familiar. All the gameplay beats were pretty second nature to me excluding the rpg elements like the upgrading of weapons.

Story-wise it's pretty decent but doesn't really stick with you for long although it's still does a pretty good job making the player curious as to what the heck is happening on the island. Characters are... well, let's just say objectively with absolutely no bias... Uncharted had better characters and everyone except Lara kinda sucks. I don't even remember most of their names are save for Roth and Reyes which really dampens the experience because most of Lara's crew does not make it to the end and I really wanted to care... but I just don't.

As for gameplay, yeah if you played Uncharted you'll feel right at home! Not a lot to say here

In conclusion, it's not a perfect game but a perfect way to revive the franchise. I enjoyed my time with it and am giving this game a 7/10

P.S the multicolored subtitles are ugly and the shaky camera makes me nauseous
