It's a 2013 game, so you're getting 2013 jank. The platforming is broken half the time, animations can be a bit stiff, and the story is pretty simple.

The camera sway is so bad, I had to stop playing several times. There is no way to disable it. I am sorry.

Lara suffers from terminal "I forgot I have a gun" syndrome, where 90% of her in-game problems would be solved if she would just use one of her several guns to kill her enemies instead of using her bow.

The story DOES involve the supernatural, so just keep that in mind.

The game is intended for 60 fps. Anything above that and you will break QTE's, and there are a lot of them, including the final boss.
First negative review ever.

All in all, I really liked it. I really like exploring what developers create so this is great for me. I had never played any of the old tomb raider games but I understood the gist. It handles really well, and the game can go as fast or slow as you like. There are diverse environments, and it changes as you travel between camps depending on the part of the story. There is immense lore here, some even hinting at a secret entity to be elaborated in the next title... This game was really fun and I will definitely be coming back to get some of the weirder achievements.

Mac users: this game does okay with performance. I have an M1 Pro 14" and it could handle the higher -- not highest -- graphics well. Definitely keep your Mac charging though, pretty much any game will devour the battery. It works with controllers (Xbox One Elite). The only gripe I do have is online. I bought this in a big pack with the other Tomb Raider titles and all their DLC, including online DLC, however there was no online option in the menu for me. I contacted support and they said they did not bring online over when they ported to Mac. Just FYI if buying in a bundle or like to just grab all DLC while you're at it.

My review is not based on the game itself, rather the port of it. I have played through and beaten this game on my PS4 a couple years ago. I wanted to play through it again on Steam, but it is literally unplayable. There are glitches all the time where you need to restart from a checkpoint just to get things to load properly. The key-binds are awful and you cannot use a controller. And yes I would love to change the key-binds but it does not help. The interactive cutscene's are what truly made it unplayable though. Because of how poorly it was ported over, it does not recognize input for shit. Literally the first wolf interaction I barely got through, and the second one in the cave was literally impossible to get passed. Like no matter how hard I spammed the F key it would insta fail me and I would die. I beg anyone, if you want to play this game; enjoy it on console. DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY ON THIS PORT. Even if it is only a few dollars at the time, it is a waste. I hope this will save someone money in the future.

First time playing any Tomb Raider game ever and really enjoyed it. The puzzles, traversing/platforming and combat is fun but became a bit repetitive at times (maybe because puzzle/platforming games aren't my go to). For a game made in 2013 the graphics/visuals of the world hold up very well. The sound design/effects are nicely done and the overall story itself was enjoyable, but I personally wasn't enthralled during my playthrough and likely wouldn't play it again. The combat and upgrading your 4 main weapons was good fun, but was refreshing was the gore. I feel more and more games are distancing themselves from it, but Tomb Raider embraces it, especially with the melee kills, cinematics and especially Lara's own death cut scenes which can be pretty brutal at times. I couldn't find a Multiplayer game, so reviewing that is out of the question. Bug wise I faced a few issues with the aspect ratio being slightly zoomed in as well as random crashes which were annoying at times. The collectibles in this game were actually decent but still felt like a chore to complete all of them including the challenges. Overall this game was a great pickup for the few bucks I paid for it, and I recommend it to anyone who has or hasn't played Tomb Raider games - 7.5/10

Tomb Raider explores the intense and gritty origin story of Lara Croft and her ascent from a young woman to a hardened survivor. Armed only with raw instincts and the ability to push beyond the limits of human endurance, Lara must fight to unravel the dark history of a forgotten island to escape its relentless hold.

Wow, what can I say about this game. I have played this game since I was in middle school and I love every single playthrough that I have repeated multiple times. Every aspect of this game such its gameplay, music, combat, exploration, and story are perfect. Lara Croft in my opinion is the best female protagonist in the video game industry. Her origin story in this story are a perfect telling of how did she became the bad-ass Lara that we've all known in the past game. This game retells her origin story beautifully. Overall, if you want to play a game with a excellent story that could spark your adventurous soul then this game is for you. For few rupiah this game is must have for that price alone.

Earlier this year, the first game in the Tomb Raider Reboot trilogy had it's 10th anniversary (happy late birthday Tomb Raider 2013!), and incidentally it was the year I randomly decided to give it a go!
 
I will say that I haven't played the original games, so I won't weigh in on how it compares to the originals, but in my honest opinion? This game bloody rules! The graphics are decent, considering it's age, and bizarrely managed to chug my frames from time to time (my rig isn't very up to date in all fairness, and I was running on maxed settings) but oh lord this game shines on game-play. 
 
I loved the story, with the Lost City of Yamatai being the main focus of the story (somewhat like Japan's version of Atlantis) with a few vicious antagonists and some absolutely killer gameplay! It was high octane, massively entertaining and downright frightening at times. My one complaint is the gunplay can be very repetitive however, that's to be expected with only 4 weapons regardless of upgradability. The game fully utilised many environments to spice up the gameplay in new and interesting ways, and it really went apeshit at the end, it was incredible!
 
The story was just the right amount of mystery to have the player figure it out before our protagonist as a nice lil' ego boost, but it doesn't make you wanna play any less after figuring out where it's going. Most of the characters had decent motivations, but some bugged me. Reyes is openly untrusting and sceptical of Lara's capabilities for a good portion of the game, and following an event which could of lead to some deserved feeling character development, tense dialogue, and allowing some depth to be added character who's been as shallow as the rest of the side cast. Like seriously, Jonah makes a joke about his hunger because he has a bit of a belly, Reyes has a daughter and Alex likes Lara. That's the extent of them. Well there's Kroft, but even he is sorta flawed explanation on why Lara is such a Mary Sue. At the end of the day though, you don't go to an action game like this for deep characters, you go there for dumb fun action, and boy does it deliver on that!
 
It's certainly not the most innovative game, but that really doesn't matter. It's a great experience and anyone should give it a shot.

Bought TR because it's on sale and it's one of the few promising games available on MacOS. I was pleasantly surprised that I was able to finish the game with 75% completion in just under 10 hours on my MacBook Pro M2. There was some snags where the video/graphics got stuck/inverted and I just had to close steam and restart the game and it's ok again. This is DEFINITELY WORTH THE PRICE AND BUY.

Compare this with my love hate relationship with the highly lauded God of War OG on steam for my Predator Helios 300 laptop which was definitely more expensive and older than TR. I was expecting GoW to work well because I'm using a "gaming laptop" but lo and behold I got stuck in that scene where Kratos was pushing the medallion in a column of light. Ugh! Tomb Raider and God of War have similar controls and movements so I was expecting a lot more from GoW but it's just crashes endlessly and I got tired of playing it I uninstalled.

In conclusion, PURCHASE TOMB RAIDER NOT GOD OF WAR if you want a better game play with less bugs and the same adrenaline inducing scenes.

[h1]Tomb Raider, the game that turns archaeology into a full-blown action movie on steroids[/h1] 
Lara Croft is like, "Who needs delicate excavation tools when you can have dual pistols and a sassy attitude?"

She's a master at defying physics—swinging from ropes, surviving insane jumps, and landing without a scratch. I half expect her to whip out a cape and start flying around ancient ruins, all while maintaining perfectly styled hair.

But let's not forget her approach to historical preservation: "Blow up the tomb, grab the loot, and leave destruction in your fabulous wake!" It's like she's on a personal mission to rewrite history, one explosion at a time.

And can we talk about her wardrobe? Lara must have a closet full of tank tops and shorts, because who needs practicality when you can raid tombs looking like a runway model? Forget about protective gear; her fashion choices scream, "I'm here to slay, both archaeologically and in style!"

In the end, Tomb Raider is the ultimate guilty pleasure. It's a game that throws realism out the window, embraces over-the-top action, and gives us a heroine who defies all odds, including the laws of nature. So buckle up, grab your virtual weapons, and get ready for a wild ride that will make you question everything you thought you knew about archaeology and just how many times one person can cheat death. It's Tomb Raider, baby—where history meets explosions, and Lara Croft proves that you can conquer the world with sass, guns, and a sense of fashion that would make Coco Chanel proud!
She moans and whines more than you think. Personally not my thing but make your downstairs neighbour jealous when you have the chance, for €3 only.

As the industry of video games has matured, its iconic protagonists have aged too. Advancing technology has evolved videogame storytelling from the jolly and fantastical escapades of Spyro and Croc, to the gripping and realistic storylines to Joel (TLOU) and Marcus Fenix (GoW). This leaves cross-generational protagonists to often fall by the wayside, forced to evolve (often unsuccessfully) or fade into obscurity. 

As we enter Tomb Raider (2013), and the changing perceptions of what video game characters can be, it’s worth considering pop culture as a whole too. The ‘grim-dark’ and vulnerable era of DC comics was in full effect, fresh of the influence of The Dark Knight. We had not just the sequel The Dark Knight Rises, but also in the same year of Tomb Raider the pessimistic Man of Steel.

The reinvention of Lara Croft necessitated a similar approach to meet changing mainstream tastes. Ignoring all marketing materials, the Tomb Raider name perhaps spurs on ideas of slow methodical climbing among magically infused ruins. However, Tomb Raider (2013) is all about the consequences and pain of survival. Lara, while initially hesitant at killing, is quickly and violently culling armies of mercenaries in some of the most ruthless ways possible. Pickaxes to the face, shotgun blasts at point range, and even dousing enemies in petrol and setting them on fire. 

While the transition is a bit sudden, this reinvention thrives on just how bloody fun it is. The gunplay is fast, fluid and punctuated by highly destructible environments. Lara also throws her weaponry about with genuine weight, and most enemies die from a single headshot even on hard. It’s gory and brutal, but also requires precision and patience – especially when using the incredibly fun bow and arrow.

Platforming is tight, rhythmic and intuitive and becomes increasingly thrilling as your equipment gets upgraded. There are jaw-dropping set pieces as Lara climbs up ropes some 200m in the air to traverse nearby towers, but my favorite moments are jumping over precarious drops only to smash your pickaxe into a cliff face and begin slowly pulling yourself up. Lara’s strength feels beyond human most of the time, but it’s for the benefit of the gameplay. I can feel the number of hours Crystal Dynamics animators put into this work, and can only imagine the nights spent perfecting Lara’s movement to feel “just” right.

What makes Tomb Raider so fantastic is now just the combat and platforming in isolation, but how incredibly well-paced the whole thing is. Every time I thought I could do with some more shooting, there was a 20-minute firefight just around the corner. Whenever I felt I needed a break to take in the landscape, there was a tomb to explore or a set piece to travel across. There’s absolutely no tedium in this game, and the end product is an incredibly lean and well edited adventure that might only take around 13 hours to complete, or near 18 to 100%. By the game’s final mission, I was quickly adding the sequel to my Steam cart.

Tomb Raider (2013) is an expertly handed reboot that brings Lara to the modern age. The gameplay is so well-polished, so tightly tuned that it’s an absolute joy to play start to finish. For that, I can only give it the highest praise.

1.) Pretty standard Lara Croft Tomb Raider game with a few new bells and whistles in the 'newest' installment.
2.) A definite must playthrough the story campaign for any longtime Lara Croft franchise enjoyers.
3.) The way in which the camps and progression of the game were designed felt really nice to me.
4.) It became clear that the design of the UI and the menus was intended for console first in mind.
5.) With that being said, I felt that the UI translated well enough to be clean to navigate even with mouse & keyboard.
6.) The combat in the game was fairly engaging, about as good as it can get for any 3rd person POV/FOV.
7.) The guns felt satisfying to shoot and the progression of the game and puzzles kept me playing casually for a while.

Right from the beginning, Tomb Raider grabs your attention with its intense and cinematic sequences. As players guide a young and inexperienced Lara through treacherous environments and dangerous encounters, the game excels at creating a sense of vulnerability and determination. Witnessing Lara's transformation from a survivor to a resilient and resourceful adventurer is a captivating journey. The gameplay in Tomb Raider is a perfect blend of exploration, platforming, and combat. As you navigate stunning and intricately designed environments, you'll uncover hidden secrets, solve puzzles, and engage in exhilarating combat encounters. The controls are tight and responsive, making every jump, climb, and shootout feel satisfying and fluid

A rarity among the trophy hall of bad video games, Tomb Raider's 2013 reboot is bad within its own right, and bad within the scope of competitors and predecessors in a wide range of aspects. Despite having award-winning inspirations in the form of Uncharted and Assassin's Creed, Tomb Raider manages to take the worst elements of both (linear gameplay and boring climbing sequences lovingly garnished with the most abysmal camera of any game ever made), package them up neatly among a myriad of other game-destroying failures (a tragedy of a progression system, hilariously bad dialogue, illogical writing, and an impressive lack of tomb raiding), and throw the whole box of goodies open-side-first over a cliff (only to grab a hanging plank of wood at the last moment with QTE, of course). The sole bright spot - a very interesting underlying story. Wasted, shat upon, dumpstered by astronomically absurd character decision making (you're right, I think we should split up [ON AT LEAST FOUR OCCASIONS]) and an ending that reveals itself a mere quarter into the story, but only acknowledged by the protagonist at the last second after having traipsed halfway around the island chasing the last brain cell she was granted by birth. The combat is designed excitingly poorly - I genuinely found myself pleasantly amused by how stupid it is that the handgun, being the only accurate weapon in the game, outclassed every single damage source (point blank shotgun, fully automatic AK) with no question till the very end. And also how a muzzle brake raises said damage, hm. Tomb Raider is a lifeless, featureless, monstrous corpse, and I am never, ever delving back into this stinking crypt ever again.

I was really looking forward to try a game from the tomb raider series and was sadly disappointed. The story is not compelling at all in my opinion. You're immediately thrust into an intense shipwreck cutscene as the opener with absolutely no context, which is a terrible start because it makes it hard to care about the plot or any of the characters. All the characters are very boring and have no personality, sadly including Lara. Coming from someone who loves a strong female protagonist, I hate how Lara is portrayed. She comes across as a robotic being who magically continues through every hardship, but it doesn't feel genuine at all because there is absolutely no acknowledgement of her persistence or overcoming any struggle. All her actions are purely to drive the poorly done story with no emotion or logic. No puzzle solving feels rewarding, you solve a puzzle and something immediately goes wrong and you tumble into another problem, which becomes repetitive and cliche. It's odd how Lara does such amazing feats in the game, but you feel absolutely no strength at all from her. Rather than her successes coming from her strength or resilience or smarts or something of the sort, everything just seems to be pure luck which doesn't make Lara seem like a likeable or strong character and just feels like the cliche shallow female character in media. Another cliche - too many damn explosions. Feels like a bad action movie. The story and how it's presented and all the characters are something I strongly dislike about the game. The story of the island is promising but presented poorly and has lots of boring pieces scattered throughout too. The gameplay isn't redeeming either, I wouldn't say it's particularly fun or satisfying, it feels painfully average. A lot of the climbing mechanics are also very infuriating, a lot of the "parkour" is finicky, and if you're the tiniest bit off from the designated landing spot (despite taking the correct route) or or pressing a button a moment too early or late you fall to your death and have to do it again. I genuinely really wanted to like this game :( wouldn't recommend it and if you really want to try it at least buy it on sale, I wouldv'e been very pissed if I bought this as full price just to hate it.

Not enough puzzles / switches / exploration, which the original TR games did so well. And notable lack of tombs. Most of the time I was running around corrugated steel shanty towns or forests, fighting swarms of bad guys, thinking "Mmm...only things being raided here are kids' bank accounts and the creative endeavour of the original development team". 

There are 'optional tomb' challenges, which feel like a 'I suppose we have to' homage rather than a NECESSARY PART OF THE BRAND, IT BEING CALLED TOMB RAIDER. They're also way too small and unfulfilling. Like my knob. 

If you want to shoot bad guy after bad guy, with an option to stealth-kill them instead as you run between various choreographed set-pieces and QTEs then play this game...or any of the other gazillion like it. Let's face it they're all pretty much identical.

A good game to play. I recommend it. While you're here, Please enjoy this pie recipe:
Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 brown sugar
4. 1/2 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples -peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double crust pie
Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F ( 220 degrees C )
2. Combine butter , white sugar ,brown sugar, water , cinnamon and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside
3- Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices
4. Roll out top crust into 10 inch circle. Cut into 8 ( 1-inch ) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie,coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F ( 175 degrees C ) and bake until the crust is golden brown , the caramel on the top is set and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing

Tomb Raider runs flawlessly and the graphics are visually beautiful but if they don't satisfy you there are plenty of mods available that changes them. The story is just average but the action scenes easily make up for that. Its obvious the game takes inspiration gameplay-wise from the modern Uncharted games which is great and the dodge/melee system feels satisfying. 

I only had two issues whilst playing this, for example, some HUD elements were cut off in the corners of the screen. Also I had one glitch where the cliff side bunker door was glitched half open meaning I couldn't continue the story but by using grenades at the floor and rolling into the door I managed to bypass it. The game at normal difficulty was a breeze and I only recall dying a handful of times due to stupid mistakes like jumping too early, so I recommend playing on hard difficulty. 

Multiplayer is empty which is a shame because getting those achievements will be tough now.

My special interest <3 It's a beautiful, interactive open-world rpg and shooter game with puzzles, amazing cut scenes. and phenomenal game play for one that debuted in 2013. I sincerely enjoy all of it, and have played it 10 times by now, and each time I love it just as much -- if not, more!

Pros: Story, atmosphere, and platforming.
Cons: Forced third-person shooting sections
The game feels like two games, one a survival stealth platformer with your primary weapon as the bow. This part is absolutely excellent. Then the game will grind to a halt and force you to fight waves and waves of enemies with a shotgun and assault rifle which isn't nearly as fun. You get perks to help you in combat, but none of those perks actually increase your health, so even in the endgame you can only take 2 or so hits from enemy gunfire. It's realistic of course considering Lara is going around the whole game in a tank top, and fits the parts of the game where you need to stealthily take out enemies from afar. But the forced shooting sections just feel tacked on and unnecessarily frustrating. 
Absolutely everything else about the game is top-notch, though.

After multiple playthroughs and a decade, this reboot of famous British archaeologist and adventurer Lara Croft still holds true as an engrossing action-adventure experience focused around the theme of survival and ergo the loss of innocence. Could you push past your physical boundaries and even kill to save you and your loved ones? 

The look of the game has aged gracefully, say for some hair, fire, and blood effects. The soundtrack composed by Jason Graves is excellent; it is not only bombastic but excels in quieter and subtle moments–sometimes just the light tapping of drums or a few choice musical notes perfectly timed upon accomplishing a goal. Just a few notes from the game’s theme–”A Survivor Is Born”–are enough for it to bounce around my head for days afterwards.

The adventure is set in the forgotten civilization of Yamatai (a purported civilization of actual ancient Japan), a mysterious and eerie–yet also beautiful–island that Lara and her companions become marooned on. Danger creeps up on the castaways as the island conceals ancient ruins, remains of past explorers, forgotten WWII facilities, and a violent cult called the Solarii. This setting capped off with the scavenger-like constructs of the Solarii provide many action set pieces for the player to explore and fight through. 

An aspect of worldbuilding that stood out on this playthrough are the conversations between the Solarii members. Upon eavesdropping, one gets the sense that the members are conflicted: some believe the fantastical elements preached to them while others openly mock it. There are some colorful exchanges too. The standouts are a cultist begging another for a book to finish his series (he retorts there is no store on the island), and the other being a cultist imploring for help to find his pet rat.  

With all this praise in mind, the game's greatest achievements are its cinematic qualities and characterization. All the supporting protagonists are memorable, each with their own chance to shine. (And that's without reading their personal journals hidden throughout the game, which only further their motivations.) Lara’s journey is of course at the center of the story, and it keeps the player invested while propelling the story forward. Her metamorphosis from a naive girl to survivor is accomplished quite naturally (with just the right amount of badass moments that feel earned and not forced). She cannot save everyone. 

Oddly enough, perhaps the most memorable part of the game to me is a quick, simple cutscene showing Lara returning to the wreck of her ship, the Endurance, after surviving on the island for some time. After enduring so much trauma and grief, for a brief second, she stares into the mirror of her old ship quarters. Does she recognize the face staring back at her? Can she ever again?

I played this game through to the end, it has great gameplay, but I would highly recommend against it. It gets progressively worse as you go through the game, and reveals is darker influences more and more, right down to the very end. It has excessive, and I mean EXCESSIVE gore, including large quantities of genital mutilation, severed limbs and body parts, cannibalism, rooms filled with mutilated corpses, and even a scene of falling into blood of many dead men and having to swim through the blood. Many images of human sacrifice with graphic depictions, including people strung up in a crucified fashion if not directly crucified. The story goes from trying to discover a lost civilization, to the worship of an actual false goddess of the shinto religion, known as Amaterasu, the sun goddess in Japanese mythology, and it reveals this only in the concept art after completing the game, as well as that the shrines and altars were dedicated to her. She's given the name Himiko in the game, who was a shaman queen who ruled by means of magic and sorcery according to ancient Chinese texts, and she sent slaves as gifts to the emperor of China. She also had 1000 men and woman buried alive with her as a part of her funerary services. Oh and in the game she ruled oni, who are demons in Japanese mythology, and at the very end, "SPOILER ALERT" she my means of sorcery has kept on possessing the bodies of her priestesses and the final battle in the game is taking place while she tries to demonically possess one of the party members. So, definitely not safe for anyone, or Christian friendly.

Tomb Raider, developed by Crystal Dynamics, is a remarkable reboot of the beloved action-adventure franchise that introduced the world to the iconic Lara Croft. This 2013 release takes players on a thrilling journey as they witness Lara's transformation from a vulnerable survivor to a resilient and determined adventurer. With its cinematic presentation, intense gameplay, and a compelling narrative, Tomb Raider redefines the franchise for a new generation of gamers.

The game follows a young and inexperienced Lara Croft as she finds herself stranded on a mysterious island after a shipwreck. Struggling to survive, she must navigate treacherous environments, unravel ancient mysteries, and confront a ruthless cult that controls the island. The narrative explores Lara's resilience, growth, and inner strength as she battles not only the physical dangers but also her own fears and doubts. The story is well-paced, filled with suspenseful moments, and keeps players engaged throughout the gripping adventure.

Tomb Raider combines intense action sequences, exploration, and puzzle-solving elements, creating a satisfying gameplay experience. As Lara, players must traverse diverse environments, ranging from lush forests to crumbling ruins, while engaging in thrilling platforming, stealth, and combat encounters. The game strikes a balance between challenging encounters and more relaxed exploration, ensuring a varied and engaging gameplay loop.

The combat mechanics in Tomb Raider are polished and satisfying, with a wide variety of weapons and tools at Lara's disposal. From archery to close-quarter combat, players have multiple options to approach encounters based on their playstyle. The game also introduces a skill system that allows players to customize Lara's abilities, enhancing her combat prowess and survival instincts as the adventure progresses.

Tomb Raider boasts stunning visuals and a cinematic presentation that immerses players in its world. The environments are beautifully rendered, with attention to detail in the atmospheric lighting, weather effects, and environmental design. Lara herself is meticulously crafted, with realistic animations and expressions that add depth to her character. The game's set pieces and action sequences are visually spectacular, heightening the excitement and adrenaline of the gameplay.

One of the standout aspects of Tomb Raider is the character development of Lara Croft. As players guide her through the harrowing journey, they witness her transformation from a vulnerable and uncertain young woman to a resilient and determined adventurer. The voice acting and motion capture work bring Lara's emotions and growth to life, making her a relatable and captivating protagonist.

While Tomb Raider received critical acclaim and is widely regarded as a fantastic game, like any other title, it has its share of criticisms and flaws. The game occasionally suffers from pacing problems, with a few sections feeling repetitive or drawn-out, which can disrupt the overall flow of the experience. Some players felt that the game's combat encounters were relatively easy, especially on lower difficulty settings. The AI of enemies was considered simplistic, diminishing the level of challenge and tactical depth.

Despite being an adventure game, Tomb Raider received criticism for not offering as much exploration freedom as previous titles in the franchise. Some players found the world to be too linear and confined, reducing the sense of open exploration. The puzzle-solving elements in the game were often considered too straightforward and lacking in complexity. The puzzles could have been more challenging and thought-provoking, providing a deeper sense of satisfaction upon completion.

While Lara Croft's transformation into a strong and capable adventurer is a central theme of the game, some players felt that certain aspects of her character development were rushed or underdeveloped. Some moments and relationships could have been given more time and depth. The supporting cast of characters in the game had potential for more development, but many were underutilized and lacked significant depth. Expanding on their backstories and motivations could have added more emotional weight to the narrative.

Despite these flaws, Tomb Raider still received widespread praise for its engaging story, stunning visuals, and refined gameplay mechanics. Tomb Raider successfully reinvents a beloved gaming icon, delivering a thrilling and emotionally charged adventure. With its cinematic presentation, intense gameplay, and a compelling narrative, the game captures the essence of Lara Croft's origins while introducing fresh elements to the franchise. Whether you're a longtime fan or new to the series, Tomb Raider offers an immersive and unforgettable experience that will leave you eagerly anticipating Lara's future adventures. Strap on your climbing gear, embrace the unknown, and embark on an epic journey with the iconic Tomb Raider.

This part released in 2013 doesn't have auto-aim assist or HRD graphics. I recorded it @60FPS 4K with 60HZ and 36mbps bitrate. The hard combat level is the highest difficulty level of this game. Fights are strategic and one or two ways to pass some important checkpoints. Few rules I might tell you to enjoy the game bit more. When you RAID an enemy gathering or AMBUSH you must keep shooting, otherwise, no one will take cover you won’t be able to stand for a second. This shooting needs to be accurate mostly, enemies won't die without clear headshots. In an ambush of the enemy, you need to have an idea who is shooting after whom, their distance, your covers, and changing covers quickly to distract their aims. They do usually do the same. It is expected that some shots will not touch you or kill you while they are fixing aim at you. Don’t be so aggressive when the number of enemies is high, they keep coming in some stronghold locations and start acting randomly to make the player angry. Sometimes you must back off to get to cover when too many shooters aiming at you in one place. This game is really difficult to play in a cool head specifically at a hard difficulty level.



You'll get fire in the Bow to shoot arrows around the quarter of the game, and a grenade launcher around the middle of the game. You must play silent mode in some places. The use of ammo is critical for this game. Arrow is a bit easy to aim best for long distances, a shotgun for short distances very difficult to aim for moving opponents, the rifle is the best like the revolver but they kill ammo very quickly. Three main tricks; moving your body to adjust your aim sometimes, dodging with button B to kill a very close attack, and rolling out and rolling in keeping your aim in control. When all is learned perfectly you are ready to finish the game in 8 hours.

Absolutely great game!
Its a good start to the Tomb Raider reboot series, with the following games being awesome as well.

Even though the following games have improved the "Tomb Raider Style" in many different ways, this game is still the most focused on the shooter aspect due to numerous battle sequences and plenty of action, which I liked very much as a person that loves playing shooter games.
Additionally, this game (at least in my opinion) has the best weapon upgrade and crafting system of the series, supporting this side of the game even more.
But also the parkour and puzzle sections have a lot to offer and you definitely get your money's worth in these areas.
Also, in terms of story, this episode of the reboot series is the most solid out of all 3 games. 

So while I think that the other 2 games are better in some aspects, the first part is the best overall and therefore absolutely recommended.

It's been a while since I sat down to play a game and it felt impossible to put it down. I kept wanting to keep going, and when I finally managed to pull myself away to sleep, or eat, I couldn't wait to pick it up again. Tomb Raider has a few cheesy lines in it, but for the most part the visuals were good, the acting was good, the story was solid, and it paced itself in a way that you wanted to progress the story, but didn't feel so rushed that you couldn't stop and collect things. I 100% the game my first time and it felt rewarding. If you pay attention to your finds you will figure out what is happening before Lara does. In fact, if there is one complaint I have about the story, it is that Lara doesn't put 2+2 together for a little longer than it should have taken her. The game puzzles pose unique challenges, and are not repetitive. Exploring incentivizes strategy, and when things inevitably go wrong, you can improvise. There are multiple ways to play out any area: stealth, guns blazing, or manipulating explosive barrels. There are many different finishers that make you want to try out the different weapons. The biggest issue I had with the game play was that it was too easy, even on hard. The most frustrating part of it all was playing on a Steam Deck, which runs the game great, but is a controller, and aiming with a controller is tough when you have dozens of enemies swarming you, ducking in and out of cover. I mostly died to miss shots due to that. I recommend starting the game on hard. There were a few glitches that required restarting the game towards the latter half, but it was mostly a solid experience. All in all a 9.5/10 for me, you should 100% give it a try.

I bought this game for $3 on sale thinking it would be a relatively short, adventure game to play between the lengthy games of my backlog. But as soon as the first pre-rendered cutscene transitions to the game, there is a terrible amount of camera wobble that gave me an uncomfortable amount of motion sickness after. 10 minutes later, it doesn’t get better. I’ve played games like Mirror’s Edge were it’s a common first person camera complaint and I never felt sick. Even though it’s in third person, this game’s camera is really bad. I couldn’t go far enough to comment about the gameplay, but based on other critical reviews, it seems that this game is average at best and a middling title overall.
I cannot recommend this game to people sensitive to even a little motion sickness, and for three dollars I don’t really feel bad at all.

Mediocre with high points.

First off, I want to praise the presentation values in this game. Good visuals, nice environments, good voice acting. Music can be repetitive at certain times, but overall alright.

Now story isnt anything groundbreaking, but fundamentally quite alright.
There are problems though. Character development of a lot of supporting characters is weak, to the point of questioning why did they even bother having them.
The progression of the story could be better too. It starts out quite slow and feels rushed towards the end.
The development of Lara, as a character, seems quite decent. Although some things could have been done better.

The gameplay is where it has the most issues. The movement is clunky. I got the impression that game was meant to be more tilted towards stealth. It doesnt feel that well suited towards action gameplay. But towards the end you become a one man army and often stealth is in no way, shape or form an option. Not that I mind such gameplay, but considering this game is going for a serious tone, it kind of went overboard.
Combat often revolves around clearing tight locals of enemies or being swarmed in a broader area by enemies. They are either melee or ranged soldiers and throughout the game they start being buffed by armor and grenade throwing. Conceptually its alright, but there was always a feeling that it lacked finesse. If there were say, less soldiers, the combat was slower, but more tactically demanding, then I think it would have been a better experience.
Level design can at times feel irritating, when you are trying to figure out, where is the next twist you need to make in order to get where you want. Its trying to confuse you and that doesnt feel fun.
In the game there are also several types of collectibles and challenges you need to find and clear. A lot of them are just fluff that add almost nothing to the story or gameplay. They're just there to clear out and waste time.
Exploring and traversing the island is a hit and miss. Sometimes its fun, but sometimes it can feel shallow. The action scenes and events are usually fun where you need to escape a collapsing environment, but they can feel few and far in between if you dont stick to the main story line all the time.

One thing I noticed that kinda bothers me. Why did all the white male characters die and all the minority characters survived? Is it that stunning and brave thing again?

There are some other gripes I could discuss, but I think I got the point across.
Its not a bad game, but it doesnt push the potential that it sets up. A lot of things feel mediocre, with the odd very cool moment shinning through.

[i] Short summary: I highly recommend this game. [/i]

Crazy to think this may be the last time I talk about the Tomb Raider games with this being the last one (unless the rumours about a new Tomb Raider prove me wrong otherwise), I'm not really interested in continuing the rest of this trilogy of Lara's fetch quest in following her father's footsteps. I'm not convinced I'll enjoy the rest of the and I think this is a nice stopping spot for this franchise. 

Just a disclaimer, this is probably my first time, or of recent playing a survival horror RPG TP game, so most of my high praises for this game comes from my lack of experience with those sorts of games, and I know there are probably better ones, like Uncharted and the Last of us, but I'm not planning on playing those games. 

Speaking on that, Tomb Raider is a good substitute or a start-up if you want to get into those sorts of genres, the premise is somewhat like the King Kong movie if the last 2 were good. Ship crashes, you're stuck on a mysterious island, you're hunting for food, shelter, and warmth,  some people want to eat you there's a lot of supernatural s*** going on, the island has a lot of embodied secrets for you to discover and figure out. You know what, by itself, this could make a good turn-your-brain-off movie for the amount of endurance Lara had to the point she still has an untreated hole in her gut, I only realise this a couple of days after finishing this game. Sorry, I'm rambling now, where am I going with this? 

I came into this game spoiler-free by ignoring it thinking nothing much about it, but as soon as I played it, it become one of the most fun experiences I had from an older big corporation game. The controls like the combat/ gunplay and platforming/ parkouring just flow well together with the weather affecting the realistic environment as well traversing through a makeshift landscape feeling nice making the game immersive, not point it doesn't feel like a game. There's still some simple tomb raiding with some clever puzzles to solve if you to earn more XPs for Lara to learn more skills. If you can't figure it out right away you can always come back with a campfire fast travel system that allows you to revisit and backtrack any areas you want to finish exploring once you unlock the necessary skills or equipment for it, like being able to climb on walls. 

Even with all those praises so far, there are still some things some problem with this game, like the new character being nothing too interesting, just bland and a bit one-note. The other problem it has it appears there's a disconnect between the cutscene cinematic team and the gameplay developer due to how chaos Lara has to go through, like surviving from a waterfall, a plane crash, or an endless swarm of enemies attacking her, but every time we see the side characters in a new location they somewhat manage to get there unscathed avoiding all the danger, like really? I know this sort of problem isn't unique to this, more so an annoying nitpick for me, but if hear another character asking me What took you so long?', I'll just pretend to give them a death stare at them thinking 'seriously, do you not see what I have to do to get here?'

Before I go overboard with nitpicking, I gonna say I probably like this newer version of Lara Croft a lot more than previous games, I'm not the only one to say that she's a lot more sympathetic and relatable starting as this innocent archaeologist with knowledge wanting to learn and explore other culture. Her vulnerable side is highlighted when making a tricky decision, like killing someone and crying over it, (I would do the same thing if I was in her shoes), making her emphasise that I can't help support her on her journey. Like most video games, it was nice to see Lara Croft as the protagonist get a lot of developments whilst progressively through the game becoming more confident and in tune with her situation. Before she was afraid of the enemies, but now the enemies know her name and are afraid of her, [spoiler]especially when she's carrying a grenade launcher toward them, that was a badass moment I have to say. [/spoiler]

[h1]Final Conclusion and a Goodbye: [/h1]

Yay, what an amazing game this was with a lot of action, a gorgeous scene, and some interesting lore surrounding it. Sometimes, I wonder why I skipped this game for all those years but I'm glad I finally played it a little later so I can have much more of an appreciation and some sort of adult nostalgia toward it when I get a lot older (if that's a thing). 

If there's a Tomb Raider game to start, begin with this one, even if you're playing it standalone story this game is highly recommended to almost everyone. 

I didn't think I'll be reviewing this game as well as the other older Tomb Raider trilogy this year. Apparently, I have a lot to say about them, but I am glad I manage to get my opinion out there, which was mostly positive, thankfully. Check out the other review of the previous Tomb Raider trilogy if you're interested in my thoughts, here's a small summary: 
[hr][/hr][list]
[*]Tomb Raider Anniversary- No
[*]Tomb Raider Legend - High recommendation to start off
[*]Tomb Raider Underworld-Nich high recommendation 
[/list]
[hr][/hr]
Either way, thank you for reading my rambling, sorry if I was all over the place, I hope you'll have a fun experience with this game if you decided to play it. 

Finally, I can say goodbye and farewell to this series.

[h1]Tomb Raider (2013): A Riveting Reboot that Sets a New Standard[/h1]

Rating: ★★★★☆ (4 out of 5 stars)
[list]
[*][b]Visually Stunning: The game's graphics are a visual feast, with lush environments, detailed character models, and breathtaking cinematic sequences. The attention to detail immerses players in a visually stunning world that feels alive and dynamic.[/b]

[*][b]Compelling Narrative: The game delivers a compelling story that explores Lara Croft's origins as she evolves from a vulnerable survivor to a resilient and determined explorer. The character development is well-executed, adding depth and emotional weight to the journey.[/b]

[*][b]Engaging Gameplay: Tomb Raider offers a mix of exploration, puzzle-solving, and intense combat sequences. The gameplay is fluid and responsive, with intuitive controls that make traversal and combat feel natural and satisfying. The variety of weapons, tools, and abilities adds depth to the gameplay experience.[/b]

[*][b]Immersive Environments: The game's locations, ranging from ancient tombs to sprawling jungles, are intricately designed and filled with secrets to discover. The sense of exploration is enhanced by hidden collectibles and optional tombs that provide additional challenges and rewards.[/b]

[*][b]Minor Flaws: While Tomb Raider is an excellent game overall, it occasionally suffers from predictable storytelling and linear level design. Some may find the combat sequences repetitive after extended play, and the lack of choice in certain situations limits the game's potential for player agency.[/b]
[/list]
[b][i]In conclusion, Tomb Raider (2013) is a riveting reboot that successfully brings Lara Croft into the modern era. With its stunning visuals, compelling narrative, and engaging gameplay, it sets a new standard for action-adventure games. Despite its minor flaws, the game offers an immersive and enjoyable experience that fans of the franchise and newcomers alike will appreciate.[/i][/b]

[h1]More than just an Uncharted Clone[/h1]

I honestly liked Tomb Raider more than I thought it would. I came in here expecting a poor man's Uncharted clone. After finishing the game I am left with wanting more. It is very similar to the Uncharted games, albeit it does do unique things to distinguish itself from the former. Most notably the somewhat more open level design. It is still very linear but you are sometimes faced with larger "hub-like" areas and optional tombs (which are just a single puzzle) which are largely missing from the Uncharted games.

Let's move away from the Uncharted comparisons and speak on what the game does. Gameplay is split between traversal and combat. For traversal, all you do is wander down often linear paths with minor platforming challenges and easy puzzles. Combat has two approaches, stealth and guns blazing. Both of these styles of combat are marred by very poor AI. AI are often comically oblivious in stealth and during a gunfight, enemies will often exit cover and walk in a straight line towards your position. Gun-play is also nothing to write home about and stealth is way too shallow to even bother with. Even with all these complaints, I still enjoyed my time during battles. They were like junk food, fun but nothing special.

I'm not sure if this is an apt comparison, but the story gave me heavy Indiana Jones vibes which I like a lot. The story was an enjoyable action filled romp. Although the beginning of the game makes you expect something more gritty but then turns into something more akin to Uncharted (I'm sorry for bringing it up again). I'm not very good at critiquing narratives as I am easily pleased, so I will leave off saying that I simply enjoyed the story.

Lastly, my technical experience was fairly good. The game ran amazingly but had issues with the UI. Certain UI elements that flashed on screen when going near an interactable or trying to grab ammo that you are full on are cut off at the top left of the screen. Thankfully nothing essential was cut off but it was still annoying nonetheless. Also, voice audio and sound fx audio were combined in settings for some reason. Music was not thankfully, but sometimes sound fx drowned out dialogue which is somewhat remedied by subtitles. Other than those issues, the game ran extremely well with no noticeable frame drops or crashes.

tl;dr
Tomb Raider is definitely worth playing because of its fun narrative and enjoyable albeit easy gameplay.

First things First - This is not your childhood tomb raider. Old school was a barrage of puzzles, deadly animals, booby traps and clunky controls; as you led indiana jones-esque lara through crazy ruins and the odd modern town/building.

This is an origin / reboot for the series, and it plays much more like uncharted or arguably even gears of war (albeit with the cover mechanics and chain saws replaced with stealth and bows).
It is a tale of a much younger and inexperienced lara croft finding herself stranded on a mysterious isle full or insane survivors, wild game, and ancient samurai. 

Gameplay: Controls for the most part work and feel soooooooo good which is huge relief after the robotronic controls of the ps1 and ps2 era games. It has the arbitrary rpg elements that every other game feels the need to have in there too - earn xp to unlock perks, find collectibles for more xp, supplies to upgrade weapons. 

         The majority of the weapons feel great as do most of the upgrades. The bow works great for hunting and long range stealth kills, pistol is a trusty close-mid range weapon, assault rifle for when the shit hits the fan.
Silencer upgrades feel somewhat unnecessary and honestly do little to help. It also commits (what is in my mind) an annoying and common trope - shotgun has almost zero range. If you've ever shot a shotgun in real life, you probably know you can hit target with a good portion of the pellets in the shell from more than 3 feet away, and most of the pellets don't spray in a 180 degree arc. It certainly doesn't hinder the gameplay but it's one of those little things you commonly see like no-noise silencers that bug people who really like accurate portrayals of the little things.

The story is good but nothing breakthrough and revolutionary. Be forewarned the game is VERY cringe inducing at times. Some of the scenes are pretty brutal especially for something labeled Tomb Raider - many of the death sequences might disturb those of a gentle sensibility. It does not feel good to watch a 16/17ish year old girl get impaled through the torso on a gigantic tree branch or strangled to death D:

The hidden tombs were neat little puzzles with big rewards and were entertaining to do. I wish there was a few more or at that they had been a little longer/more challenging.

However those few tiny things did very little to detract from the overall experience. If I had any good honest-to-god complaints about it, there are three and one (few people in multiplayer which is kinda meh imho) is not something everyone will care about. 
The other complaints which I feel is very valid: 

(1)There were too many sequences where you had to run in what was essentially a straight line while the bridge, building, plane wreck, etc. was being blown to hell and you jump or slide down some stuff. There is one in almost every major area. After the second or third  time they lose the excitement and feel very cliche.

(2) Too much quick time stuff. I don't mind it much but there are a lot of uneeded button prompts, short QTE's, and mashing X. I'm kind glad they were simple though, didn't have to really repeat any: stick to shake loose, combat prompt is almost always Y on my pad, grabbing or mashing stuff was always x. While simple QTE's certainly aren't entertaining, these did not interrupt a rad cutscene orhad to be attempted multiple times *coughhrmmcough* Resident Evil 4 krauser knife fight *COUGH COUGH*


Overall though: Pretty darn entertaining. Tight controls, fair combat, some good platforming and puzzles and a campaign that'll last you 8-12 hours. And it looks fan-freakin-tastic, especially with if you can run everything at top settings. Would have appreciated less quicktime events or tap x, and pew pew explosion running sequences. Unless you have the patience to find decent sized multiplayer matches and enjoy them, I'd probably wait for it to go on sale even if it was only 15% off.

Its pretty decent. I 100% completed the single player in around 14 hours or so. 

Story is fine but I didn't find myself invested in the characters more just the plot. Didn't like how you never really travel with a friend outside of a cutscene. I didn't care for anyone when they died because I didn't spend any time with them. The plot is interesting and unique however.

The combat is fine but is quite boring. Also the visuals on the Assault rifle for example are awful. The gun itself has no recoil on Lara but the bullets just come out the barrel in random directions. it looks terrible.  

The climbing and platforming is pretty fun but can be glitchy. Too many times I fell when I pressed climb or was going for a zipline. QTE's are really bad at the start but happen less often later. The small world environments on the island you can explore with secrets are a nice touch to give more for the player to do, but why allow the player to do everything the first time they are there? You get abilities later like the rope ascender but only use it in the place you unlocked it and beyond. Why not have puzzles or areas only accessible by going back after the story with the new abilities to keep the player interested after? The tombs are literately just one puzzle that takes like 2 mins to figure out and do. Way too short but sweet enough.

I actually managed to find my way to a story section you are not meant to access after beating the story and my 100% save is just bugged at some place I can't escape because it saved when I got down. Pray this doesn't happen to anyone else going for 100%. Not a bad reboot for Lara in the end.

TLDR: generic and mediocre. Not bad necessarily, but no reason to play this over anything else.
The 2013 reboot is certainly easier to play than the OG, but the modernization comes at the cost of all the charm and everything that made the original unique.
This new Tomb Raider is a mediocre third person shooter, with platforming that might as well be a qte, a meaningless progression system, and a pointless pseudo-open world. The plot and characters are a bit bland, and the cutscenes and actions sequences aren't any better than the actual gameplay they interrupt.
The sequel is a little better, and the overall plot is pretty episodic, so you aren't missing anything if you skip this one. Just try the sequel. Or Uncharted. Or just a different genre honestly.

The fast-paced parts of the main story are exciting and satisfying from an action standpoint, but in other parts, the gameplay mechanics fall into too much repetition in many places and start to become boring after a while. Overall, it's an ok origin game.

Tomb Raider 2013 has an aesthetic and vibe that's kinda scrappy and...not necessarily realistic, but somewhat grounded? Maybe it's the art direction, but it feels like a bridge between the brown era of early to mid 360 and PS3 titles and the photogrammertry + global illumination era of the Xbox One and PS4. Not quite photorealistic, not quite stylised, but very pretty and unique.

I love Tomb Raider's pacing; it never has a dull moment, and is far more action film than any previous TR game. And yeah, it definitely lost the puzzle + combat variety that the LAU era had, but I think it made sense for the era in which it released. As much as I love Legend and Underworld, I think it made sense to chase mass appeal, especially with the success of Uncharted and other third person shooters at the time. I do wish it focused a bit more on the 'tomb' part of 'tomb raider', because the devs clearly put so much thought into Yamatai and its history only for players to possibly completely miss all of it in search of the next combat arena. 

Lara herself is the game's strongest suit, as her transformation from scared shipwreck victim to vengeful, brutal, murderer gives shades of Jason from Far Cry 3, but not quite as successful. I know literally every reviewer has pointed out TR2013's ludonarrative dissonance, but I honestly don't think it's quite as bad as, say, Uncharted. It's clear that Yamatai is a place in which only the strong and brutal survive, as evidenced by Mathias and his Solarii. So it seems only natural that, trapped in an environment in which only the strong survive, Lara would quickly become even more violent than her enemies as she becomes increasingly desensitised and vengeful in her pursuit of both her friends and a way off the island. It's also kinda clear that Roth taught Lara survival skills, which definitely included fireams training. So when she shoots Nikolai in self-defence, it seems like it awakens something in her, kinda a feeling of 'well, I've killed one person and it wasn't that bad, so I'll kill anyone who stands in the way of getting home'.

idk, I might be rly misinterpreting Lara, but I also think there's definitely enough in the game to support such a read.

Speaking of combat, TR2013 has THE BEST pistol sound I've ever heard in a game. It's such a satisfying sound, especially as it reverberates around the environment. Actually, all the weapon sound effects are excellent, as are the shooting mechanics and even upgrade trees, which I normally hate. I rly love when games show your upgrades visually, so seeing Lara's guns change over the course of the game was super satisfying.

Oh! Also, istg there's a subtext of Big Sapphic Energy between Sam and Lara. I know the game tries to set up Alex as Lara's love interest, but it honestly feels so halfhearted and kinda like the result of a writer changing the love interest last minute because some producer said a non-straight relationship shouldn't be in the game. Again, I'm probably reading waaaaaay too much into this, but it's based on the way that Sam and Lara interact and how Lara's voice changes around her, the way they hug, and just general vibes lol. I'm honestly curious to know if in original drafts of the script, it was more overt, or if I'm just seeing stuff that's not even there.

Ultimately, I rly like Tomb Raider, and think it was a rly compelling starting point to the Survivor trilogy that neither sequel truly capitalised upon (especially Shadow). I'd totally recommend it, and still can't believe it's ten (10) years old???

The game itself is good however the camera shake is so bad that I had to quit. The camera shake is nauseating and gives me migraines. If you can stand the camera shake then I'm sure you'll enjoy the story. For me, I doubt I'll be able to finish it.

NOTE: Modern computers will have bugs. I had to back down to build743.0 in steam because the HUD bugs out on larger monitors in latest patches (reports are that it expects monitors no larger than 24"). The game also has visual and gameplay issues if your frames are too high, so I had to use VSYNC to fix that. You also often have to reload checkpoints sometimes as Laura will suddenly refuse to do things like her climbing jump--almost quit right after the very first camp you find because of this when I spent 20 minutes trying to get the bow because the game was just bugging out. Kind of wild to me that these exist in a ten year old game they were just pumping up for resale due to the anniversary event.

As for the game itself, I bought this back in 2015 and didn't make it very far. Not sure why but it just didn't hold my interest. Decided to pick it up in 2023 during a lull in other games and liked it a lot. It surprisingly holds up fairly well, but it's definitely showing some age. Worth a play through, but there are a lot of QTEs and they're hard to decipher and a bit unforgiving, so some sequences get frustrating as it becomes "do it over and over until you memorize the sequence." The controls are also not intuitive and a bit unresponsive by today's standards. The menus are pretty, but actually pretty hard to navigate and certain things in the game are introduced poorly or just not at all (collectibles, side tombs, even your map). I enjoyed the story though so it kept me playing through until the end. I fairly naturally hit 80% completion without backtracking but I was probably ~50% through the game before I really figured out how to use the map/survival instinct. (That said I didn't look up guides / walkthroughs on purpose).

It's good but there's nothing here to make me want to do another playthrough or finish out that last 20%. I often like to 100% games, but not when so many of the achievements are for multiplayers. So liked the game and its worth a buy given how cheap it is now, but be prepared for some frustrating technical issues and gameplay that doesn't quite feel polished by modern standards for third person action adventure games.

Tomb Raider is one of the best action games currently available. The game offers a great combination of story, graphics and gameplay, making it incredibly fun and exciting.

Tomb Raider offers you a variety of different missions where you have to overcome obstacles, fight enemies and solve various puzzles. The game also allows you to discover different secrets, collect resources and upgrade your equipment. All these elements, along with incredible graphics and an excellent story, make Tomb Raider an unforgettable experience.

However, for some players, the game may be too short. If you are an experienced gamer who is used to fast paced and quick completion games, you may feel that the game was too short. This can be disappointing, but if you focus on the details and try to play through the game again, you may discover new elements that fill you with joy.

Overall, Tomb Raider is a great game that will win the hearts of many gamers. If you are a lover of action games and adventure, this is the game for you. Even if you found the game too short, don't be afraid to go through it again and discover new possibilities and experiences.

Tomb Raider is a classic action-adventure game that has been entertaining players for decades. The game follows the adventures of the iconic protagonist Lara Croft as she explores ancient ruins and solves puzzles in search of treasure and artifacts.

The game's graphics and visuals are impressive, with stunningly detailed environments and character designs that bring the game's world to life. The game's sound design is also excellent, with atmospheric music and sound effects adding to the overall immersive experience.

The game's combat mechanics are also well-designed, with a variety of weapons and tools available to Lara as she battles her way through enemies and obstacles. The game's puzzle-solving mechanics are also a highlight, challenging players to think creatively and use their problem-solving skills to progress through the game.

One potential downside of the game is its linear progression, which can make it feel somewhat restricted and limiting at times. However, this is offset by the game's engaging storyline and memorable characters.

Overall, Tomb Raider is a classic game that is still worth playing today. Its impressive visuals, engaging gameplay mechanics, and iconic protagonist make it a must-play for fans of the action-adventure genre. I would rate Tomb Raider a 4 out of 5 for its memorable gameplay and impressive visuals.

Replaying Tomb Raider (2013) in 2023 after a slew of disappointing newer AAA games really highlighted how great this is.

Story is well-paced, focused, with clear progression in gameplay and visuals between areas. Environments are wonderfully hand-crafted and change with story events.

Collectables are few per area and actually interesting (you get to learn a bit about different historical artefacts). During the more intense sections, there are ZERO chests, collectables or side objectives. It's so amazing when you notice it compared to other games (middle of a burning building, before an obvious boss fight? Wait, better run around to find that 1 out of 250 copy-pasted collectable).

"Crafting" is just a simple 1-resource upgrade system, because this is a action-adventure videogame, not a chore simulator. It encourages you to pick things up as you go but there is never any need to grind.

The main con is it's too easy. On hard mode, I was always full on ammo, and the only times I died was when I was messing around with melee specials. I appreciate that enemies aren't bullet sponges though.

Tombs are just mini-puzzles, one room with 2-3 moving parts, sometimes you have to time 1 jump or whatever. There are a couple of slightly longer puzzles but they're still straightforward.

Occasional minor bug with mouse focus in menus but otherwise playing with M&KB was great.

The level design is dazzling, displaying a decent a grasp and genuine love for Japanese crafts and history, though perhaps a tad more diversity would have been appreciated. The gameplay is remarkably fluid and effective, with smooth transitions between the numerous scripted events, the platforming and action or infiltration phases. All of those are very well made and the controls are a model of simplicity and efficacy (except for all the times I've lit a torch trying to pick up ammo!) The enemies' AI is pretty good and even packs a few surprises, though the 'bosses' were a little disappointing (partly relying on quicktime events, which I hate.) The 'enigmas' were a bit disappointing compared to the excellence of TROTR (the next opus in the series), some of them demanding menially repetitive movement and a few displaying no real logical structure, but they were all eventually manageable. 
The game's real strength is as a cinematic experience, bizarre as it sounds. Many (most?) AAA games try so hard to look like big budget movies: I often complain about it, because I'm not fond of big budget movies. Well the TR series tries and pulls it pretty well I have to say. The dialogues and voice-acting are pretty convincing, and although the story plays it safe, it holds its own in the face of many a Hollywoodian adventure flick. The various villains are really secondary characters, and the environment get's the lion's share of our attention, but the supporting crew is well fleshed out (though more screen time would have been better). Lara herself is well designed and animated. She lacks perhaps a little character but the 'survivor' theme is effectively narrated, particularly in the opening sequence. 
My only complaint: I nearly finished it in one sitting. That says something to the game's quality (I seldom 'binge') but it also says something to its length. I played on hard (and I am not particularly 'good' at games usually) and I found it all too easy. What content there is in there, is dazzling, but compared to the following opus, there's just not enough of it. I paid less than a tenner for it, though, and that was totally worth my investment.

For a reboot of a series that had lost its focus and purpose, gathering fifteen years of baggage over the course of nine games, this new shot at it shows remarkable confidence. It has all the pieces of a third-person action title, but it's also isn't rushing for completion.

This version gives us a younger version of Lara Croft, an archaeology-obsessed young woman eager to follow in her father’s footsteps, and her group bound toward the stormy islands of The Dragon's Triangle. When her ship crashes, separating her from the crew, she's forced to explore, survive and uncover the mystery of the island's strange, hostile inhabitants.
Lara doesn’t start off as the badass heroine that we know from her earlier games. Instead, she starts off as a survivor of her shipwreck looking for the missing crew. That isn’t to say she doesn’t turn into that person; her transformation takes place within the first few hours of the game. As Lara pushed through narrow caves, crawled along ledges, killed her first animal and scavenged for parts. Lara's first kill is the game's first dramatic crescendo, a moment of genuine emotional impact; but that doesn’t last long. She goes from a terrified survivor to a reluctant killer looking for blood in an instant. She had to get used to killing quickly, and so does the player.

The freedom that this game provides when exploring is refreshing. The Dragon's Triangle isn't an open world exactly, but it's far from a jungle-themed series of hallways. Each of the major locations has multiple zones, which most of them are wide open for you and Lara to explore at your own leisure. You can breeze through the game quickly, going from checkpoint and objective to checkpoint and objective, or you can take your time and explore your surroundings (which, in my opinion, is the best way the play). If you decide to explore, each side path and every lone, faraway cliff has a bonus waiting—whether it be salvage, boxes, ammo, or a lost relic or document that helps you piece together the history of the island.

Lara periodically discovers new weapons, injecting the combat with fresh novelty every few hours; and whether you’re fighting with a bow, a shotgun, a pistol, or a rifle, the combat is probably one of my favorites in a series. Each area is populated with combat encounters that follow the same open-ish design that the game carries. If you want to sneak around, you can take out enemies with stealthy melee kills and well-placed headshots from your bow. If you want to run in firing your assault rifle, more enemies will be alerted to your presence, but it is satisfying to watch them all die by your hand. The game throws in explosives, vertical level design, multiple points of entry for bad guys and tons of other wrinkles to the combat that help make each scenario stand out.

This new take on the series is cinematic yet open, intense yet laid-back, fresh yet polished.

9.3 out of 10PROS:(1) I'm 40-year-something old and this is the first Tomb Raider game I have ever played. This game was very thrilling and I enjoyed a lot. I felt like I'm controlling a character in an action movie. (2) Difficulty of the game was good. I played "normal" but sometimes I had to repeat the same battle many times to beat all enemies. Overall it's not too easy and not too difficult. It was really right difficulty for me. (3) I liked the fact that I can redo the same battle or scene right before Lara dies. If I had to redo way back from the beginning, I would give up but I can redo right before Lara dies. (4) I'm using an office desktop PC with a low-profile graphic card but the game worked fine on 780p screen, and graphic looks nice to me even though this game was released in 2013. (5) I liked that navigation system when I press L1 button, any interactive objects near me light up. That's nice system and very player-friendly. (6) Controlling of the character was excellent with great movement and actions.CONS:(1) I don't like so much playing game where people kill people. I didn't expect that Lara has to kill hundreds of people in the game. I enjoyed the game anyway but I prefer that the enemies are not human. (2) Sometimes I have no idea which way to go or to jump, so I tried to go or jump and as a result Lara dies: Lara can climb up a 15-feet tall building, yet she can not climb up a 6-feet random rock in the game. (3) Once I finished the game, there are some items to collect or some places to go but I may not be playing after the completion. The very first play-through is the most enjoyable. There is not really addictive elements in this game that you want to play over and over again. (4) Online game is not working.Overall, I highly recommend this game!

[h1]Tomb Raider 2013: A Decepticon's Perspective[/h1]

[b]Pros[/b]

[*]Thrilling and immersive gameplay that keeps you engaged from start to finish, perfect for any Decepticon looking for a challenge
[*]Stunning graphics and visuals that bring the world of Tomb Raider to life, just like our beloved planet Cybertron
[*]Compelling story that makes you care about the characters and their struggles, something even Megatron can appreciate

[u]Cons[/u]

[*]Some of the puzzles can be frustrating and feel like a chore to complete, much like the human's constant attempts to resist our rule over the universe
[*]The game can be quite linear at times, limiting exploration and player choice, but as Decepticons, we know the importance of staying focused on our mission

[i]Final Verdict[/i]

As a proud Decepticon, I was intrigued to experience this reboot of the Tomb Raider series from a human's perspective. However, I found myself thoroughly enjoying the game's exciting gameplay, stunning graphics, and compelling story, despite some minor frustrations with the puzzles and linearity. If you're looking for a great action-adventure game that will keep you engaged from start to finish, I highly recommend giving this game a try, even if you have to temporarily put aside your plans for energon extraction. Who knows, you may even gain a better understanding of the human race and their fascination with these so-called "video games."

A Brilliant take on a classic franchise. Personally, this game doesn't feel like its from 2013. If you told me it came out in the past 5 years or so I wouldn't question it. Ahead of its time.

Tomb Raider ist ein actionreiches Spiel, das sich auf die Anfänge der berühmten Archäologin Lara Croft konzentriert. Das Spiel wurde von Crystal Dynamics entwickelt und von Square Enix veröffentlicht. Es ist ein Neustart der Tomb Raider-Serie, welcher 2013 stattfand, und bietet eine neue Interpretation des Charakters und der Handlung.

Die Grafik des Spiels ist, auch im Jahr 2023 für damalige, Verhältnisse immer noch atemberaubend und die Umgebungen sind sehr detailliert gestaltet. Von schneebedeckten Bergen bis hin zu dunklen Höhlen, jede Umgebung hat ihren eigenen Charme und ihre eigenen Herausforderungen. Die Charaktermodelle sind ebenfalls sehr gut gestaltet und verleihen den Figuren eine hohe Detailgenauigkeit.

Die Handlung des Spiels ist fesselnd und bietet viele überraschende Wendungen. Lara muss auf einer mysteriösen Insel überleben und ihre Freunde retten, während sie sich mit einer unbekannten Bedrohung auseinandersetzt. Die Geschichte wird sehr gut erzählt und lässt den Spieler tief in das Spiel eintauchen.

Das Gameplay ist sehr gut gestaltet und bietet eine Mischung aus Action, Rätseln und Erkundung. Das Kampfsystem ist flüssig und macht Spaß, während die Rätsel herausfordernd und lohnend sind. Das Spiel hat auch eine Vielzahl von Sammelgegenständen und optionalen Herausforderungen, die es dem Spieler ermöglichen, die Welt vollständig zu erkunden.

Insgesamt ist Tomb Raider ein hervorragendes Spiel, das jedem empfohlen werden kann, der Action-Abenteuer-Spiele liebt.

End-Note: Auch auf dem Steam Deck ist das Spiel eine klare Empfehlung!
