Truly engaging story and atmosphere, with decent combat and stealth mechanics, and memorable (yet predictable) characters.

I played this entirely on Steam Deck. I completed the main campaign and most of the collectibles and upgrades (for a 95% completion). I was able to play on Ultra settings using Proton experimental.

NOTE: Don't make the same mistake I did and change your proton version without backing up your save first. I lost my first 6 hours doing this due to poor performance on the normal version of proton.

I grew up with the PlayStation 1 classics and have loved this franchise for decades. This reboot gave the franchise new life. It didn't feel like a cash grab, and the people working on it knew what made a good Tomb Raider game. The story had depth, even though it was a bit predictable at times, and the world felt alive. With wildlife running around, lush greenery, rushing water everywhere, and the ancient villages, this felt like a truly lived in world. The mystery surrounding the island and how you uncover it felt well paced. There was never a dull moment.

When you encounter hostile wildlife (only a few wolves), and the other unfortunate inhabitants of the island, the game does a good job of introducing you to combat mechanics. It worked well slow rolling it, because at this stage Lara Croft is not the bad-ass we have known for 25+ years. She is a young girl in it for the discovery. She hadn't been put into dangerous situations like this. As you gear up and learn new skills the combat feels pretty satisfying overall, but gets repetitive. Especially since all the encounters happen at scripted times. It works in this game though with the story driven and cinematic approach they took with the game.

The characters are not bad, but they also are not great. Some are pretty memorable, but very predictable. You also don't really grow attached to any of them other than Lara. Not a bad thing, since she is the heroine in this story and is told from her perspective, but it would have been nice to care more about the other members in your party.

In addition to the campaign there are collectibles in each area, camps which you can fast travel between, and hidden tombs. None of it feels out of place, since she is an archeologist first and foremost, collecting relics and exploring tombs feel natural. Later in the game you can unlock skills to help make collecting item easier as well.

My only real complaints with the game came from the shaky camera during cinematics, and the number of quicktime events. Nothing that detrimental though.

Overall, I really enjoyed this game. More than I thought I would. I was engaged from beginning to end, and it felt like a proper reboot to a beloved franchise.

9/10 - EXCELLENT!

Awesome action-adventure and a great reboot to a beloved franchise! Lara Croft was long overdue for a modern new look and deserves all the praise for her legacy in the video game industry. The devs did a great job and poured all their passion into this game. It is well balanced with action and exploration sequences. The tombs are basically environmental puzzles and are easy to solve. Some would criticize that they lack complexity, but I'm on the side that they are serviceable and fit the story and the island setting. Since I mentioned the story, have to say that it is OK and keeps you invested to see the ending. The graphics are good and I took plenty of screenshots of beautiful vistas. The sound design is solid and the gameplay is smooth. Whether you explore and traverse the environment, or shoot and melee your opponents, you are always in control. Since this game was released in 2013, it runs extremely well on modern PC's. With Ultra settings I never saw less then 100 FPS. If you are a fan of the genre, definitely play this ~10 hr. adventure. You won't regret it!

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

Game that tries to be realistic survival experience. Genesis of one of the most iconic game character - Lara Croft. 
After the first hour game just gives up, and becomes generic cover shooter with some jumping and puzzles.

PROS:
- Nice graphics.
- Good platforming.
- Puzzles are interesting.
- Weapon and skill upgrading is nice.
- Controls are precise and simple.

CONS:
- CAMERA IS CONSTANLY SHAKING! It does not matter if you are walking, talking, fighting or platforming. Camera shakes violently all the time.
- Story is first about survival, then about mystery. Main characters are complete morons, including Lara. This destroys any atmosphere, that story is trying to set.
- Main characters are acting painfuly stupid in cutscenes. Lara could have shot main villain a million times over the course of a game.
- Shooting feels like crap.
- Maybe worst shotgun of any game ever? Works ONLY at point-blank range even when fully upgraded.
- Cover mechanic is automatic - that means it is not working when you want to.
- Enemies are retarded cannon fodder. No tactics at all.
- "Secret" Tombs have entrances so visible, that many times I confused them with a main path. Writings on the wall, lit torches and sound alerting you, that there is "Secret nearby". Duh..
- Tombs are a joke. One large room with a chest, that you reach after solving one puzzle.
- Lara picks something from every treasure chest and because she does not have backpack, she just shove it up her as.s. We never see what she took. It makes discovering completely worthless.
- Lara never wears anything protective. Some jacket, or gloves. Anyone in survival situation would try to wear more than a tanktop.
- Lara becomes invincible, Rambo style - killing machine in the first half of a game.
- Lara with her spooked-sad face reloads weapons without looking, faster than a Terminator.
- On-rail sections are annoying and stupid. Everything is crumbling, shaking, exploding like in a Michael Bay movie.
- Too many QTE events. I hate them.
- After Lara is impaled or hurt, she forgets about it after the minute. Wolverine would envy her healing ability.
- Skulls, dead bodies, piles of corpses everywhere. How many people died on that island?  Few hundred thousand? A milion?
- Tons of continuity errors. If you drop something heavy and it makes a hole into concrete floor, you jump inside to find, that the big heavy object just dissapeared.
- Music and sound design are mediocre at best.
- Zero replayability.
- Ending is just unexpectedly bad. All is foreshadowed in second half of a game. No surprises, nothing. Who wrote this story anyway, bunch of teenagers? I was expecting some twist or something.

For 5 bucks it is OK.

I hope that sequels are better.

Lara is introduced as an unexperienced adventurer, although the way she picks up after being shipwrecked and thrown on an unforgiven island is feral. Survival is right. Despite open wounds she wades through waist-high baths of blood and guts. One would expect her to have raging fevers as one moment she dashes through volcanic caves and the next she’s climbing a radio tower that sways dangerously in a snow storm. So, scratch that former remark—this is no survival, it’s mythical. While her diligent band of cardboard friends struggles to find important things to do, she risks her life every single minute. That is, of course, how Lara ‘Grave Robber’ Croft came to be – as the first true female video game hero – but why, then, would the writers cast her in this at times toe-curling, teeth grinding fantastical pseudo-realistic-American-soap-like plot? Was it the contemporary fad of rehashing the heroes of old (e.g. Batman) in an emotional and profoundly human way? If we, one can hear the developers assert, salten Lara’s adventure with themes of loss, maternity, insanity, mass murder and resurrection, we surely will learn more about her, understand her, [i]care[/i] for her? 

The beauty of the first games was the fact that the introduction to the player was neutral and short, providing just enough incentive to become Lara. [b]In this reboot we are never Lara, merely the page-turners of her pre-written adventure[/b] - which wouldn't be that bad if the writing was engaging. But [b]the story is troubled with too many ideas and too little focus[/b], and I did not care about any cutscene, journal or conversation (except maybe for the sake of being a completionist, which is no accomplishment on the developers’ part). 

Nevertheless, [b]I actually enjoyed the gameplay very much[/b]. As with in all probability the entirety of the former Tomb Raider games, and similar third person (acrobatic) adventure games like the Assassin’s Creed series, it is troubled with moments of utter frustration, whenever there is a discrepancy between how you want to control the character, and how this gets interpreted by the game engine. Fortunately, this is not as common as in some parts of the aforementioned series. [b]Overall the movement is fluent[/b] (though their animations sometimes leave something to be desired), the input-to-control ratio is up to par, the weapon handling and ammo switching are good. And, above all, stealth is a welcome and well-implemented, albeit at times glitchy, addition.

Autosaves are frequent (at times too frequent even), and any kind of statistical progress is, as is common in this genre, saved immediately. 

[b]The skills that can be unlocked are usually ungratifying[/b]. It really is okay; it spices up the gameplay a little, but only a handful of skills actually give you an idea of improvement; these are mostly included in the brawling and weapon upgrade trees, adding new moves or types of ammo.

[b]Graphically, Tomb Raider is quite pretty and very well optimized[/b]. The atmosphere is arguably the best in the series, and the level design is rather good as well, as long as you don’t care too much about examining every nook and cranny. It obviously has been designed for a linear playthrough, turning the completionists’ endeavour into a galling burden.

[b]Verdict: Until the Tetanus DLC is here, or Lara learns to shipwreck in more distinctive company, Tomb Raider earns a mere 'mediocre'.[/b]

What can I say about this reboot of the iconic video game franchise? Well, let me start by saying that as a fan of the original series, I was skeptical about this new take on Lara Croft. But, after playing through the game and taking in all of its elements, I have to admit that this is a damn fine entry in the series.

Let's start with the story. Tomb Raider 2012 takes us back to the beginning of Lara Croft's journey, showing us how she became the confident, badass explorer that we all know and love. The story is well-written and keeps you engaged throughout, with plenty of action, drama, and twists to keep you on your toes. The character development is also top-notch, with Lara going through some serious trials and tribulations that really test her resolve.

As for the gameplay, Tomb Raider 2012 is a great blend of exploration, puzzle-solving, and action. The game is full of secrets to uncover, puzzles to solve, and enemies to take down. The combat is fast-paced and visceral, with plenty of weapons and upgrades to keep things fresh. The controls are tight and responsive, making for a satisfying experience overall.

But what really sets Tomb Raider 2012 apart is its presentation. The game looks absolutely stunning, with gorgeous environments, realistic character models, and impressive effects. The music and sound design are also top-notch, adding to the overall immersion of the experience.

In conclusion, Tomb Raider 2012 is a fantastic reboot of the series that manages to capture the spirit of the original games while updating them for a modern audience. The story, gameplay, and presentation are all top-notch, making this a must-play for fans of the franchise and newcomers alike

[h1]A mysterious island full of environmental puzzles, intense combat and tombs to explore[/h1]

[i]Tomb Raider GOTY Edition[/i] is a third-person action, adventure video game developed by pioneering American developer 🇺🇸, Crystal Dynamics, who has been commissioned to develop every [i]Tomb Raider[/i] game since 2006.

With energetic combat and amazing tombs to discover across a mysterious island, this title [b]gives a second reboot[/b] to the life of Lara Croft as we knew her before, and takes her to the edge of her possibilities with this [b]new proposal that tells her origins[/b] from a different perspective.

In this revamped instalment, we take on the role of the young and innocent Lara Croft, who has just graduated with top honours from Cambridge University in London, UK 🇬🇧. However, her eagerness to embark on her own adventure and make her mark on the archaeological world as her father, Richard Croft, did, leads her to take an expedition to the end of the world to the Dragon Triangle in southern Japan 🇯🇵 in search of the location of a lost civilisation known as the Yamatai.

The Game of the Year Edition version of the video game, which is more like a bundle in itself, brings with it all the DLC released to date for [i]Tomb Raider[/i] in 2013, including the [i]Tomb Raider: 1939 Multiplayer Map Pack[/i] and [i]Tomb of the Lost Adventure[/i] DLCs. The latter allows us to unlock and explore an additional tomb, but without the possibility of getting a later achievement by looting it.

In total, [b]21 DLCs are added to the base game[/b], but nothing new is added, such as graphical improvements or a rebalancing of the combat system. A release that, rather than saticfastoria, was a mere whim on Square Enix's part to highlight the fact that the title has been awarded and pressed by the press on many occasions.

[b]Score: 95[/b]

[b]Pros:[/b]
■ An amazing story-rich that takes us to the origin of Lara without further delay.
Three difficulty modes that expand the length of the story.
■ Most comprehensive collectibles list in the entire series (100 in total).
■ Survival instinct is original and profitable at all times.
■ Realistic graphics that take advantage of new technologies.
■ An exceptional soundtrack and outstanding sound effects.
■ Camilla Luddington's performance as Lara Croft is excellent.

[b]Cons:[/b]
■ The GOTY version of the title doesn't come with any relevant extra content to make you want to pay for it in the first place.
■ Extremely short campaign to finish (between 15-20 hours).
■ A Very limited weapon list.
■ Aiming is weak on a few firearms, making them difficult to use.
■ Few challenges when exploring tombs with negligible rewards.
■ A New Game would have increased the replayability of the title.

Here are some reasons to play Tomb Raider 2013:

It's a reboot of the classic Tomb Raider franchise, but this time Lara Croft isn't just a pair of pixelated boobs with guns - she's a realistic, relatable, and badass character who you'll love to play as.

You get to see Lara grow from a scared and vulnerable survivor to a confident and skilled adventurer. It's like watching your little sister become a superhero, except with more bow and arrow action.

The graphics are stunning - seriously, you'll be blown away by the lush environments and detailed character models. It's like going on a virtual vacation, except with more murder.

The puzzles are challenging, but not so hard that you'll want to throw your controller at the wall. Plus, solving them makes you feel like a genius, even if you had to look up the answer online.

There's a ton of exploration to do, and you can spend hours just wandering around the island, searching for hidden treasures and artifacts. It's like playing an Indiana Jones game, but with more wolves.

The combat is intense and satisfying, especially when you pull off a headshot with your trusty bow. It's like playing a game of darts, except the dart board is a guy's face.

Lara's death scenes are hilariously gruesome - you'll laugh, you'll cringe, and you'll wonder how she manages to survive half the stuff that happens to her. It's like playing a game of Operation, except the patient is Lara Croft and you're using guns instead of tweezers.

The story is gripping and emotional, and it will keep you on the edge of your seat until the very end. It's like watching an action movie, except you're the one controlling the action.

There's a lot of replayability, with different difficulty levels and challenge modes to keep you coming back for more. It's like eating a bag of chips - you tell yourself you're just going to have one, but before you know it, the whole bag is empty.

Did I mention the wolves? Seriously, there are so many wolves. If you love killing wolves, this game is for you. If you hate killing wolves, this game is still for you, because it's really satisfying when you kill them.

Best tomb raider game in the series

This game was my entry point into the series and a delightful experience overall.

Tomb Raider is an action-adventure game that serves as the reboot of the series focusing on how Lara transforms from a young and inexperienced archeology graduate into a hardened and capable explorer, unafraid to kill as a means to survive.

Lara embarks on a journey to find a long-forgotten empire of Yamatai. Her ship is destroyed by a storm and her team gets separated. They fight for their survival and uncover the island's secrets, revealing the ancient curse that had trapped them on the island with the Solarii cultists. The team has to find and save each other and break the curse to get off the island.

The graphics of this game are dated by now but some of the locations are beautiful nonetheless. In combination with the soundtrack, a lot of locations made for an amazing atmosphere.

Gameplay is from 3rd personal point of view and involves quite a bit of gunfights, puzzles, some collectibles, and an interesting traversal of the environment that will have you do a lot of climbing and running. It should be noted that this game has no small amount of cinematic moments and will have you running from falling caves and desperately trying not to die using quick time events on several occasions. Some people might find those very cool and enjoyable but I personally don't really like those. The game is structured into several hubs with their own tombs and collectibles. Each of the hubs has a map to be found, which reveals the locations of places and collectibles. All areas also have a few campfires that are used for upgrading weapons and learning new skills. The exploration of some areas is obstructed by various blockages for which you will need special gear that can be acquired by progressing the story. 

Puzzles are found all throughout the game, some in tombs, some to get you through the story, and even small ones that make simple looting more interesting.

The game offers 5 weapon types: Bows, Pistols, Rifles, Shotguns, and Melee. Each can be upgraded using salvage. Some weapons are found, given to Lara, or crafted from weapon parts. One thing to be noted here is that the weapon parts seem to be part structured and part randomized and you will want to loot all enemies to collect all of them which might be frustrating for some.

In conclusion, it is definitely a good game, worth playing, especially when being very often on discount.  8/10

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a Virtual Youtuber empire for over a year now and using me as his recruiter. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my Live2D knowledge to recruit talents, which he would then hire using his connections in the Japanese utaite world. Connections that he made through his career with Niconico. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small indie channel could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Motoaki "Yagoo" Tanigo, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Yagoo threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Yagoo had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Yagoo flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Yagoo was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Riku Tazumi , he plotted to kill Yagoo, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Cover Corp, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my vtubing activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

This was my first Tomb Raider game, and boy was it a fun one.

This game is an origin story for Lara Croft. She's not yet the tomb-raiding, dual pistol-wielding badass heroine we know her as, but rather an innocent and inexperienced adventurer on a journey to a mysterious island in the Pacific. Without getting into spoilers, things go awry during the journey and Lara and her compatriots end up getting stranded on the island and soon discover their arrival on the island was more than an accident. 

The gameplay is divided between shooting, some light platforming, and exploration. You'll be doing all three in fairly equal measure, although some parts of the game will put more of an emphasis on one than the other. The shooting feels pretty good and you're given plenty of cool and useful upgrades for your weapons to better dispatch anything that gets in your way. The platforming is fun and definitely reminds me of the climbing and jumping in Uncharted 2. There are a few moments where it seems like there's some invisible force helping you make long jumps and guiding you towards ledges and hand-holds, and some of the animations are a bit janky, but overall your options for traversal are quite varied. Speaking of Uncharted, the game takes more than a few pages out of Uncharted's book - which isn't necessarily a bad thing seeing as the OG Tomb Raider games likely inspired the Uncharted series - when it comes to action sequences, which the game has in spades. Lastly, the exploration rewards the careful and patient gamer with upgrades, diary entries that flesh out the characters and story, and other special goodies. There's a fairly well-implemented fast travel system but it doesn't always let you go to the area you need to go to, rather the closest checkpoint to it. So be ready to do a bit of travelling on foot.

Now, I know that the term "ludonarrative dissonance" gets tossed around quite frequently these days, but the game does suffer from this quite a bit. While Lara is scarred by the many acts of violence she witnesses (and later has to commit in order to survive) she begins to become such a brutal killer by the end of the game that you wouldn't be wrong if you begun to believe she got some sick enjoyment out of it. There are some late-game kill and takedown animations that would fit into any Gears of War or Manhunt title. As well, Lara takes quite the beating throughout the game, sustaining any number of life-threatening injuries. After a while it almost becomes silly to see how many times she survives something that should have gotten her killed, only for her to just get up, brush off the dust and blood, and keep going. It's a minor gripe, but one that kept rearing its head throughout my 15-hour playthrough.

Overall, if you're a fan of action games (or movies) and like exploring, shooting, and climbing, you'll almost certainly love Tomb Raider. While some of the animations might feel off and the game's mechanics can clash with the story, it's still a fitting reboot for one of gaming's most iconic and recognizable names.

Tomb Raider is an excellent adventure game that brings a fresh new take to the classic franchise. The game's graphics and sound design are impressive, with stunningly detailed environments and sound effects that bring the game's world to life. The game's mechanics are well-designed, with a good balance of exploration, puzzle-solving, and combat that keeps the game engaging throughout. The game's story is also captivating, with a well-written narrative that follows Lara Croft's journey to survive on a mysterious island and uncover its secrets. Overall, Tomb Raider is a must-play for anyone who loves adventure games and wants a game with a well-crafted story, engaging gameplay, and an immersive world.

Previous, classic Tomb Raider games are challenging, but not so difficult that you find yourself raging while playing it. This game is extremely hard even on "normal" difficulty. After getting most of the way through the game I found myself saying out loud "this isn't even fun anymore" like 3 or 4 times. I'm not a cozy gamer, so I can take a little difficulty and will do parts over and over if I have to until I get it right but this is genuinely insane. I can see why it wasn't a hit.

a fantastic reintroduction to a legendary character. 

the story is exactly what you'd expect and better from a lara croft game- plot twists, unsolved mysteries and lots of action. there are tons of secrets and extra details to be found, and you will never run out of things to explore. the origin story in this game is particularly well made, i like how it shows lara's struggles and doubts as she pushes herself to unleashing her full potential, which is something we rarely see nowadays in newer hero/action media. 

the characters are very multi-dimensional, each with their own unique quirks. lara is mild-mannered yet bold, reckless yet careful and timid yet fearless. this is so far my favourite version of the character, as she feels much more "human" via the showcase of her internal struggles.

the environment is beautiful, it was ahead of its time. the whole island is so immersive and brimming with secrets, you could still have a good time spending hours wandering around the island without any missions. 

the gameplay is phenomenal. the traversal never feels stiff, though i wish there was an option to sprint. the combat surprisingly does not get repetitive despite the lack of variety in terms of close-range attacks. the puzzles also are fairly challenging and require a bit of thought. 

overall a very good game that did and continues to do justice to the icon that is lara croft.

So, I do like this game. Or I was planning on liking this game. The plot seems good, the controls are nice and fluid and the visuals are really good, even in 2023. However - I absolutely resent that the player is required to hunt and kill animals for food. This completely ruins the game for me. There should be an option to either turn this off for players who do not want to kill animals or a foresting mode for vegan and vegetarian players. 

Requiring Lara to kill animals carries a hint of right wing survivalist propaganda. It would entirely feasible for Lara to conveniently retain a pack of canned food or something. Or just not really worry about a diet element to the game. I also believe that someone as well trained and accomplished as Lara would be able to find non-meat food, like plants or whatever. Besides, since this is a video game there could be nut protein or whatever else. There is no real reason to require the player to kill animals and I hate that this is a part of this game. 

A shame, too, because it was seeming really good. I will probably play it through and remind myself that it's just a game. But still. A major turn off. Can't give this a good review because of that.

tomb raider is a third person action-adventure game developed by crystal dynamics and published by square enix limited, a european branch of square enix, in march of 2013. it's the 10th tomb raider game and acts as a reboot of the series, and also acting as the first part of the 'survivor trilogy' that came to be after the successful release. the purpose of the reboot was to re-establish the origins of lara croft, so in this game she is just a young archeology graduate. i really enjoyed the plot of this game and i can't wait to get into rise of the tomb raider just to continue the story. it's well-written and incredibly well-done. the one thing i had a 'problem' (if you can even call it that) is how fast lara transforms into a hardened killer capable of taking out multiple enemies at once.

gameplay is third person action-adventure, so you know what the gameplay is mostly gonna be like, but the fact there's survival elements, and uncharted-like combat, and even minor rpg elements makes this game unique enough to stand apart from competition as a really solid gameplay experience. the graphics are great, even though i'm making this review in february 2023, a month away from 10 years after the release, the graphics are high-quality and they really gave lara croft great characterization. the setting is great, i really enjoyed the myths and mysteries of the island. now that full price is only $15, you can still get this for 75-85% off, which is an absolute steal for one of the best series reboots of all time. i definitely reccomend waiting for a sale because getting this for around $3 is an insane value.

this is nothing like the 'old' tombraider games, no old tombs and killing puzzles which could take hours but only a bit of exploring and climbing, little 'tomb' here and there (nothing difficult, just lift this, put this here etc) then a fight out, this repeats throughout the game o and lets not forget the 'o god i am sliding down a path with impossible to dodge obstacles' which is just made almost impossible to do to toughen up the game.  entertaining but no tomb raider. before the end i just quit. one can upgrade the bow, guns etc but then the enemy's get harder too head shots don't matter, 5 burning arrows in a dude with plain clothes but does'nt die, 4-5 close shotgun rounds? too no avail, they have machine guns, dynamite and they just keep on coming etc etc the weapon upgrades do not make a difference at all and the fight outs just get so damn hard. shame though i would love to have seen the end of the game, but nah. when i am scolding and shouting, out of frustration, while doing something i love then there is something wrong with the game. i will go back to elden ring or the witcher 3 for my exploring and difficulty craving

Tomb Raider is a top-notch action-adventure game that truly stands out in its genre. The game's graphics are breathtaking and bring to life the lush and dangerous environments that Lara Croft must navigate. From the dense jungles to the crumbling ruins, each level is full of detail and life. The game's combat system is also top-notch, offering a variety of weapons and tactics to use in battle against both human and supernatural enemies.

Additionally, the game features challenging puzzles that require players to think creatively and use their problem-solving skills. These puzzles are seamlessly integrated into the overall experience and add an extra layer of depth to the game.

Lara Croft herself is a standout character, and the game does an excellent job of exploring her backstory and development over the course of the game. Players will feel a strong connection to her as she grows from a novice adventurer into a seasoned tomb raider.

One of the most epic games ive ever played. It was so much fun that i even remastered this game 3 times. Its worth playing. Suspense,action,friendship,adventure, you name it all and you'll get it. Plus the multiplayer option is like a cherry on a cake.

**The good**
- The graphics are nice (even I couldn't play it on ultra on my Steam Deck because of some framerate drops)
- The music fits totally with the adventure.
- The gameplay is good and fun and the only that I can criticize is the camera, too shaky and a pain a lot of times.

**The bad**
- The plot is boring, non-catchy at all, full of absurd and cliché moments, characters are irrelevant and totally forgettable.
- Tombs are great but short and simple.
- Multiplayer achievements (really??!!! I hate this!)
 
**Conclusion**

To be honest, I have some fun playing this. I think it is a good reboot for Tomb Raider but I feel that it could be so much better. 
I hope they learned and made 'Rise' and 'Shadow' of the Tomb Raider great games after this one!

[code]MY RATING:	✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔	10 / 10[/code]

The Tomb Raider series has been through a lot during its existence, but in 2013, Crystal Dynamics said it would release the game ... Tomb Raider... (reboot). Which should provide the series with modern gameplay and a better story, but how did the fans take this reboot ?

[b]How did Lara become an adventurer?[/b]

In this installment, Lara is no longer a seasoned adventurer as we know her, here she is just a teenage girl searching for an area near Japan, which according to myths should be known as the Devil's Triangle, which was once held by the ruler of the world, but as things stand, when Lara sailed into this area, causing her ship to split in two, leaving Lara on her own. As a teenage girl who had never encountered such conditions in the city, it was not easy for her to find her way around and survive. But after a while, she does it (almost) on her own. After some time, he finds his friends and this is where things get a little messed up. Lara discovers that the local "citizen" Mathias wants to use her friend to rebirth the local queen. Which honestly... reviving the dead isn't the best thing to do. So you will try to prevent him from doing this, but your path will be full of obstacles.

[b]Great and unique Gameplay[/b]

This part has its own new elements in terms of Adventure games, the classic gameplay from the original games just wouldn't stand up. So the creators made a new one, along with elements that just fit like cogs in a machine. Apart from the fact that you have classic climbing controls, this part can appeal to you with its arsenal, not only of weapons, but also of skills. At each camp, you have the option to upgrade your weapons with whatever parts you find, or upgrade Lara's own abilities, and honestly, what's better than teaching Lara to take a handful of sand, throw it in someone's face, and then jam an Ice Ax into their knee... Ouch . You have 3 skill trees to choose from and each of them is worth something, combat, survival or just being creative with raw materials and crafting. From an ordinary Bow, you can work your way up to a Shotgun or a Submachine Gun, which you then turn into an Assault Rifle... how? I don't know, but it's divine! Long story short, this part gives you so many options to play and even more opportunities to play the game your way (Except for a few passages).

[b]So... is it worth it ?[/b]

I will not list the optimization here, if only for the reason that this game is almost 10 years old, so everyone can play it. But I have to say that this first game of the new series is my favorite and every year I return to it with enthusiasm and amazing zeal, because I know what awaits me in the game and I enjoy every playthrough of the game, it's one of the things that you you will never get bored, as this part has a lot to offer for the way it was made, and you can only benefit from it. I actually played this game for the first time when I was about 12 years old, so I have a really special bond with this game, and I hope I'm not alone. The Tomb Raider series is simply heartwarming, and anyone who has never tried it doesn't even know how much fun they're missing out on. There is hardly any episode that I didn't like from this series, and I can warmly recommend this episode and by extension the whole series, enjoy it and see you in the tomb.

[b]MY PROS AND CONS[/b]

✔ Nice graphics
✔ Well written story
✔ Unique and Inspirating Gameplay
✔ Great Optimization

✘ Occasionally confused controls when jumping over ledges

Tomb Raider is a reboot of the series that started in 1996, and it was the best game in the franchise until its successor. This game got a lot of its inspiration from the Uncharted series, which, in turn, drank heavily from Tomb Raider itself. So, we've come full circle here.

I was never a fan of the original TR series. I understand the importance of the games, and they were certainly impressive at the time. However, tank controls, strange shooting and strangely designed dungeons kept me from having a good experience with the games, in spite of their technical feats. This reboot corrects all of these problems: controls are generally great, combat is a lot more engaging and the dungeons (or areas) are much better to navigate, while maintaining the spirit of exploration the series is known for. Even better that the story is kind of nice, and the development of Lara as the protagonist is really well done. The developers clearly tried to give a cinematic presentation for the game, but cutscenes never outstay their welcome. Puzzles are great, not really difficult to figure out, but some are challenging enough that it feels like a victory when you crack them.

There is good content in the game, with a lot of collectibles and side missions to do; however, after finishing the game, I felt very little inclined to come back and complete it. I believe they don't offer enough incentives for completionists, but I can hardly blame the game for it, as it's just a matter of opinion.

I recommend this game, but try to get it on a sale, as the game becomes dirty cheap, making it an even better deal.

After I optimized it, Tomb Raider was an enjoyable experience. Fun gameplay, with a special emphasis on the bow and collecting parts - reminiscent of The Last of Us. Enemies are aggressive, constantly pressing you, often trying to flank. 

There are many different weapons to use (each of which can be upgraded) along with improvements for things like melee. What also impressed me about the game were the various set pieces, often topping those found in the Uncharted series.

A few negatives do bring the game down from GOTY contention. The story while conceptually interesting (think Uncharted 1), is littered with stereotypical characters and some uninspiring voice acting and one too many cliches - watching these cutscenes is not my idea of fun. 

Lara's 'development' into a survivor is highly unrealistic, feeling more like a switch and than an earned status. And tbh the ending was underwhelming and highly forgettable - AAA developers always to conclude things.

Overall, would recommend the game. Lots of fun, looks pretty and good value for the money. But it is hardly one of the best games of 2013, especially in the category of survival horror like Last of Us. It's a functional reboot of the Tomb Raider series.
the story is indisputably amazing, the game-play and graphics are great despite it being a 10 year old game. so many childhood memories brought back. definitely recommend playing.

A must play for fans of action/adventure games.
Tomb Raider mixes survival, puzzle, loot, combat and platforming with a system of weapon, tool and skill upgrades.

The main quest is excellent, the atmosphere of the game is very dark and immersive with sometimes a quite oppressive side. There are also optional areas and relics to find. The fights are also very satisfying thanks to the different weapons and tools you can use.

I had played this game at the time on Xbox 360 and recently redone on PC, the game has aged well and can run well on any current computer.

In conclusion, this is a game that I absolutely recommend to anyone looking for a single player game with excellent gameplay and a very good story for a very generous price.

El único coleccionable divertido son las tumbas opcionales, el resto son muy aburridos y poco interesantes en general. Aún así este juego lo recomiendo, es una muy grata experiencia y vale mucho la pena por todo lo que mencioné anteriormente.

Square Enix's take on Uncharted, the new Tomb Raider game focus a lot more on creating a third person survival experience with much more casual platforming than the original series. Using a bow, stealth takedown to kill enemies quietly, improving your gear and abilities.

It's also one of those games where stealth actions are much more rewarded than overt one, so anything else than stealth is making the game harder for you.

Overall a fantastic breath of fresh air for the Tomb Raider series that had stagnated for a long time.

A Fun Time, Worth Spending Some More Time In

I had a fun time hunting for the various loot, becoming a badass and learning to waste clowns that wanted to kill me. Some buzzkilling moments when I felt like the game was railroading me (like several sequences where I was jumping off exploding platforms or sliding down waterways) and if I didn't do exactly what it wanted, it killed me. 

Some very cinematic, even beautiful moments. Overall, a worthwhile game.

I've finished this game so don't mind the hours played. It's a fun game, just hopelessly average. I've played plenty Lara Croft games, but the early 2010s obsession with realism and gritty themes don't suit her. The series has always been about escapism -  a way to play out the camp of the 90s Bond films but with a female lead - yet all that is absent here. Naughty Dog cribbed that and made the stellar Uncharted games, while Tomb Raider 2013 decided to experiment around. Thematically I found it perplexing that the story seems intent on showing how Lara struggles with murder and survival while at the same time making her into literal death machine in the player's hands. 

Gameplay wise - it's fine. The puzzles are interesting and well-placed within the confines of its world, the combat is serviceable, there's some lite RPG mechanics to give a sense of progression. My gripes boil down to story - how it's told, what it's trying to tell. Telling, considering the later sequels to this game further alienates me from this franchise. 

In short, I simply don't enjoy this game as much as I want to and wished it was a completely different game. Which is unfair criticism towards it to be frank. I'm sure some people would be happy to play this version of Lara. Humanised, realistic, expressing reasonable human reactions towards being shipwrecked on a mythical island with eerie temples. And more power to you! I just feel like my interest in this series would only be reignited upon a proper remake of Tomb Raider Legend.

This is my second time playing and was my first introduction to Tomb Raider, and overall the game is still rewarding. My fist time was on the XBOX so graphically there is a huge improvement on PC. While visuals definitely show their ages in places, especially with distant visuals, the game still looks pretty good. I'm running on an RTX 3080 and Ryzen 7 5800X, and there were a few cases of stutter and freezing later in the game, and a few places where Lara would glitch around the geometry in comical ways, but overall the game ran fairly smooth. 

Game play and controls are easy to get into, and the feeling is very similar to the Uncharted Games. While it lacks the humor and lightheartedness of Uncharted, TR is not afraid to delve into darker and more grotesque places. After wading through piles of bodies and body parts, you start wondering if Lara Croft has some serious issues, because she handles those situations too well considering this is her first adventure. Then again the acting and dialogue are just okay, so perhaps its better Square Enix did not attempt a more realistic response. There are a few cases I felt the dialogue was a little cliche and melodramatic. A lot of the characters and their motives are very obvious, yet all still remains a mystery to Lara. That might be the downside of reading through every journal in an otherwise very scripted game. 

I would say the only areas of the game that show its age in an unwelcome way are the boss fights that overly rely on cinematic and quick time events. Best example is the final boss where you get the hang of staying close, dodging, and attacking, and then everything gets bungled after missing a QTE. By the end of the game, enemies begin to feel sort of "bullet spongy". How many head/face shots does it take to bring an enemy down? The use of slow motion in many sequences is also somewhat unwelcome, but perhaps all that slow motion is where the game finds its humor. 

I would say TR is solid 6.5/7 out of 10. Worth playing if you need a break between longer and more intense games and or just want to get back into the series.

Tomb Raider is an action-adventure game that follows the story of Lara Croft, a young and ambitious archaeologist who sets out on a journey to uncover the secrets of an ancient civilization. The game is a reboot of the popular series and it offers a fresh take on the character.

One of the things I loved about this game is the level design. Each level feels unique and offers a lot of exploration opportunities. The environments are beautifully rendered and the attention to detail is impressive. The game also features a variety of puzzles that are challenging but not impossible to solve.

The combat system is also well-done. Lara has a variety of weapons and abilities at her disposal, and the game gives players the freedom to approach combat situations in different ways. The stealth mechanics are particularly well-done, allowing players to take a more stealthy approach if they so choose.

The story is also engaging, and it keeps you hooked from start to finish. It offers a lot of twists and turns, and it explores Lara's personal growth as a character. The voice acting and motion capture are excellent, making the characters feel alive and relatable.

Overall, I would highly recommend Tomb Raider to fans of the series and newcomers alike. It's a fantastic game that offers a lot of variety in gameplay, beautiful environments, and an engaging story. It's a game that kept me hooked from start to finish, and it's one that I will definitely replay in the future.

It's important to play this game with a controller, as the game play is not geared towards a keyboard and mouse experience at all.

It's a short game that won't take you very long to finish, but that keeps the action more densely packed. It took me 10 hours -- around 2 days of moderately heavy playing to finish (with a 69% completion rate, according to the game).

Tomb Raider remains a very playable game in 2023. The graphics are a little better on Ultimate in 4K, but are one of the game's weaknesses compared to its newer peers. The facial animations aren't as convincing as in other titles like Uncharted 4 or the Assassin's Creed games, but the voice acting and story arc are believable.

The gameplay is great, with a good number of problems/obstacles that you work out with only a few tools. You can customize your weapons as you progress, and develop different skills in the order you want. It's really a matter of what you want to prioritize, since by the end of the game, you should have nearly all the perks leveled up.  

The stealth aspect is probably one of the game's stronger suits. 

If you enjoyed the Uncharted franchise, you should definitely take a look at this game.

UPDATED REVIEW (THUMBS DOWN):
DO NOT BUY! 
A badly executed update to add support for Epic Game Store (i.e. selling out to Chinese Tencent corporation money) has had the side effect of breaking the game.
The game has been broken since 2021-10-19, resulting in significant parts of the HUD being displayed offscreen.
Two subsequent updates (both for Epic Game Store issues) - last one a whole year later in Sept 2022 - have NOT addressed this issue. 
In other words: Square Enix is fuilfilling some $$$ contract to support the Epic Game Store - while blatently ignoring/breaking everything else about the game.
The only solution is to select old BETA BUILD version 743 in the Steam game properties.
If they ever purge the old beta builds, the game will become unplayable.

ORIGINAL REVIEW (THUMBS UP):
This game doesn't get old for me - I find myself revisiting this game every year or so.
Taking my time the campaign on Hard is about 20h... and none of it boring even after the 5th or so playthough.

Nothing on the old games. The story is there, but the repetitive moves, the never ending 'mash the buttons to not die' sections and the horrible combat situations mean this is less tomb raider, and more of an elaborate corridor shooter.

The level up system seems a bit misplaced, the puzzles are too easy.

There are moments of great enjoyment in this game, which are then cut short and ruined by the shooting sections and the quick-time action events. Shame!

The game is dated and the Multiplayer is non-existant, the biggest knock against the game is ultimately that it feels a bit torture porn-y, especially at the start where it really goes out of its way to shit all over Lara and physically kick the hell out of her at every available opportunity.

Laying that aside, that only lasts a brief period, it doesn't take Lara long to turn into the terminator and go full on murder machine. 

The story's decent, good action popcorn entertainment.

If I had another choice other than yes/no.. I'd give it an ok for game play but it has a terrible/idiotic story and some really pathetic 'physics' puzzles. the story is full of contradictions, and useless 'story arcs'. for instance in the intro she comes off as some confident, well researched, 'hero type', but as soon as something starts to get hard, she starts crying that she "cant do that" or "its all too much for me".. and just about everyone she tries to 'save'.. dies or is severely injured.. because she is off wandering in a random tomb that she finds along the way!! its so bad its cringe worthy! then there is the combat.. she gets stuck with one bit of metal and she passes out.. but gets riddled with holes from combat and is perfectly fine! if the devs are going to allow the protagonist to take brutal  beatings (where she is literally riddled with bullets and has massive falls that no one would ever survive!).. dont weave a story that she is some dainty flower that faints over a grass cut and cant take the pressure of 'life and death' situations! its just plain stupid.

other than that, if you can 'get past the setting and the pathetic story'.. its an ok play through.

Tomb Raider 2013 is a fun, interesting, unique entry in the Tomb Raider franchise. Despite being 9 years old, the game is still visually stunning today, with stellar graphics & exceptional level design. The game also has good pacing, survival elements & multiplayer. The multiplayer is decent, but not amazing. There's a small group of people that do multiplayer, so multiplayer is still possible.

The game does have tombs, but a lot of the gameplay revolves around Lara's origins & the survival elements like collecting scrap, killing enemies & hunting. Plus, the game has good character development, having an interesting story wherein you get to learn about Lara's origins & see her develop, mature, & progress towards the beloved character we know her as today. Overall, Tomb Raider 2013 is a polished, very well-done action-adventure game that I highly recommend.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Story: 1/10 truly terrible. Super predictable.

Characters: 1/10 truly terrible. Just a bunch of tropes

Gameplay: Short platforming and/or puzzle section. Short shooting section. Long set-piece section full of bullshit QTEs that will account for 95% of your deaths. Rinse and repeat.

Gunplay: 3/10. Guns feel like laser guns with RNG spray patterns. Very unsatisfying to use

Platforming: 5/10. Floaty and underwhelming

Puzzles: 5/10. Some make you think hard while others are just plain bizarre.

Progression system: other than passive buffs to your weaponry, there's not much there. At least nothing that will really change up your gameplay.

Replay value: 1/10. Beat this game way back in 2014. Came back to play it in 2022 and quit after a few hours, asking myself "Why?"

My name's James.
Last year, I found out that there was a tumor in my head and I underwent chemotherapy many times to treat the tumor.
One day I got tired of all the chemotherapy and trying to survive.
I said to myself that there is nothing in the world that I want to live for
Until one day my friend Jesse gave me this game as a gift
I wanted to not accept the game
But I accidentally accepted the game
I installed the game and played it for a few minutes and I realized that I like it and until today I have played it for more than a hundred hours
This game made me try to survive and now the doctor told me that chemotherapy has destroyed the tumor and I will survive.
Thank you Jesse, you are my best friend and your gift was the best thing that happened in my life.

Another thing that really ... surprised me ... was the incredible amount of gore. Never played any Tomb Raider game until just now. Steam recommend this game to me and i saw that this and the 2 follow up games were on sale. I got all 3 for like $22. Figured it was a steal and worth a try. 

I just finished the first game (14 hours). I really enjoyed it and look forward to starting Rise of the Tomb Raider next. I really have zero complaints about it. The game was fun, engaging and kept me hooked. I liked the areas, platforming and puzzles. I dont like games that have overly difficult puzzles or platforming. This game's were fairly simple which im a fan of. It was a very linear game (which im also a fan of). Open world is over hyped. Other than going back to prior areas to get missing collectibles, there isnt much point (which was fine). 

I enjoyed Lara's voice actor. 

PC games are well know to run poorly and have stability issues. This game is not one of them. I never crashed once. The only bug i had was some of the tool tips at the lower right hand part of the screen were a tiny bit cutoff. Other than being a visual bug, it really did not matter whatsoever. 

I would definitely recommend this game. Excited to see how the next two play out.

My name's James.
Last year, I found out that there was a tumor in my head and I underwent chemotherapy many times to treat the tumor.
One day I got tired of all the chemotherapy and trying to survive.
I said to myself that there is nothing in the world that I want to live for
Until one day my friend Jesse gave me this game as a gift
I wanted to not accept the game
But I accidentally accepted the game
I installed the game and played it for a few minutes and I realized that I like it and until today I have played it for more than a hundred hours
This game made me try to survive and now the doctor told me that chemotherapy has destroyed the tumor and I will survive.
Thank you Jesse, you are my best friend and your gift was the best thing that happened in my life.

The game that made a spectacular return of the greatest videogame heroine of all time.A sensational reboot of Lara Croft into the gaming world. This game is an action packed thriller with explosive set-pieces and a storyline to root for. The Lara Croft we know is absent. Long gone the duel wield weaponry and the unbeatable killer machine of a women we love, instead we get a timid and frightened young lady who is stranded in a japan-ish bermuda triangle. Hunting for her life are the fanatics led by an intriguing character named Mathias who wants to resurrect the fabled Sun Queen who used to rule the world ages ago. However, Lara is not alone in her journey, she has her mentor & friend along with her best friend Sam and a group of rag tag explorers. The atmosphere is beautiful and horrific at the same time. Equally, gorgeous is the lead heroine Lara, who instead of over-sexualized in previous games, is depicted as an average explorer who when faced with the mortal dangers quickly sprangs into action. Camilla Ludington the voice of Lara has done an amazing job! The puzzles are few but very intelligent and realistic, Lara dont have to push a button to solve everything like in past, here she has to manipulate surroundings in order to solve the puzzles. This game is amazing, I have already played in 24 times. After playing its sequel (Rise of Tomb Raider) and the series finale (Shadow of Tomb Raider) I conclude that this one is by far the most superior of the trilogy. For Lara worshipper like me it was a mandatory game to play, however I would encourage every action/adventure lover out there to try this amazing masterpiece.

This game is so frustrating because of the many glitch!!!!!!!!!! I really want to like this game, but the damn glitch made me stuck countless times, and I have to watch Lara died again and again!!!!! The devs of this game is probably a sadist or have a sick fetish that like to watch woman die and suffer.

EDIT!!!
I have finally able to finished the game with 100% completion. And I really enjoy this game when it's not broke. There's a few place this game glitched on me, [spoiler] First one is right from the start when I swinging upside down, there's no other body hanging for me to push so I can't complete the puzzle. Turns out it glitched because I was rewriting the save slot I used before to start a new game. So this is solved by starting a new game with a new save slot.
Secondly, the most annoying glitch in this game is when Lara fight with the wolf! By seeing other people play this part on YouTube, I got to know that I can't finished this part because the game didn't give me the necessary prompt! There's this one prompt that is missing that should make Lara stab the wolf. This part is really annoying because I loss count on how many times I had to watch Lara died because the prompt didn't show like it had to. I tried changing the graphic quality, changing full screen on off like someone suggested, and somehow I finally got the prompt appear, after trying a few times. [/spoiler]
There are other glitch that I don't remember because it's minor or not as annoying as those two above. Over all I like this game and my only problem is the occasional annoying glitch and the gruesome death scene of Lara. if you don't mind those, then yes I would probably recommend this game.

This game has aged really well. It's still a lot of fun to go through the story as a whole, and the combat is fun once you know what your doing, and its well worth your time if your interested. I would recommend this game if you’re interested in the reboot trilogy and they are on sale. That said, this game has not aged great. It is pretty much what you would expect from a action game from 2013. Rustic tones, exhausting fighting sequences, everything exploding and getting destroyed seemingly for no reason and an unnecessary multiplayer mode which no one plays anymore so it is almost impossible to get the achievements unlocked. There’s also no new game+ which is disappointing after  the long process of leveling up perks and upgrading guns. No double pistols. :(

Collectibles are a one thing that this game does right. There isn’t an overbearing amount of them and I really enjoyed hearing more background story through the various journals and relics. The story isn’t half bad.

Now THIS is how you do a female protagonist correctly. Lara shows emotion, grieves over the deaths of others, starts rusty and turns into a badass, and she's hot. Everything nowadays try to go in the direction of a STRONG FEMALE character, instead of a STRONG female CHARACTER. This game does the latter option and it is better than all of that other stuff for that reason.
The gameplay is fun, but in my opinion, it's too repetitive. The game is very generous with it's ammo and you are able to upgrade your equipment, making it even more powerful. It isn't a bad thing, but it takes some of the challenge away.
The story is absolutely phenomenal, the characters are great, (fuck you Whitman) and the visuals are beautiful. But there is one thing that drags the story down, but it isn't something to do with the game itself.
"Did I ever tell you, what the definition, of insanity, is?"
Yeah, Far Cry 3 beat this game to the market by about 4 months, meaning that if someone plays this or that first, they will probably see the other as really similar, which I am experiencing right now. It's a real shame because the people involved with FC3 and TR really put their all into making a great game, only to have both games being compared to each other because of extremely similar ideas.

Overall, I do highly recommend this game for it's story and characters.

The 2013 incarnation of Tomb Raider is not perfect in any way, but it's exactly what I need and expect from a very solid adventure game. First of all, the world is very immersive, with the events we experience and the lore we find building an intriguing picture of the situation on the island we find ourselves in, and the events that led up to it. Character design was decent, as was voice acting, but unfortunately the dialogue writing was pretty uninspired, though luckily not terrible. The world is also designed very well - both realistic and aesthetically pleasing, with terrain variety reminescent of CoD 4. Traversing it is generally very pleasant, although climbing routes are way too obvious for my taste, with white paint marking almost anything you can use on your way.

The progression throughout the game was quite satisfying, both in terms of the available movement mechanics and in terms of combat. The available weapons and the encountered enemies both got gradually more and more advanced, in what seemed like a natural way. Combat in general is quite satisfying as well, although sadly, is way too easy. Even at the highest (3rd) difficulty level, it's trivial to headshot everyone with a bow most of the time, and it's very difficult to get killed (unless you're grinding an achievement which requires you to tackle an enemy with a rifle...). Although it's not much of a challenge, it's still quite fun, and an optimal amount of hidden locations and collectibles makes the world even more enjoyable to explore.

Overall, Tomb Raider is a solid adventure game in every aspect, and a modern benchmark for the genre.

Jumping, climbing, shooting, puzzles – yep, it’s a Tomb Rider title. Solid by-the-numbers game.  I enjoyed it, but I fear I’ll soon forget it.

At medium difficulty the game doesn’t give a huge challenge.

The surprising thing is the amount of bones, blood, and hanging flesh. At times, the game environments are almost uncharacteristically gory.

I've been collecting a bunch of "old games" and "old game series" recently for the sake of making my inner child happy again (never got to play any of these games as a kid), so this was a fun start.

Yeah it has it's glitches and it's issues but I had an absolute blast playing it nonetheless. I've not played the previous games but I absolutely loved all the characters and the story arch. The Stormguard were cool as hell, Lara gets a really cool start to her character arch and development and it's a reasonable one too. I mean it implies that she's a college student by the time this journey starts so it makes sense that this is shown to be a traumatic experience in Rise of the Tomb Raider. And her distress over this game, all the way til Shadow of the Tomb Raider, was really well handled.

The character gets cooler, and even scarier over the course of the events of all the games and it's so interesting and genuinely fun to watch it happen. I love being part of that. 

TL;DR if you wanna make yourself enjoy something just for the hell of it I recommend it, and I genuinely believe they did a good job and the story was well done.

It's interesting to recognize, even if more recently, the games to which the next entries within the same genre will compare to as a standard. In that sense, it is undeniable that [i][b]Uncharted™[/b][/i] (and, subsequently, its sequels) became a staple to the action-adventure genre from 2007 onward.

And so, it was almost inevitable that the [i]Tomb Raider[/i] series would take notes and inspiration from that other series, from which this reboot brilliantly resulted. Despite being much more focused in the action part of it (and recognizing its dissonance with the story, that tries to ground the violence since her first kill but ends up almost glorifying it), this game ends up offering a new Lara Croft, intentionally distant from its original iteration but, for that, much more interesting.

Although loving the character and having played the Legend Trilogy from start to finish, I'm not as defensive as some may be for the original games (which I never got around to playing). I simply adore the way they have taken this character here, inspired clearly by the [i][b]Uncharted™[/b][/i] series but never copying it. Instead, it leans on this character's distinct characteristics and personality, with a story that explores her vulnerability, hiding a clear dormant survival instinct, that would develop in the sequels. 

I've seen many point out the lack of the dual pistols as Lara Croft's signature weapon, even by the end of this new trilogy, but not only do I recognize the bow as an intentional departure from the old games, offering a new iconic weapon for the character, but its integration is ingrained in the platforming and is an added challenge to the game's combat. I found myself using that weapon for most of the time, as it helped develop my aim and take my time developing a a stealthier approach for some of the encounters.

I couldn't be more in love with this franchise than I am with this game, revitalizing the different game mechanics but, most noticeably, the main character. Lara Croft definitely became a hero of mine from this point on.
The games very good just needed more tomb raiding.

It's polished to a sheen and a lot about its story and looks and feel still holds up. The lack of rough edges unfortunately also means it lacks a lot of identity; its combat never gets sophisticated and the puzzles never make you think too hard. Very little of the environmental puzzle rooms from the old tomb raiders are here. It has absolutely fantastic pacing for what it is (don't worry about collectibles, you won't need the xp). My biggest problem with it is the lack of challenge. Even on the hardest difficulty the final boss is a joke and as long as you can click on a head you'll be a murder machine during the entire game.

Overall so far I'm really enjoying the game. It's got beautiful and well detailed graphics, a good action packed story line and decent game play mechanics.  The only down side in my personal opinion is the camera they decided to get super "creative" with.  I absolutely hate feeling like some idiot with a handheld camera is running as fast as they can behind my character constantly jiggling, bouncing and trying to zoom in and out for dramatic effect to film my journey.  I don't want my gaming experience to feel like i'm watching it through a camcorder. I know i'm in the minority here apparently but for me it delivers the opposite feel as to what they were going for. They claim they do this to amplify and intensify the action and make it feel more "real" but for me it ruins it entirely, it takes me out of the game submersion and into wishing the "camera guy" was real so I could beat him with his own camera for being so crappy at filming me. I want to feel like i'm the character not the camera. Anyway despite my rant, it's still a great game, it would just be even better if you at least had a choice in the options to avoid the creators "creativity" with your viewing experience.

This is like a ride through Disneyland. You follow the path the game has set out for you. Along the way, there are a bunch of cut scenes with over the top action sequences and a bunch of quick time events. The shooty parts of the gameplay bored me about halfway into the game, but the puzzles in the tombs are fairly engaging. I ended up turning off my brain about halfway into the game (and even turning down the combat difficulty to easy) to get through the story and finish the game. The story and writing is pretty underwhelming, and a bunch of side characters die for no reason. You're probably better off playing Uncharted or The Last of Us.

This game is fairly alright, I just cannot recommend it to play. I've not finished the game in my 8 hours, and I plan to finish it, there's just a lot of problems I have with the game. First, Lara survives an absurd amount of damage to herself. In the first 5 minutes, she slams her head twice, falls about 25 feet onto a piece of rusty rebar that impales her, and she simply PULLS IT OUT. She falls about roughly 100 times from impressive heights that look like it would hurt a lot, but she keeps going like nothing happened. Only once in the game does it address that she's been injured. I would allow it if this was uncharted, however even uncharted isn't this absurd, and at least with Drake it's plausible that he could survive everything he's been through. My second issue is that there's no humor in the game, and the game takes itself very seriously when the reaction to anyone dying is "oh no! anyway..." Anytime a character dies it tries to have emotion for 10 seconds afterwards then it's completely gone and it's quite jarring, combined with the fact each character has very little screen time s when they die it's impossible to care about them. There's a couple of other issues I have being the game tells you when a tomb is nearby, completely throwing away the exploration mechanic and the tombs are comically simple to complete within 5 minutes of showing up to one (and I've done 5 so far). You kill about 300 guys or so in the game and Lara doesn't really flinch or react besides the first one and it's pretty strange logic, but I can't fault it too much since every game is like that.

The game isn't all bad though. I like the story somewhat and the gun play is good, The bad guy is interesting and I like the creepy island element. it's pretty much uncharted game play with a bow involved and less guns to choose from. and that's sort of my issue. This game is a worse version of uncharted where you're chasing a treasure and something bad happens once you've found it.

TL;DR Game is a serious version of uncharted and executed somewhat poorly comparatively, Characters die and you don't have time enough with them to care. Takes itself very seriously. Not terrible, maybe a 5/10 for me but can't really recommend.

Had only played Rise of the Tomb Raider back then on the Xbox One. Got myself the trilogy (on discount) to play on my PC. Gotta say, what an amazing game the first Tomb Raider is so far. I absolutely recommend this game (so far).

[h1]A phenomenal game.[/h1]

As an Tomb Raider game, I highly recommend veterans and newcomers to give TR 2013 a try. It DOES feels different from the past releases, but different in a good way. 

As we all know, we had a new Lara Croft within this entry, and we get to know more about her throughout the game, including the way she deals with every misfortune put upon her. New Lara makes a good job to introduce the reboot series, having more of a female Rambo grip than any other. It's the very first time that I envision Lara as a survivor, when before she felt to me much more like an adventurer, always managing to have the upper hand by clever thinking and being very bold, where in this game she is pretty much the underdog until half of the story. 
Lara will do anything to stay alive and to keep her friends safe, I really liked that!

The whole game is very consistent from start to finish, making the whole adventure much more seamless and with less halts, even giving the player a chance to take a break and inhale some fresh air once in a while (something that Tomb Raider 3 didn't even considered to). It takes up to 16 - 18 hours to complete, and if you want to do 100%, 50 hours should be enough.

The controls here are very, very good. One thing I've always liked about Crystal Dynamics is how they manage to implement such great controls for Lara, making her feel the most swift and agile possible.

Combat here is the best it ever had been, never liked how combat worked on the previous entries and it does feel archaic, but here it is very refined and works really well. Lara cycles through 5 weapons to fight against her enemies, so in almost every fight I changed weapons in a flight, rapidly changing the pace of the fight in my favor and giving myself the advantage I needed. 

I liked the story, it is original with some few nods here and there to other titles. I like how important fundamentally interwined japanese culture is to the story, so that's a plus.

Is it different? A lot. Is it bad? Not by a chance.
