NO REASON TO PLAY THIS GAME IN 2022 when there are so many better games available. This game was created by someone with completely bizarre ideas an misconceptions about what a good modern game should be like even for 2013 when it was created. 

VOMIT INDUCING CUT SCENES. Literally!  Extreme closeups and simulation of shaking handheld camera is not something you do these days. Especially in games. Those effects were popular 50 years ago when people were watching smaller tube TVs from across the room. Now everybody is either playing close to a high res. monitor or on a huge 4k TV, again, sitting close for better immersion. Most of the game Lara's figure is probably less than half of the height of the screen, but cut scenes show extreme close ups with camera shakes so much that you can barely see what is going on. Your eyes start to hurt. Cut scenes are only watchable from across the room, and even then the shaking feels excessive. 

Some devs still don't get that "Cinematic" does not equal "good". This effect is a cheap and lazy way to make an action scene seem more dynamic. It is not suppose to be used 100% OF THE TIME. Why in the world my screen shake like crazy in a scene where 2 people are calmly talking to each other.  It shakes throughout EVERY cut scene in the game regardless of what is going on there. And throughout much of the game itself, for example, when Lara smoothly slides down a rope. Why? It is a smooth action! Or on top of the antenna, again, shakes like crazy. Antennas sway side to side and it is a slow swaying action that makes you get a vertigo, not stupidly shaking of the entire screen.

Anyway dynamic scenes should be created with lots of interesting action on the screen, not with shaking the screen itself.

CONSTANTLY TAKING CONTROL OF PLAYERS POV. A good game attracts the attention of a player with interesting details, not simply rotating your screen to where the game thinks you should look. When Lara is moving it immediately turns your own view towards the direction of her movement. You cannot simply run sideways while looking forward for example. When Lara is hanging, or climbing or doing anything in particular the game rotates your view for you. It is extremely annoying and frustrating. A player should ALWAYS be in full control of his camera, otherwise it feels nauseating and annoying as if you are not in control of your own head and someone physically takes it and turns it towards something they think you should look at. Such a dumb way to kill immersion.

Those are the main topics that made this otherwise good game annoying and unplayable and I'm deleting it unfinished. It is simply not enjoyable. I played the later Tomb Raider and It had the same things, but not as excessive as here.  Times are changing, new techniques and devices are developing, old school cinematic and tricks no longer work and I'm not likely to buy anything else from a studio that does not get it.

Great graphics, even seven years after its release it is one of the prettiest games that I have ever played. The story is intriguing, characters and voice acting compelling. The gameplay is also very fun, with both combat and exploration enjoyable.

My first major complaint is with regards to difficulty. I am playing on hard difficulty and apart from a couple fights within the first hour or so of the game, combat is quite easy. Fights do take some strategy, and the stealth aspect of the bow is quite interesting, but I haven't had to reload due to dying in combat since the (very well designed) encounter where you fight while escaping a burning building that occurs very early on. Ammunition is also far to abundant, in fact I rarely find myself without full ammo for every weapon. This completely eliminates resource management and makes the ammo finding skills fairly useless. Nevertheless, since the game mainly focuses on story and exploration, I don't find the difficulty aspect detracts from my experience very much.

There are also issues with story immersion due to the fact that several tombs and other side quests pop up during very tense moments of the story. For example, as Lara is attempting to rescue a pilot who parachuted from a burning plane before he is captured by the cultists, she finds a tomb and is given the option to explore this. Since it is time consuming to backtrack, I often find myself wandering around during tense story moments to grab some equipment or discover relics.

All in all, quite an enjoyable game: 8/10

Edit: Having completed the game I will say that things do get more difficult once again towards the end, and ammunition eventually does become somewhat of a resource to manage. On a negative note combat becomes somewhat repetitive without many new types of enemies to overcome. Instant reloads without penalty eventually took away the sense of fear that I had while exploring early on in the game and contributed to my building feeling of boredom as my playtime passed 10 hours. Rating remains the same, worth it for the voice acting, visuals design of the island, and the atmosphere created in at least the first half of the game.

This is not a bad game by any stretch of the word. The cinematics and visuals are very pretty. But the question is “Do you recommend the game?” and I honestly wouldn’t. I didn’t really care about the story or characters. Gameplay-wise, it’s a cover shooter with a lot of climbing, and I do mean that; there was too much climbing and not enough combat imo. There are stealth mechanics, but not many chances to use them to their fullest. I spent a lot of resource points on character and weapon upgrades that I didn’t really need or want. It’s not that the game offended me in any way, it’s just that I’ve played a shit ton of video games, and not much stands out here to justify buying it in 2022.

This game may not receive a lot of love from the TR fanbase but it's still a decent Tomb Raider game.

Getting tired of grinding in mmorpgs and open world time sinks, that seems to be the vibe these years, coming back to this title, was a breath of fresh air, reminding me what it really feels like to enjoy playing a video game again.

Playing this game without worrying about finding every little nook and cranny that eventually makes you bored (at least it makes me bored), so you can be a "completionist" (wonder why anyone would care about that)  was my approach. Enjoying the world, the story, the gameplay, even with all the flaws, was a time well spend.

Graphics in highest settings hold pretty well for such an old game, the world looks amazing, the story is interesting and you get enough tense moments for a tomb raider game. Combat is ok, but again, this a tomb raider, it is more about the story, the puzzles (not hard ones), and the jumping, climbing, sliding around.

Overall had really fun with this. Next "Rise of the Tomb Raider" that has been sitting in my library for so long.

The controls are a bit clunky, but overall I'm having a blast headshotting people with flaming arrows and hunting for all the collectibles. Beautiful, detailed maps and exciting gameplay that will never leave you bored.

This game is enjoyable if you A) expect a mindless platformer and B) don’t value realism. If you want a more immersive and polished experience then you need to know these main faults:

Nothing is realistic. Flammable objects burn down in seconds, animals have terrible AI, and the landscapes all have the same obvious signposting for jumping, climbing and grappling. This isolated island is absolutely filled with skeletons, still-lit lamps, and wreckage. Many of the baddies have bows, for some bizarre reason, and ammunition litters the map in a quite preposterous abundance. Curious string bags can be found regularly and they must be set on fire in order to get the ‘salvage’ from within. Why these bags couldn’t just be opened with our Lara-hands is beyond me.

‘Salvage’ is a form of currency used to, somehow, upgrade your weaponry and it can also be found in random crates and, um, in animals. Yes folks, that means you can innocent deer and use the body parts to make a better receiver for your automatic rifle. How? Don’t know.

The game is over engineered in many parts. The shaky camerawork is unrelentingly present, even in cut-scenes and there is simply too much freaking weather on some maps. The camp menu, which you’ll be using a lot, throws pointlessly exaggerated animations and sound effects at you every time you navigate through it, and I hated it. This menu is where you spend your experience to choose new skills and where you spend your salvage to upgrade your weaponry, and there aren’t many options in it but every damn one of them requires several grades of navigation. Please just show me all the skills on one page and all the weapon upgrades on another without the special effects and flashes and booms and swooshes and beeps—it’s like Michael Bay directed the flipping thing.

Strangely, I have seen other reviewers praise the characterisation and the story but I warn against believing them: Lara has no arc at all, starting out as a tough cookie who says she hasn’t a clue but then adventures away with ease; and ending as a tough cookie who, well, adventured away with ease. It’s all tell with opposite show. The story, too, is pretty silly (the big, bad cult leader wants a woman to sacrifice in order to revive a goddess, the protagonist fights through endless lesser baddies to save the woman who we barely know) and it is entirely superfluous with minor, pointless exposition happening through books you can find on the map. None of this really matters, none of it affects the gameplay, and we don’t care enough about the lesser characters to feel any bond to them. Lara could have shot the antagonist many times but the game decided, for no reason, that his death must be saved for the final (disappointingly easy) showdown. Only someone that thinks action flicks are deep or who skips the cut-scenes in RDR2 or The Last of Us could admire the writing in Tomb Raider.

But there are positives: it is a decent game with graphics that still look good in 2022 and the weaponry is fun to use. One thing that I really appreciated was Lara Croft’s appearance. While she is still an attractive representation of the traditionally female form, she is no longer overtly sexually portrayed and there are menu options to have her clothed in more practical attire than the skimpy vest she begins with. She is well acted too, with some genuinely memorable lines.

If you want some mindless fun then get the game; if you want a cerebral or powerful gaming experience then look elsewhere.

I was able to finish this game a couple of times before already WITHOUT any issues even when I ran it on Max settings. Now, for my Nth re-run from scratch, I've encountered multiple bugs which doesn't exist before. I'm currently stuck on a specific scenario where you need to press Shift Key to move along the Zip Lines, and on the second line, when you press Shift, it doesn't make it to the next line, which causes Lara to fall short of the Line transitioning. It was an okay game and is replayable. Though at this point in time, I don't know why it has so many bugs now compared to when I ran it for the first few story runs. I wouldn't recommend getting this game the way it is now. Spare yourself the stress of counteracting the bugs. I've already tried to restart the game a couple of times, but still, Lara falls short of that leap transition.

Really enjoyed the game and the story, graphics still hold up pretty well despite being from 2013. It's fun to explore and was nice to see 100% being quite achievable (and the game makes it easy to go back and complete things you miss).

However, I encountered at least 3 game breaking bugs (one of which forced me to restart about 11 hours in since I wasn't saving multiple slots). In No Man Left Behind the crate you need to jump on can get embedded in the wall, in the Gondala section when you have to do rope jumping motion stops completely in the slow-mo not allowing you to jump and in Cliffside Bunker a door which needs to open fully does not. All of these bugs stop you from proceeding.

It seems they were due to running at 144Hz, 1440p with no VSync (using G-Sync in my case). I got past all of those issues (after restarting the came from the first one and then saving a *lot* more) by dropping to 60Hz and enabling double buffering temporarily for those sections. I was just able to do this from the in-game menu for those bits then switch back to my normal settings. There are definitely others who have encountered some of these issues, it's a shame they haven't been patched, paticularly since the most recent update is not that old.

Looks pretty; seems promising but it feels like it's on rails. You just move from one cutscene to the next and look for the prompts as to what keys you are supposed to press.  If they are going to take away my agency, I'd rather watch a movie and do away with the hassle to be honest.

I was first introduced to Tomb Raider back in 1996, when you could still go into movie/rental stores. Or rather, when they were still a thing. It was the third or forth game I had ever played on my brand new PS1. yah. I'm that old. I was taken aback by the graphics, the music, the atmosphere and the general feeling of something not very nice could be hiding around the corner. Like a bear. Or a bloody wolf! I loved Lara's story. And as a girl, I felt inspired! Besides playing as Sonja Blade  or Kitana from Mortal Kombat (Sega Genesis....I feel soooo oooold) Anyhauser---- I don't recall any games from that time with a female lead.  I've played every single game since and was beyond overjoyed and a little scared when I first heard of this remake. Of course I bought it and was blown away! They really captured the essence of Lara. We get to see her before it all began.  The very catalyst of her sharp sense of adventure and desire for danger. I enjoy this game greatly. I couldn't recommend it enough. It's beautiful, haunting, dangerous and damn those wolves!

While I would recommend this game, it would honestly depend on your taste of gameplay and story.
Simple story, easy to grasp gameplay mechanics and plain old fun game to go through.

The story was just okay, but I'm not out here expecting some high grade storytelling, I just thought the plot and how it paced was really mediocre. How it played out became repetitive. [spoiler] It was just going somewhere for something, you get that something but for a cost. So now you need to go to another place to get something. Repeat. [/spoiler]

BTW, there is no post-game story here. Which disappointed me a bit. The post-content is basically for completionists and collecting stuff to get that juicy 100%. What's the point of me maxing my gear and skills anymore besides getting the achievement.

The combat was really simple, to the point where it felt like it needed more variety. Like the pacing of the plot, the fighting gets stale and boring. Sometimes I felt like I'm slogging through these fights to finish the story already.

Platforming and mini-puzzles were enjoyable, I'm a fan of those things (this is tomb raider after all), [strike] although this game sometimes have wonky parkour [/strike] [spoiler] Tangent: The secret tomb with the buoy was so fucking annoying because of how you need to tediously crank on every attempt. [/spoiler]

But despite its flaws, I still enjoyed playing it. What's important to me is the feeling that I didn't waste any time playing this game.

You see, you were supposed to use that cage to climb to the top of a high ledge, which is less than ideal when your cage broke himself to oblivion. A good game, but with an ageing, mediocre storyline.

First of all, I did enjoy the metroidvania style gameplay that this reboot brought for the Tomb Raider franchise, as it feels fresh amongst the once linear, level-by-level design of it's predecessors. My only criticism of TR2013's gameplay is the out of place crafting system, specifically upgrades to your weapons and tools which feels less rewarding than simply having Lara finding those upgrades herself by raiding tombs.

Despite good, non-linear design, the game feels dragged down by it's unremarkable story and forgettable characters, including the Lara Croft herself. As nearly a decade has gone by, the reboot era of Tomb Raider has been growing less appealing as I've been realising how much reboot Lara is boring, weak, and lacking of meaningful and memorable personality, which since has gravitated me back towards the stronger, confident, elegant, and more mature version of Lara from her earlier adventures. I understand TR2013 serves as a new origin story for Lara, but the way TR2013 portrays her is almost like a completely different person with none-to-barely any of her older characterisation being intact or reformed by the end of the game.

There is a decent experience to be played here, but it's story has grown more mediocre and unmemorable as time has passed. My only wish for the future of Tomb Raider is to see a return to form, or a modern port of the original CORE era games.

Playing this at 14 was so significant for me. Like many young gamers I too had a  really hard spot on my crotch for this game. Her grunts, screams and moans definitely awakened something in me.

Tomb Raider 2013 feels like AAA polished perfection IMO. There's zero fat on the game. Nothing feels extra, tedious or out of place. Incredible visuals for the day and they hold up just fine. The high resolution textures, shadows, tessellation and hair physics? Icing on the cake.

The reason I liked this game way more than the sequels is that it's the story of how Lara becomes a badass. 

It was the speed of her transition from ingénue to stone-cold killer that really got me! It's been a while since I played it, but I'm sure I remember a scene towards the beginning where she really gingerly and uncomfortably picks up a gun that someone dropped, and then a few scenes later she's John Wick, leaving piles of bodies everywhere she goes.

Additionally one of my favorite things about the game was the metroidvania nature to it, and  how you slowly developed your arsenal and used it to complete the myriad of challenges tucked away.

That said, the scale of mass murder, the lack of tombs, the amount of times she falls and the way she falls (honestly it’s almost injury porn), do drag the experience down a little. I mean, do we really need to see Lara with a large spike through her head, futilely trying to unimpale herself only to finally give in to death? Yeah, no thanks. 

Finally, I really liked the way the game actually progressed through a bunch of genres, taking bits and pieces from each but never over staying its welcome.  Too many games are afraid to try anything different.

Honestly now that I’m 49, I really just like linear games at this point. I’ve long since ODed on Ubisoft worlds, so a game like this continues to feel like a breath of fresh air.

While this game can be somewhat entertaining at times, it's got several flaws that I think make it not worthwhile, except at steep discount.

This is basically like playing through a movie.

Far too many cut scenes where they want you to mash a button for Lara to do something. Riding down rapids where you can't see where you're going and if you run into an obstacle the same death scene keeps repeating. It's extremely annoying and boring. What's the point? If you're off by a second because your hand isn't in the right position on the keyboard, you die, then you have to go through the sequence again and again until you hit every button at exactly the right time. It's dumb; it's annoying; it's frustrating, and it's not fun.

The game will also have you going back through different sections, just to collect various random objects. Some add a bit to the story or background of the island, while others are pointless, and just challenges to fulfill.

I at least kind of enjoy the weapon upgrades, which may have you going through various parts of the island again to collect scraps you may have missed.

The majority of the game is small sequences where you fight a collection of enemies, and you try continuously from the last auto-save. It makes it feel less like a game than a movie where you just have to advance the plot to the next point.

It also feels very one track. You can't explore much, except what is on the track, and specific hidden spots for secrets and salvage to upgrade your weapons.

It feels less like a game than a challenge to complete the story and collect all the knickknacks from the island.

Your character doesn't even seem to stay hurt. It's like she's an immortal death god.

It at least feels a lot less buggy than it did years ago, and seems to run alright on integrated graphics now.

63 hours, multiple playthroughs, and over a decade.

I just completed this game for the possibly 7th time. It still holds as one of the best reboots out there, and making it available for pc even back then was awesome. I remember playing this game for the second time in college, and not having the graphics run very well because of my laptop's limited hardware. Fast forward to today, and I was able to put everything on ultra settings, and it was a blast to play one more time!

The story still makes sense, and the game has rich characters and gameplay for its time. You still smile at Jonah, who does in fact return in later entries due to high demand. You still look at Whitman like he's crazy, and you still wish Reyes would believe or trust you.

In the end, I would very much recommend this game to anyone, even beginners to video games like these, for years to come.

The gameplay is simple and varied. Here you will kill opponents (a huge number of ways are provided), and solve riddles (how to get somewhere). Parkour is also included. To not let you get bored there are moments where you need to do a series of actions in response to the reaction ( to escape from the collapse, dodge the debris, etc.).Collecting items, experience points and spare parts is not intrusive. 2. Multiplayer. It is dead. For those who want to get all the achievements, this will be a serious problem.

TLDR: This game is bad. It's really really bad.

Year of writing (2022)

I've never really cared much about Tomb Raider games as I wasn't a Play Station household, so I'm coming at this from a fresh unbiased direction. I like to think that I can appreciate or dislike the game without nostalgia clouding my judgment, especially since this is the kind of reboot that is trying to take the content in a different direction. However, I don't think this did the game any favors. I'm going to start with some of the things I liked about it.

The game is really well paced, and thankfully short. It never punished the player for failing stealth, and combat is competent, though I think it was balanced for people using controllers. Even so, the default PC controls are pretty good. I never felt like I needed to change them and they were intuitive enough to use without thinking about them. Visually it was smooth, though I had issues in windowed mode as it tanked frame rate and stuttered while the GPU never even went above 20% load. Lara's face looks weird but all other visuals were really good for 2013. Gameplay wasn't over complicated and worked relatively well.
But ultimately I disliked the game. While this garnish of good qualities is nice, the meat of this game (or cauliflower for you vegetarians) is pretty awful.

Camera
There's so much camera shake. It's absurd. There's more camera shake here than Ocean's 12 and will make you borderline nauseous. Apparently this gets some attention in the sequels when they patched in a way to turn it off, but that's not available here. On top of that, this game was made with either no experience of gaming on PC or no consideration for it. The auto centering third person camera is so aggressive that you can only look at things if you're standing completely still. This includes situations like stealthing around enemies where peripheral vision is much more important.

Bad Direction
It's rare for me to notice direction as a factor in how good or bad a game is because it encompasses too many things. But in this case a lot of what's wrong is on a macro level instead of being in the details. The first most obvious issue with direction is that it feels like it's plagiarizing from other popular games. Little pieces of Far Cry 3, ideas from Uncharted, but not enough from Tomb Raider. The decision to make Lara a character that the "player wants to protect" was terrible, leading to all kinds of bad writing and some of the most obnoxious sound elements I've ever encountered.
The set pieces are too much. It becomes abundantly clear that Lara only survives based on extraordinary luck. So many times you will engage a set piece, even without being forced to jump in by gunfire, without a way to get all the way through. As in damage to the environment during had to happen before you could actually progress. On top of that, a surprising number of them were obvious. You can see the pieces in place before it even happened. This predictability makes it hard to stay immersed and makes you think about the tools you have available and wonder why you don't approach things from different directions.
The realistic approach makes the supernatural elements seem out of place or shoe horned in. You just don't get enough exposure to this sticking point until later in the game. I'm not sure if this is a problem for other people but for me it felt like I was in two different pieces of fiction. I felt like I needed more incentive to question whether or not the Sun Goddess was real or not. Instead we're left with only two small cut scenes where no one in their right mind would have flown through in the first place, and one slightly more convincing scene of dramatic wind shift. That's it. Everything else is in realism town until you're fighting zombie samurai at the end. Yeah, that sounds even dumber now that I'm writing it than when I was doing it.

Character
Lara being the worst archaeologist in the world doesn't bother me as much as other people. There's a little joke hidden with the horse figurine that I enjoyed a great chuckle at. But her character writing and voice acting just don't line up with her actions. Instead of being realistic and relatable, she comes across as the the side character in a B movie from SyFy you hope dies by the end but doesn't. She starts off generic, over dramatizes in the cut scenes, never seems to show an ability to critically think or put together the obvious clues. She also has a persistent jarring naivete that completely disconnects from her body count. I actually don't mind that she says, "You can do this," so many times, but her breathing always sounds like she's mid sob. So running around is like enjoying a whiny companion you can't get away from. The tone in her voice never changes either, despite what the character has been through; which always make her (and any character in any game) sound silly when they try to swear by calling enemies "bastard!" It just doesn't have the emotional weight of fighting someone who killed people close to you, or real horror of having killed so many more of them to survive or for revenge. She always sounds like someone on safari or a vacation, a tourist in her own story. Basically the opposite of the gritty intent of changing her character.

Bad Writing
I don't mind linear writing. You're not really playing the main character as much as you're along for _her_ ride. And this being a Square game, I gave it quite a bit of leeway to be grandiose and silly. But the constant stupid decision making, cliche character development, and quite often mediocre voice acting really rubbed me the wrong way. One of the first things to happen in the game is that Lara gets a piece of rebar punched all the way through her. Instead of inspecting it for potential bleeding, she immediately pulls it out and never in the entire game bandages it. She also immediately wades through dirty water with the wound.
The obvious character who will betray you is obvious. The narrative is full of cliches like, "I'd finally set out to make my mark; to find adventure. But instead adventure found me." Which isn't even true. She went to the island, the island didn't go to her. Even in 2013 we'd seen it all before.

Minor Gripes
The placement of things that ropes attach to almost always causes you to make a small leap of faith that the game mechanic will register. Just back these up from the edge by a yard, give us some space to be under the rope.
The physics that would be involved in arrowing something than pulling is obviously going to be dramatically different from what's presented in the game. This breaks immersion every time.
Everyone is constantly yelling and calling out to each other. It's a wonder there's any stealth in this game at all.

So if I were to put this on a scale of how many drinks at a bar is it worth, a single over priced domestic. It's done enough competently that I would say don't pay money for it, but there's so much bad about it that makes it hard to justify value. Part of the problem there is that it's bad, not wrong. Wrong things you can be patch out, but bad things are in there intentionally forever.
How much did I pay for it? I don't remember. I got it on a steep discounted sale, but the whole trilogy was given away later on Epic for free.

[h1]Still Good in 2019/2020[/h1]
I started the reboot series by playing Rise of The Tomb Raider. I then beat Shadow. I enjoyed the other games so much I decided to loop back and play the first in the series. It's a tad dated (most notably the menu/leveling systems, etc.) but it's still a [b]really[/b] good game and an absolute must if you're a fan of the series. The graphics still look really pretty (one of those games that was ahead of its' time like The Witcher 2). I think the tone is a bit more "horror survival" than the other two games which I appreciated.

It was slightly cliche but I really enjoyed watching Lara transform from being kind of a wimp (in the intro she whines into her radio "can you come get me?") to a battle-hardened bonafide badass by the end. As the game progresses, her character model picks up more and more scars. She goes from being sick at her first kill (which she barely manages to pull off) to being a cold-blooded assassin, wherein you can choose perks that reward you with extra skill for dispatching opponents with flair (stabbing them at close range with an arrow while they are stunned, etc.).

The enemies aren't that varied and I wish there were actual boss fights but the combat (which borrows heavily from uncharted) is still satisfying. Collecting headshot after headshot with your bow will basically never get old. The plot isn't amazing but it's entertaining and above average for a video game.

[b]In summary:[/b] play this game. Especially at the current price it's a no-brainer.

As a long time Tomb Raider fan, the newest trilogy has a tough standing.
However, I think that despite my heart beating for the blocky riddles and hilarious dialogues of TR I to V, the reboot trilogy is a worthy successor, basically an heir to the Tomb Raider series.

Tomb Raider 2013 is essentially the origin story of Lara Croft. So be prepared to play as a wimpy college girl for a bit. That shocked a lot of people and caused some backlash, since we know Lara Croft as this badass, tough-as-nails raider. Tomb Raider 2013 for me feels a bit Call-Of-Duty-esque: You have a lot of shootouts with human enemies and there is action scenes that are really pushing my suspension of disbelief to its maximum! However, it is still very fun to play through and tells a story that adds (yet contradicts) to the incredibly complex (and already contradictory) Lara Croft Lore. So whether you're a die-hard TR fan or a newcomer to the series, it is an enjoyable game.

Only downside to it is that there's multiplayer achievements.. for a multiplayer mode really nobody wanted or needed. If you're an achievement hunter.. buy the game twice. Once for you and once for your best friend who will help you grind these achievements, there won't be anyone else playing..

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

summary:
Really excellent game elements that were wasted on an extremely stupid, rushed game. Rise & Shadow of the Tomb Raider are basically FAR better versions of this game. There's no reason to play this one unless you're a completionst (which I kinda am, ha). Still very fun, but the weakest in the new TR series.

	pros:
- young lara is a cool character, even if she doesn't do as much in this first reboot game.
- awesome weapons, good action
- fun RPG style upgrade / XP system
- neat historical tie-ins with lore
- mostly good environments / puzzle environments (more linear than the old TR games)
- excellent sound design! immersive
- great graphics even if they've aged in a decade

	cons:
- feels unfinished
- badly ported console UI
- the bushes will kill you and eat you
- early 2010s syndrome: never too sure if playing or in a cutscene, character animations take away control at random times, and large parts of the game make no sense at all.
- some environments are extremely nonsensical, ugly mazes. (https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2868692782)
- characters come and go, sometimes literally with no introduction or explanation as to why they're in the game. just... you know... a bunch of stuff that happens.
- broken third person physics makes certain levels near unplayable (https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2871838199)
- QTE scenes. arrrgh

A rebooted iteration of Tomb Raider - an inevitable re-imagining. 

Laura is tethered to the history of video games as much as Stephen King is synonymous with horror. Her first outing is amazingly barbaric and brutal, as it is emotional and human. It remains faithful to its predecessors while adding deep psychological elements. Combat is vicious and sometimes very visually extreme but not at all over the top. A perfect blend of disbelief and awe that just happens to be trapped inside an inescapable bubble of realism.

Want to play with an intricately planned stealth approach? Sure.
Progression through being environmentally resourceful? Go ahead.
Hardcore action? Have at it.

A story of fractured identity. An awesome first chapter; the beginning of Croft's journey feels grounded within the parameters of the type of world they have established. Equal in adventure and survival - a gripping, visually gorgeous experience, that has a little bit of something for everyone. It's awesome.

While I praise the game on it's graphical fidelity(amazing if your system can run the game maxed out with 4x SSAA enabled), there are some major issues that have a negative impact should you consider spending your hard earned money on purchasing this game.  

(1) Very Short(yet perpetually repeating the same premise) Story Line, I was able to beat the Single Player campaign in 10 hours with 80% of the items found. Note: Prerequisite, I have played every single TR release, and this scores second besides Unfinished Business in being the shortest Single Player campaign I have ever played.

(2) Deviates from the traditional puzzle solving mechanic's presented to us from the previous Tomb Raider franchise. Thanks to the survival instinct feature "puzzles"(dare I even call them that), are pretty much a walk in the park.

(3) QTE(aka quick time events), due to these additional gameplay mechanic's the overall game feels more like Uncharted with simply a female protaganst.

(4) Grindfest - Nothing but killing hoards of enemies, lather, rise, repeat till you eventually reach the next area.  Warning: The ending will leave you thinking:  "Wth, thats it?"

Finally, overall the game is fantastic on it's shear graphical prowess alone, but due steams not so wonderful rating system being limited to a simple yeah or nay.  I wouldn't recommend purchasing this game if you expect the similar gameplay offered by previous Tomb Raider games.  Since the game overall lacks a compelling story-line, any real puzzle solving, gameplay(total number of hours playable before completion), and sense of reward when completing a level.

This game really rocks!!!!!!

Tomb Raider is the reboot of the popular franchise of the same name. It was Square Enix response to Uncharted as a way to try and generate revenue through their newly acquired Western studios such as Crystal Dynamics. The product was one of the most expensive games ever made. While the reimagined Tombraider trilogy never met Square Enix financial expectations, it was enough for them to continue making titles. 

Tombraider plays similarly to Uncharted but with more content. There is a multiplayer mode that was pretty much dead on arrival so do not bother trying to play it. Unlike Uncharted their are optional "Tombs" to raid that offer a puzzle for Lara to solve for extra XP and salvage, they are a relatively fun distraction with nice set pieces. The shooting gameplay is pretty much your standard fair third person shooter but with the ability to upgrade your weapons as well as having more options to traverse the environment vertically than others. Unlike other games, Tomb Raider decided to go with a sticky cover mechanic instead of toggle, it is not janky like some other attempts at it and never got in the way or led to frustrating deaths or inability to traverse the environment. 

One thing to not in the game is that Lara goes through absolute hell in the game with extremely brutal death scenes and set pieces where she is thrown around like a rag doll while screaming. It is pretty gratuitous and took me out of the moment especially because it happens so frequently. It is like they played through Uncharted and saw the crazy set pieces that Drake went through and decided to make Lara go through even worse as a quantity over quality approach. 

The games story is alright with an interesting setting of Yamatai and Queen Himiko that does not really have a presence in Western media. It felt a little derivative at times but it was still enjoyable all the way through outside of Lara getting so many innocent people killed and not really feeling that bad about it. 

TLDR, Tomb Raider is a great reboot to the franchise and its gameplay stands out enough from Uncharted to become its own thing with its optional tomb puzzles, collectibles, and skill/weapon upgrade mechanics to be a fun time sink.

This simply is not a Tomb Raider game. It doesn't concentrate on things previous games in this series did. It doesn't have an atmosphere of being one on one with ancient tombs where you have to navigate through complex enviroments and solve puzzles. It packed with constant action and gunfights without compinsating it with enough platforming or puzzle solving.

We had this original 3D planformer (something that almost no one ever nailed before). Then came Uncharted, took a lot of inspiration from Tomb Raider and established itself as another game series. Then Tomb Rider forgot what it suppose to be good at and tried to simply copy its rival - the Uncharted while losing all of its originality that made it into amazing game to begin with. That irony could of not be any heavier. A franchise that drestroyed itself as an original series while trying to mimic its rival that actually took an inspiration from it.

If you want a TRUE Tomb Rider experience - Try out the [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/8000/Tomb_Raider_Anniversary/][u]Anniversary[/u][/url] instead.

https://store.steampowered.com/app/8000/Tomb_Raider_Anniversary/

----- The original review -----

... this game is so... weird.

Whenever I play this game I find myself on a roller-coaster of emotions.
One moment I'm captivated and the next I'm cringing.
I never really know if I'm enjoying myself or left wanting to quit and never touch this game ever again.

The game-play...Well there is a lot more gun-play this time around... but I do find it to be fun and exciting enough... usually.
There is down-time here and there as you wonder through the level. Fun sights to see and moments of Player VS Environment but the experience is crippled by quick-time events. Also bad is that at currently 30% completion the levels have so far been extremely linear compared to the original with a quaint environmental puzzle to solve here and there. Most of the "substance" has really been in the flash of the visually beautiful level aesthetics, graphics, and the intensity of the action... and unfortunately the action requires a cringy level of suspension-of-disbelief.

Some of the things that really make me cringe about this game:
- Obsessive use of violence and gore which comes off as out-of-place; there are scenes that made me feel I was playing Resident Evil 5 FFS... The violence towards Lara is also depicted in fairly explicit detail as we see her die by getting crushed by boulders and shot in the face... Sure those things happened in the original game... but here it is so gritty, in-your-face, and bluntly depicted... it can be very off putting and just isn't and aspect that I would have focused on if in charge of rebooting the series. We even get to hear Lara admit that killing is easier than she thought it would be... ok miss edge lord... Like, don't get me wrong, I play Postal... It's just a game...  but I mean... did we really need this in Tomb Raider?
- The dialogue is... I don't even care... I've heard Lara say "why?" so many freaking times times it's burned into my brain... and the writing goes in an absolute loop; the story is constantly repeating itself with every new cut-scene and really helps to remind one that time is a flat circle... I skip all the cut-scenes, dialogue, everything... I know the absolute basics of the story and that really is enough...  Seriously listing to these characters is like nails on a chalkboard. 
- The upgrade system for abilities and weapons feels... meh, underwhelming and pointless.
- And almost every scene in this game Lara is surviving some outlandish and complete unbelievable scenario like a comic-book hero.

I just don't know how I feel about this game, I just don't get what's so "overwhelmingly positive" about it.
At 30% completion, I've found this game is just average, heightened by beautiful environments to gawk at and action with a style of intensity that works in the moments when it's working until the game asks you to believe Lara would survive falling 20 stories... 5 times in a row with-in 30 seconds... after falling through burning buildings that are also falling... while having arrows and molotovs hurled at you.

I will start by saying that I [b] did [/b] enjoy this game, as you can see by my positive review, however there are many faults in it I will mention. I have only played the Tomb Raider Crystal Dynamics trilogy, and this is the point of view I'm looking from when reviewing this game.

 Tomb Raider is a game that greatly differs from its predecessors. It is a lot more action focused, trying to draw the player in as if we were watching an action movie. And as it is common with action flicks, it is totally unrealistic and there is an explosion every five seconds. Lara has a solution for every problem, she is far superior to other characters in every way and she can tumble down, get stabbed, get shot and run seemingly forever like she's a superhero. She alone, armed with a bow and a tank top, can defeat an entire army of savage angry men with assault rifles and dynamite sticks. Over and over.

 Previous Tomb Raider games focused on adventure, many of the enemies being wild animals, traps and the environment itself. What invited people in was the wonder of exploration, ancient tombs and seeing a witty Lara Croft know her way around uncharted territory. This game tries to show us a young and innocent Lara, before she became THE Tomb Raider. Unfortunately, it mostly fails on this. Lara is very one dimensional, she's your typical hollywood movie survivor fighting bad guys.

 The rest of the characters are a million times worse. The Endurance crew is devoid of any personality, they're common archetype characters that you even forget exist throughout the game. The same can be said about the main villain, which is (and I'm sorry for repeating myself!) an archetype character. I honestly did not care for anyone in this game except for Lara. None of these characters develop whatsoever, and the little you learn about them is through documents scattered throughout the island, which leaves you uninterested. You can see right away what type of characters they will be, and what their intentions are. 

 The dialogue is also lacking. Lara is constantly shouting "SAM!" trying to make us care about her endangered best friend, yet we know nothing about their friendship so we could care less. Everything is very predictable and boring, your typical "I promise" for dramatic effect.

 Despite this, the game is in fact [b] entertaining [/b] and I had fun watching the story unfold (it is simply extremely cliché).

 Regarding the gameplay, it is pretty good. There are many areas which you can explore, a big map you can access, and different challenges and collectibles in each area (the tombs are terrible though, they're very small and require no intellectual effort at all to get through, which was disappointing). And speaking of "intellectual effort", there are barely any puzzles in this game, less than in Uncharted and every other TR game. And the ones that do exist can barely be considered head scratchers.

 The combat is very good, there are four weapons to which you need to find parts to upgrade (and there are lots of upgrades), you can have fire arrows, silencers, grenade launchers, rope arrows etc. There's also a bit of melee combat that even has a dodge + counter skill you can learn.

 Finally, in terms of graphics and visuals, the game looks alright for a 2013 release. It is not perfect, but the lighting is good enough that you get some really cool sceneries.

 I know I was a bit harsh in this review, but all in all I recommend this game as it is simple and fun and you can never have too much Lara Croft.

Developer Crystal Dynamics wanted to put more emotion in protagonist Lara with this reboot of Tomb Raider. 

No longer did she have to serve as a sex goddess with only boobs shaking. Gamers had to be able to empathize with the suffering Lara endured. Because she is more than just that sexy woman. That immediately explains the transformation that Lara has undergone; she looks slightly different from the previous parts. more humane.

Our archaeologist is 21 years old and together with a few other people on a ship en route to Japan. In the land of the rising sun, there is a lot of art to discover. True treasures. Every archaeologist's wet dream. But before Lara gets there, she is shipwrecked and not every person on the way seems to be equally nice. Logically, otherwise the story doesn't have a leg to stand on.

One of the most powerful features of Tomb Raider is its cinematic aspect. Right from the start when Lara gets into trouble at sea, you'll be on the edge of your seat right away. 
The adrenaline rushes through your body, because Lara has to flee for her life. The music has nerve-racking sounds and at the right moment you have to perform some quick-time events, because otherwise you become one with the boulders in the depth. That beginning of that game - that first hour - is really sensational.

However: it gets to the point where there is so much non-stop explosive action in this game that it makes a Michael Bay produced movie almost seem like a French art house movie with lots of conversations instead of explosions.

It seems like the developers wanted Lara Croft to have a near death experience every couple of seconds and frankly that wears out quickly.

Humor is also completely absent in this game.
That doesn't take away from the fact that Tomb Raider is a fantastic game with very smooth controls. 

Although you sometimes get the feeling that the 'Uncharted' formula has been copied (despite the fact that Tomb Raider has been around for much longer!) and it is all not very original, it should be noted that Tomb Raider is addictive. 
This is partly due to that butter smooth control. Every jump hits the spot, every move feels natural and every arrow or bullet hits its target.

Mechanically the game plays brilliant although it may be on the easy side for experienced gamers (only the end boss is difficult but I did get past him in the end, after multiple tries).

After about a third of the game, the number of shootouts increases massively compared to the first part of the game. There are simply way too many.

There is a serious balance issue with this game imho. There is far too much non stop action with hardly any points in the game where you can relax a moment and come to a rest. This is in particular so for the second half of the game. 

They adressed this issue with 'Rise of the Tomb Raider' but that still had a lot of action but more puzzles & exploration but they only fixed it in the third part, Shadow of the Tomb Raider.
In a way that's fine because it does give each game a different feel with the most action packed game first and the least one (and imho best one) last.

In any case it's a fantastic way to reboot a series, a breath of fresh air.

Tomb Raider 2013 is a reboot of the franchise. It's an origin story showing Lara transition from a young and inexperienced archeologist to a hardened badass.

Lara and her friends get shipwrecked on an ancient island full of mystery. The crew soon encounters the island's cult inhabitants called the Solarii. Some of the crew members are killed and Lara is separated from the others. She has little choice but to fight to survive.

Positives:
+ The story: Engaging and has great pacing.
+ The setting: Yamatai is both gorgeous and deadly.
+ Good graphics.
+ Experience system: Unlock skills in three categores (survivor, hunter, and brawler) as you level up.
+ Combat: Use either a bow, pistol, shotgun or a rifle. It's really fun and tense especially when you're against multiple bad guys.
+ Great stealth and cover mechanics: It's fun silently picking off badguys with your bow.
+ You really feel the tension in some scenes.

Negatives:
- You can walk off damage during and after combat.
- Besides Lara, there's little character development: Most of the character development comes from documents you find scattered throughout the island.
- Too many quick time events: Even the final battle is a QTE!
- Ending is too short.

Score: 8/10

It's many hours of fun and was fun to replay a couple years later. Having been a fan of Lara's since 1996 I really enjoyed this update/reboot of the franchise.

I really wanted to complete this game, but I will be uninstalling it, and here's why:

There are some parts of Tomb Raider I enjoyed. I love the combat and weapons segments, climbing and jumping mechanics, and the tomb discoveries. The puzzles are okay, but they don't always make sense from an engineering perspective. However, the scenes where Lara is sliding, falling, struggling, kicking, or being carried down a river are enraging to the point of ruining the game for me. All those segments have steep learning curves and exact timing, so Lara is going to die over and over before you find out exactly how to navigate out of those (extremely difficult) segments. Her deaths are so grisly, vocal, and awful that it's like watching a snuff film. I watched a wolf rip her throat out like 15 times. I've watched cult members cut her throat over and over. I've watched her fall through a disintegrating bridge into the chasm below 14 times. I've watched her impaled in the river scene on Mountain Descent a good 25 times already. Not only can I not make it past this part, but I've just decided it's no fun anymore.   

You would have to be a sadist, a psychopath or a misogynist to enjoy this game, and I am none of those things. Navigating high speed or perilous situations in the game should not be this difficult. I can't believe they haven't fixed what are some obvious mechanical problems with Tomb Raider. It deserves better.  I've never died this many times in any game and each death is over the top gruesome. 

Bitterly disappointed that I won't be able to complete this, but I wanted a fun action-adventure game, and this has become more frustrating than fun. The character suffers too much and dies too often for the game to be enjoyable.

It's my first "Tomb raider" game ever! I remember seeing pictures and videos of the old Tomb Raider games where Lara Croft was very cubic, jumping from a ledge to another, eventually sometimes shooting at dinosaurs. I really thought this game would be in the same ballpark, and I was expecting something cute, but hell no! It's really an "adult" game, with lots of blood, guts, cult psychopaths and all. Poor Lara Croft is going through hell in there and when she fights, she doesn't just pull out her tiny gun, she's equipped with everything, except maybe a bazooka (scratch that, she has a grenade launcher)!

Overall the story is pretty cool, the graphics are awesome (and this game already has almost 10 years), it's smooth, the gameplay is fun and easy to get used to. Even the music, the atmosphere... No, really, I have nothing to complain about, this is an awesome game! Too bad the game is too old to try the multiplayer mode (nobody is online anymore), but I already have a decent 25+ hours of gameplay, so I cannot complain :)

Masterpiece. Back in the day, the Tomb Raider games did not catch my attention. I was playing other video games as a kid, but I always knew about this saga. 

When the Tomb Raider Reboot came out in 2013, I was stunned. Loved this new realistic Lara, the fact that they drop the dumb dual welding pistols, and she now grabbed the gun like a pro, was it for me. Her body and clothing are more believable now for a female adventurer, I never really get mixing sex and video games, but that formula clearly worked for quite some time. This new Lara is fantastic, you get attached to her walking her journey. This 1st entry is all about "a survivor is born" so is a painful journey filled with hardships and difficult emotional moments. But in the end, we see the Tomb Raider emerge from that.

The original PC version released in 2013 is way better that the console definitive edition they released years later. Since the game was released, I completed it several times, and it's always been an exciting adventure to get into Lara's shoes. Love the stealth gameplay, the enemy pre-combat dialogs, the enemy AI is great, and the weapons! Total masterpiece and a great franchise reboot.

This game is a masterpiece, I really enjoyed my experience with it and oftentimes felt very sorry for Lara during her hard struggles. 9/10. Don't know if this is a pc thing but the camera angles made it hard for me to see whether a leap below Lara was safe to drop down from and when I hid I sometimes got things like the wall or leaf blocking my view of the enemies I was aiming at, but again, maybe that is just a pc thing. Hated those experiences but overall Tomb Raider is awesome, so much action, it gives you open room to explore the island and do whatever you want basically. It gets tricky all the time but that's the charm of Tomb Raider games ^^ Also adore Lara's new design! 

This game is not for the faint hearted, there are scenes of cannbalism involved as well as disfigured body parts, blood, tortures and extremely heavy displays of blood and gore, killing animals cursing and so much more vile things. I would say it is 18+ but do not go into this if you're feeling uneasy with dead bodies, blood and killing because all of those things is the central theme of the game.

The storyline is very good too, emotional yet thrilling. Sometimes it can be hard to know when a cutscene has ended. Some games makes it very clear when a cutscene is happening and when gameplay is happening. Tomb Raider does not do that so you have to be ready for thr TB icon at the bottom of the screen, that is your only cue that it is possible to move again.

A fun game similar to the Uncharted games. You are stuck on an island and are trying to get off but need to fight your way out. This game reminded me a bit of Uncharted 2 (Gameplay, Themes) and Resident Evil 4 (Story, Gameplay, Environment).

STORY:
The story is focused on Lara as she is shaped into a tomb raider and that happens gradually as the story progresses. Your group is trying to flee an island, but they have to fight their way off from a cult.

GAMEPLAY:
Similar to Uncharted, the game is divided into puzzles and combat. Puzzles take place in tombs, but are more focused on physical puzzles compared to logic puzzles (Puzzles are more similar to the ones in the LoZ: Breath of the Wild shrines compared to Uncharted series). You climb and jump to move through the map similar to Uncharted. Combat is more personal than in Uncharted, where you can select between 4 weapons and alternate ammo types (similar to Bioshock). You can fight melee or range and perform finishers. Quick time events occur every once in a while in this game, but are not too bad.

PROS:
Character development exists for Lara
Music was decent
Puzzles were relatively easy to solve
Great setting
Great voice acting
Combat is fun

CONS:
Constant shaky camera causes motion sickness within an hour of playing
No character development for any other characters (All of them except maybe 2 or 3 are forgettable)
Characterization and the story do not mix well realistically (Don't cry and then forget and be okay 2 minutes later)

RATING: 7/10

The Graphics and the Story line depicting Lara's younger life were great.

I completed it in a few evenings which probably says more than enough about how much I enjoyed it the story line and character development is engaging and the gameplay is varied enough to rarely get repetitive or boring.

There are four distinct types of thing that go on in the game: Puzzles, Fighting, Action Scenes, Cut Scenes.

The puzzles are fun but a bit simplistic. You won't be stuck for particularly long with these things none of them require more than a couple of steps and most are pretty straightforward to figure out.

The fighting isn't great enemies are as lethal as a hippie feather duster and have heads the size of flying saucers, but the combat sequences are short enough that it doesn't get in the way of main gameplay.

The action scenes are great buildings collapsing all around you whilst dodging flying debris pretty regularly, but again not so much as to get samey.

The cut scenes tell a good story, although I did get a bit fed up with occasionally having to randomly press a button at a specific point for little apparent reason.

Not perfect then, but an enjoyable little romp. Well worth the price; I had fun with this game.

One of the best adventure games you will ever get to play, hands down phenomenal. Thank You to who ever had the idea to reboot the franchise with this game, as a Tomb Raider fan i am more than happy.

Pros - Story is amazing because it forces the game to happen, without Lara becoming The Tomb Raider in this game she would have never left the island, animations are fluid and smooth, likable side characters, lots of weapons with amazing costumization, a semi open world that connects it all really well, lots of different environments, the graphics look amazing, lots of good and well put together collectables, voice acting is fantastic, physics are superb, fun puzzle segments, soundtrack is great and gives the game a feel of adventure, there is never a dull moment (great pacing), brutal kill cams for when she dies and kills enemies, very welcome but unexpect gore, optional tombs to explore and overall the gameplay together is fantastic, from combat to exploration.

Cons - Terrible subtitle boxes, truly awful, some unexpected bugs caused by the physics.

Nitpicks - Wish there were more tombs to explore and that they were bigger in scale not difficulty, also wish we got the PS4 character model version for the PC version as an update or even DLC honestly.

Final Verdict is a 100%. (Final Verdict varies from 10% to 100%)

Since they're very similar, I don't feel like bothering with 3 independent reviews for each of the Tomb Raider games, from this trilogy.

They're also very similar in terms of gameplay, with slight variations. But suffice to say, it's nothing bad, but also nothing remarkable. As most other action-adventure titles, very derivative of the metroidvania style.

What they all, also, have in common is the plethora of random bits and bobs to discover and pickup. It's sort of a OCD person's collect-o-thon, which was nice for a while, but then it really felt like it turned into a job. 

Another derivative thing, which I've really grown to be annoyed by are the action set-pieces where you have to dodge, bob and weave around a set trail, while usually there's something grandious happening around you (most often, some calamity that you have to get through). These were again pioneered a long time ago, in whatever first action title, but they've really grown stale. Especially since you often get the wrong direction, or just plain get it wrong, and you constantly have to reload the same section until you learn it by heart. Not fun anymore. But it's not been fun for a long time now.

But the worst thing about these games is that somehow they never manage to neither write a compelling story, nor make the character drama anything interesting. It's all so boring most of the time. Surprisingly, Shadow did manage a few nice heartfelt moments, but it also faceplanted while attempting some other ones. One really stands out, where they tried, for a brief while, to do turn Lara into a sort of Max Payne, revenge driven, killing machine. The idea wasn't bad, but somehow, with the way they wrote Lara, and the way she is, it just would not be in her character. So it really looked ridiculous.

For the first in the trilogy, and Rise, I honestly cannot remember any moments of nice characterization. And i finished Rise very recently, after having lost steam initially at about the midway point. That's another wrong thing about these games, they're so long and filled with so much content, that even in Shadow, towards the second half of the game, I just sprinted towards the ending as I just couldn't bear doing the random "quests" that they introduced with Shadow, where the lackluster writing and unintesting quests really standout. Ignoring those, you could say the main plot is serviceable. But with all the derails caused by the side quests, it really turns into a chore, and causes the game length to be artificially inflated.

Another very nice thing in Shadow, compared to the previous two was the addition of a lot more tombs and crypts to explore. It really seemed like they took the criticism of too much combat, in the previous games, to heart. Some of the tombs are actually very nice and challenging.

I realize I didn't say much about the first two games, but that's just how unremakable they are. And they are that, in most regards, except for visuals and level design. In these two areas, I think all three games really excel. Especially the visuals, and especially in Rise and Shadow. Some are just jawdroppingly beautiful. So much work must have gone into the landscapes. If only the games would have also had some fantastic stories to tell, with some compelling characters. If they wouldn't managed that, it would've been perfect. I really hope Crystal Dynamics manages to do something about all of this, in the UE5 Tomb Raider game they're apparently heading. Say what you will about Uncharted, at least they have some really charismatic characters, like Sullivan and Drake.

Replayed it again after almost 10 years and am still impressed about how Lara's story unfolded. This game aged pretty well. You can grind all collectibles if you want, but you don't have to. Since I am no completionist, the story was the main focus, as was upgrading Lara's skills. The controls can be clunky, are otherwise quite smooth and sometimes not as responsive as one may think. You'll miss a ledge every now and then. The enemies unfortunately are not truly a challenge. The levels are beautifully crafted and the narrative remains throughout engaging. The autosave works wonders and is very well integrated. Even if you die, you're never far away from where you were before your digital demise. I never truly was a fan of "old Lara", but the three new games (alas, 10 years now gone like nothing) are all a blast.

[h1]Tomb Raider 2013[/h1]
[u]This is how reboots should be done[/u]

edit, original review done in 2013 

Tomb Raider never really grabbed me back in its early days. I played 1,2 and 3 and found them fairly mediocre to be honest. I then paid no attention to the series at all until 2013 when the commercial's for the reboot started hitting tv. The commercial was enough to peak my interest as it look alot more realistic and dark. I decided to take the plunge when it came out and I was not dissapointed. I am looking forward to ROTT very much.

[h1]Single Player[/h1]
The story and characters are very good. Starts of very realistic and gritty, almost like a survival/thriller start. The story does develop more into fantasty and mystacism but its done in such a way that its enjoyable and is done right. The gunplay is fun and the ability to upgrade weapons and craft things is a really nice touch. The puzzles in tomb's and amount of collectables is great fun if you like me love collecting and 100% things.

[h1]Multiplayer[/h1]
The Multiplayer is an odd one. I'm sure some people will absolutley love it but to me it seems unnecessary, the same way that other great single player games recieved what seems like a "forced" multiplayer mode for the sake of it being there. Games like Batman Arkham Origins and to an extent Max Payne 3. The MP can provide some fun, for me it was about an hour then I realised it was more of a chore than fun. So I grinded out the MP achievments and never went back.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
A truly fantastic title with a meh MP (Hence why it didnt make it back to ROTT), I am glad I overcame my doubt and went for it. This is one of the best reboots I have seen in a long time and would recommend it to anyone.

Very well-made game, certainly. 
Without the QTE button mash cutscenes, I might have loved it. They interrupt the flow of an otherwise excellent game. And oh boy - The salacious sadism vibe in those scenes, intentional or not, is... not subtle. 
You end up having to watch her die or get really hurt a lot to figure out which buttons the game designers wanted you to mash when, in order to get through the grueling cutscenes. 
But after a while, seeing Laura die or get brutalized in various ways started to look like the designer's point with these QTE scenes. I did finish the game, loved everything else about it. but those cutscenes left me unsettled. 
So I looked it up, and found I was not alone-
Turns out this was a very controversial game when it came out. Now that I finally got around to playing it, I can certainly see why. 

As Jim Sterling put it in a Destructoid article (ten years ago, and actually before many people  even played it -)
"I do not think, as some do, that the game is reveling in the abuse of women and trying to sexualize Lara’s physical and emotional torment for the gratification of its male audience. From the way the game is marketed, from the way its PR are talking about the game, the message radiates that the developers don’t quite know what they’re doing, and are firing a volley of tried-and-tested emotional trauma at the audience in the hopes that something will resonate. "
https://www.destructoid.com/the-tomb-raider-scandal-everybody-is-right-and-wrong/

I think t's a good article, even if I don't agree with a lot of it. 
As for the whole male gaze thing - whether they intended it or not, it's clearly there. Getting hung up on intention is a mistake. Lots of things we do have effects we did not intend, especially in art. And yes, video games are absolutely an art.

The thing is, even if I go along with the idea that it somehow wasn't intentional, "firing a volley of tried-and-tested emotional trauma at the audience in the hopes that something will resonate" is bad art making. And when you do it, you DO know exactly what you are doing. The cutscenes do not flesh out the origin story. There is no real narrative or character development to be found there. Although they do physically move her from one location to another, they are just assorted scenes of punishing trauma and death if you mash buttons wrong, punctuated with the sound of Laura moaning- which essentially boils down to trauma porn. Trauma porn is not storytelling. It's manipulative and lazy at best. It's bad in movies, it's bad on tv shows, it's bad in books, and I think it's bad in video games too.

Tomb Raider is the one of the best action adventure games I played.

Pros

Open world is massive. There is sense of an adventure in every corner of the world.
Survival element is fun part of the game. You need to craft weapons and items to survive the wilderness. There are lots of predators that you need to look out for like bears, wolfs, leopards and cougars. Predators are hard to take down so you need to play tactically.
There are lots of different way you can approach a situation when you encounter enemies. This makes the game fun. Stealth is very good in this game compared to Tomb Raider 2013. AI is smart, when they discover the dead body they alert the other guys and they then start to search for you.
Environment sounds are great and Great voice acting by Camilla Luddington.
Lots of weapons and gears to choose from. You can be a rambo with bow and arrows. There are different type of arrows to choose from like fire, poison and explosive arrows.
Graphics is awesome. This is one of the best looking games I've played.
Character animations and Facial Expressions are so life like that it is feel like you are watching a movie.

Side missions and Optional tombs are very good. There are lots of optional challenge tombs in the game that make this game a true tomb raider experience. Puzzles in the tombs are very well balanced. They are not to hard but not so easy too.
Challenges and collectibles give this game some replay ability.
Lots of achievements which allows you to experience the game in different ways if you like to 100% the game.
Story is very good. There are documents to find that allows you to dive in to the lore of the game further.
DLCs are great. You can modify the experience of DLCs using cards.
Optimization is great but to MAX it you need newer hardware.

Cons
Nothing I can find.

I've never really been into single player story based games, apart from various Lego games when I was younger. I decided I wanted to play though the whole story so purchased Tomb raider 2013, RoTR and SoTR. First of all, the graphics on this game are unbelievable for a 2013, I'm not kidding when I say they are better than some games released in recent years! But then also the story is so interesting following Lara across the many places she visits, and learning about the histories of the areas through collectable diaries and artefacts. Overall i would highly recommend this game to any gamer whether you are a sweaty shooter player or a chill single player, it is amazing you will not be disappointed.

Score: 8/10 - GREAT
This game features an exotic Pacific island setting for you to explore, presented with incredible graphics and great attention to detail. Traversing the island by jumping and climbing is fun, solving optional hidden tombs is satisfying, and the controls are excellent. Unfortunately, the combat against human goons and wild animals is a bit too easy and simplistic. Although this game features many cutscenes, the story and characters are rather dull. Nevertheless, it’s plenty of fun to run around the island, admire the scenery, collect treasures, and remorselessly murder all the wilderness animals.
Great game from a classic series. Game has come a long way from the originals.

Tomb Raider 2013 is the breath of fresh air the series needed. Lara Croft's character development is fantastic, the parkour is sublime, the puzzles are satisfying and the gunplay's not too bad either.

It's far from a perfect game though- most of the gameplay (specifically the grappling, stealth sections and radio dialogue) was pretty obviously done first in the Batman Arkham games. The plot itself is basically Lost, and side characters have all the purpose of Star Trek's redshirts.

If you're looking for something innovative, you'll probably be disappointed. But compared to the previous instalments in the series, this is a worthy restart to the Tomb Raider series.

Really miss the days when video games were on an obvious quality growth. Man, the 2010's were such good times! Those were the years when people didn't have such high expectations from AAA developers, and games were made in somewhat of a vacuum, not influenced during development by consumers and executives. These were the days when making a video game of this caliber was a work of passion, when game developers wanted to put out a work of art in the world. 
Tomb Raider 2013 embodies all of these attributes. It is such a GOOD GAME! It has such cinematic camera angles, such good writing, such wonderful sound design! It represents what talented people can do with all the resources available at that time.

The graphics didn't age terribly well, but it's not bad enough to really make a difference in how enjoyable this game still is. I played this first shortly after it came out, and on this second play-through I was a bit surprised just how much a) gore and b) dumb button-mashing were in this game. I distinctly remembered both, but I really had forgotten just how prevalent it is. I'm so glad that in most new games we have accessibility options where you can either just keep holding down a button instead of having to mindlessly mash it for a few seconds - or even skip any interaction requirement whatsoever. Just let me enjoy the dramatic cutscenes instead of breaking up the tension with a "PRESS Y TO BURN HIS FACE" prompt. The gore is also way over the top, so many gigantic halls just filled to the brim with rotting bodies and skeletons, pools and rivers of blood... yuck. Aside from the gore, the torture porn aspect of the game also is a bit off-putting. Do we really need to see Lara get speared by a metal pipe, ripped to shreds by cliffs, etc., every time the controls aren't exact enough and a mishap occurs? That's _in addition_ to all the creepy shit during the storyline. It's just a bit much.

That said, that's all fairly high-level criticism. The core gameplay still is fun, and the game is mostly well-paced and not drawn out too long. The collectibles were mostly even fun to do, and didn't take particularly long after completing the main story. Shame that there's no maps for the challenges as well, that was the only annoying part. Encountered a game-breaking bug in one particular scene that could luckily be fixed by switching to 30fps just for that one scene. Also had to downgrade to an earlier build (which is luckily possible using the "Betas" menu) to avoid an issue where some (but not all, I didn't even notice it for the first few hours) HUD elements are displayed outside of the visible screen area. Shame that the Definitive Edition isn't available here, the game deserves a bit more polish. But even in this state, it's a good time and easy to recommend.

Fun game.

This is an amazing game which gripped me from start to finish. The reboot draws heavy inspiration from the Unchartered series particularly in the combat and the cinematic set pieces but IMO stands on its own due its story and main character. Lara is not the swashbuckling Tomb Raider from previous games but instead she's just a girl trying to survive and save her friends (by becoming a one woman murder machine but hey it's still a video game!). Suffice to say, I'm in love with this more realistic version of Lara which definitely had me caring about her as opposed to the buxom caricature from previous entries.

Another highlight for me was the weapon system. The game gives you only 4 weapons but gives you the freedom as to how you approach each encounter. Do you prefer to snipe enemies from afar using the bow or blast up enemies in the face with the shotgun? I also really like how the game unlocks weapon upgrades at steady pace giving you a clear sense of progression. And to add to that, the upgrades are not all just "MOAR DAMAGE" but also modify your weapons in interesting ways (like allowing your arrows to penetrate armored foes or equipping a silencer on the assault rifle??)

My only minor criticism is that the "tomb raiding" the series is known for has been relegated to small optional sections featuring a single puzzle. I understand the sequel improves on this aspect considerably so I'm really looking forward to giving those a go.

I loved the reboot trilogy. 2013 made the Tomb Raider franchise more serious and story focused, and I like it. Would recommend if you like combination of survival and adventure games.

I personally prefer games with more level structure over open world games, and this one has the perfect mix. You can explore areas but the gameplay and rich storyline continue to be linear. The combat is fun and challenging enough for me to die every once in a while on normal difficulty even as an experienced and pretty good (to toot my own horn) gamer. Overall 9/10 game, 10/10 would recommend at the price.
