Tomb Raider is a fantastic start of the franchise's reboot trilogy, and features nice graphics and action. The main story can be completed under 20 hours, which is a nice length (not too long or short). Moreover, it has optional side content that can easily stretch beyond that playtime.

I don't really have any complaints about the title, it performs well, looks good and plays great. While the action isn't necessarily my cup of tea. I do still think is good. If I had to nitpick, I can only say that I didn't like the quick time events (QTEs) in geenral - as it breaks the momentum for me - and I didn't think they fit in well with the original Tomb Raider experience (PS1 era) that I was more familiar with. Luckily, the amount of QTEs isn't too excessive here (unlike in later series which completely ruins it for me).

In retrospect, I feel that the trilogy has gone the way of being generic, but the quality is undoubtedly that of a AAA title and it has also aged well. At its lowest discounted price, Tomb Raider is most certainly a steal and I would highly recommend getting it when it's on sale.

[h1] A Series Is Reborn - A Solid 9/10 [/h1]

Old, but still gold - this 9-year-old game is just as incredible as the first game that came out in '96. There are very few deals this summer sale that will give you this level of value for $3 CAD. The fact that you can get the best trilogy of this game for under $30 CAD is unbelievably good for fans of Third Person Adventure games. I completely forgot this game had multiplayer, and so did the community - just get the base game and your wallet will thank you. Put the extra few bucks you would have spent into future games in the series.

Out of all the times that they tried to breathe new life into this older franchise from 1996, it finally stuck through the rerelease in 2013. All it took was a little bit of plot, a hint of character development, and a feature-rich open world ripe for traversal (with the most fluid movement mechanics yet!) Honestly - I loved the characters that they had for this trip, and Lara finally felt relatable in the proverbial (and actual) storm she weathers. I will say that with how much ground they covered in such a short amount of time that characters could have benefited with a bit more screen time. Sure, you were happy to get what was conveyed both in good cinematics, tasteful flashbacks, and journal logs that were dictated by the character's voice actor. But, it would have played out better in witty ongoing dialogue. 

Combat and movement were honestly at their best in this one, and only got better after this. The use of the bow made so much sense for this sort of game, and will delight Hanzo mains or fans of The Last Of Us. Other weapons felt right, and every weapon had an alternative mode of fire that added another level of depth to the combat. Enemies also had an array of weapons and tactics to ambush Lara that added a lot of challenge to this cover-based shooter. But it was more of an adaptive form of cover - it didn't feel sticky in the Gears of War sense, allowing you to scramble around enemies and use a mix of weapons and hand-to-hand combat to best them. I do wish that Boss fights were a bit more challenging, but this was also responded to in sequels. 

Movement in the world is great, and incentives to move around in the open world were plentiful. Lara's movements are incredibly fluid, and the use of choice camera angles that didn't just go for butt shots was certainly more cinematic than pornographic. You can compare the quality of the visuals and combat to something better than the earlier Uncharted games, although the character development just isn't there. Quick-time events and events that relied on fast reflexes were reasonably fair, and supported tense moments in the game vs. substituting gameplay. Upgrades to weapons and level-up perks also worked well, although crafting and doing more with the flora and fauna were better perfected in later games. I saw maybe 3 animal variations, and hated the idea of just picking berries or mushrooms just for XP. Music and sound design was there, but nothing memorable.

At its core, the game pivots primarily to action over the old-timey fetch key and do puzzle structure of levels. If you wanted a balance, start with Anniversary or Underworld. A balance is eventually met in future sequels where they were able to build the trust with their action-focused player base not to bore them to death, but this game marks a distinct move away from puzzles and finicky movement and guess the aim/hit registration that older fans of the franchise adored. It is a defining title of action/adventure games from the 2010s, and will likely go down as being the title that revitalised the series. Buy it. The game has a lot going for it – just don’t forget to look around in the open world.

This Game Is So Good

It's just much better than I expected for a reboot, it feels like a 2nd or 3rd game in the series in terms of ambition and execution. You can say what you want about the writing and voice acting, but the *game direction* is truly masterful and the technicians and artists who worked on the game did a superb job. The game looks unbelievably good for a 2013 Xbox 360 title and runs at full speed on a modern rtx card. Camerawork in particular puts around every other game new or old to shame. The puzzles are simple yet pretty fun, the game is mostly linear but gives you a sense of being open world. Combat is on the easy side but the solid stealth mechanics keep the whole thing interesting. Doesn't reinvent the wheel as much as refine it into something. Certainly a landmark game which is among the high water marks for the medium and holds up very well to this day.

It is my first time playing any Tomb Raider game and I had fun playing it.

There are a few complaints I had and one of them is that the story writing often felt like it was sloppy, cheesy and very often even ridiculous. It might be just the style of the series but as a stranger to this series, it pulled me out of the game. The other complaint is that the gameplay felt very scripted. I've heard that The Uncharted is rip off of old Tom Raider games and this Tomb Raider trilogy is a rip off of The Uncharted. I have no idea if it is true because I have no experience with the old Tomb Raider games but this game felt weaker compared to The Uncharted series in gameplay wise. The game's combat, stealth and even the traversal felt very scripted because of its lack of multiple approaches. Everything felt pretty linear and I just wish I had more control over how I would approach and clear out enemies. 

Other than these complaints, the game was pretty great. I had very little hope for the gameplay because the game is almost 10 years old now but the gameplay is very smooth, fun and I had no problem with it other than that I felt the melee combat was weak. I liked the weapon and skill upgrade system and I would give this game a 7 or 8 out of 10.

I finished this game on the Steam Deck. Although Valves warns this game is not fully compatible, it plays very well. I had 3 crashes (locking the Deck, had to turn off) and sometimes, in the menus, resolution problems (the Deck screen only showed a corner of the image), but nothing game breaking. The only thing that I did, performance wise, was to lock at 40 frames and that gave me 3 hours gaming sessions, more than enough. The game mostly stayed at 40 FPS and I never saw the counter below 37. For a single player game it’s great, no need for more.
I loved the game, not as tough as the originals (never finished one, platform games are not my thing) but not as easy as Uncharted. You see Lara growing in powers, as it should in an origin story, and become more competent, more the Lara Croft that we know. That will force you to go back to the first levels to complete the game with 100% but it’s made in a way that makes sense.
I believe the story is the weakest point of the game. It’s nice, but a little bit too predictable, you can see the twists coming from a mile away. On the other hand the story doesn’t get in the way of the game and the cutscenes are very nice.
The puzzles make you stop and think but nothing too complicated.
The strongest point is its beauty. Everywhere you look there’s something interesting to see. The animations are also great (love to jump with Lara and use the pick to climb the walls). I would say that is the only problem playing on a Steam Deck. The small screen is great but this game deserves a bigger picture.
The sound seemed very good but I didn’t play with headphones so I might be wrong.

The game is just excellent, it has some negative points that I have also listed.

Strengths:
Excellent ambience
Excellent soundtrack
Almost perfect gameplay

Negative points:
The physics is very strange, in some moments the enemy after being shot down, simply goes flying, this also applies to objects in the scenery
Climbing many times unnecessary, it got repetitive and boring
The shotgun and simply useless, only served to complete the upgrades part, because in the game itself I almost never used it
Multiplayer mode with achievements, I completed most of the achievements available in single player mode, but now I have to run behind in a way to be able to complete achievement in an almost extinct multiplayer.

Final considerations:
The game itself is simply magnificent, the few defects do not disturb, I found the story acceptable, it could be much more explored at times, I recommend it to people who are fans of the old series, because it is a beautiful reboot, but I do not recommend it if you just want to get the achievements, because you’ve lost a lot of time to get the multiplayer achievements.

I've been a huge fan of the classic Core Design Lara for most of my life, and I was curious about this game. The old fans had mixed reviews about this reboot, most likely because they inevitably compared the new with the old.

Well I found that this is a more realistic Lara Croft, by that I mean she is more human and is shown with normal emotions, which I think caused some people to find her whiny and/or overly dramatic. Firstly this is how Lara became Tomb Raider so it is normal that she reacts to danger with fear. Besides she becomes a badass as the game progresses anyway, but again with her human side intact. And to be honest she is not a psychopath like the classic Lara. I must say I prefer this version. I think she was written very well, with the voice actress, Camilla Luddington conveying her emotions and experiences succesfully. I think she did a pretty good job.

The game itself is closer to reality. Yeah, people's injuries are the opposite of what would happen in real world, Lara goes through half of the adventure with a huge hole in her side, jumping and running around, she falls down huge heights without any permanent injury nor does she develop infections. Lara's mentor somehow travels and hikes all around the map with a leg that would most likely need to be cut. And the game has supernatural elements. 

But I found the tombs and buildings and map designs were closer to reality. The game doesn't have weird and extremely complex tombs where you ask who the hell would build a place like this, putting levers that would open the door to the toilet on the other side of the map behind spike traps or something. Not that I didn't enjoy that style (and the old games were a lot of fun) but this one is a better approach. Kudos to the developers.

Anyway overall I quite enjoyed this game. The story is good, the dialogues are good, graphics are excellent, pretty good debut overall. Only thing I really disliked about this game was the weirdness of the challenges. Mainly, the main plot is too hectic and there is always some kind of emergency going on. It doesn't let you breathe and there is no suitable time to explore the island. Yes you can travel around for weeks and the game won't punish you but it feels weird looking for ancient texts and random items while some friend is about to die all the time. I think either the plot should have some breathing moments, or the side quests should have been removed. 

Many more things to say but it is enough for a random review.

This is the first time I've played a Tomb Raider game, and the first time in a long time I've played a third person puzzle action-adventure game like this, with the last one probably being Indiana Jones for Wii. I came in pretty blind and I have to say it was a lot better than I was expecting, in every way. Any issues I have are really small things.

Note: I played on Hard, and finished with 91% completion.

+ First of all: it's fun!
+ Voice acting that's actually good!
+ The story is pretty good and the characters actually had thought put into them.
+ Overall polished mechanics: all the different types of movement have a distinct feel to them, and the same can be said about the weapons (though the gunplay could be better). Survival Instinct is really fun and it's cool to be able to see the game world in a different light, it makes objectives and items easy to spot without cheapening the feeling of reaching them.
+ Combat difficulty is fitting for the type of game this is. That is, it's pretty easy, but not so easy that you can just run around aimlessly, you can still get gunned down quickly if you're far from cover.
+ Graphics are respectable, not top-tier even for 2013 standards but certainly good enough. (By the way, you can tell the entire facial animation budget went into Lara's face during cutscenes, lol.) On the other hand, it certainly performs well, I played with a GTX 1070 at 1440p Ultimate and only went below 60 when looking at the entirety of the largest areas at once.
+ The puzzles were enjoyable, made you think but not terribly difficult. Unfortunately, there aren't that many tombs.
+ Collectibles done right: they add character depth and worldbuilding. I have to criticize GPS caches (aka geocaches) for not really doing that, but I actually [b]wanted[/b] to find all the documents, relics, and treasure maps. Some you can only reach by revisiting previous areas with new tools, which some may not like, but I didn't mind at all.

= It's a bit quicktimey for my tastes, you need to mash keys pretty regularly.
= There's a mechanic for peeking around cover, which is nice, though I had a few occasions where it didn't quite kick in, mostly when trying to aim around walls up a staircase.
= Some baked-in animations are at 30 fps.

- Three bugs worth mentioning: I got phased through a closed gate, and one time I was respawned [i]after[/i] the fight I died in, not before. Neither a big deal, if anything they were amusing. An annoying one was that a certain cave didn't load in and if I tried to follow the objective marker I would fall out of the world. Fast travelling away and back with lower graphics settings seemed to fix it.
- The shotgun kinda sucks.

I was a bit skeptical about this new appoach to a rather dusty representative of the adventure genre, especially since I am not a big fan of the recycling of game titles, forcing me to add a (2013) to it. But they have managed to pull it off created a Lara Crft game that really put me on the edge of my seat. It looks great, plays well (although as a console port *grrr* it could be better optimized) and has a, for my taste, great story to follow along. The multiplayer is wasted though, who buys a Tomb Raider game and expects a shooter-MP?

Also, Crystal Dynamics: less gory deaths next time, please. I don't need to see Lara's head get impaled everytime I miss a QTE...and then she gets slowly dragged down along the spike. It's unnecessary, overly bloody and too long.
I like the jumpsuit

Impressive. It's the word that comes to my mind to describe this reboot. Most of the game is simply fantastic, even if it's different from the others tomb raiders. I just don't like so much some scenes where you have to fight tons of ennemies. Lara croft isn't a rambo like. And some scenes are too scripted. Except these points, it was a real pleasure to play this game.

Story:
I loved it. It was well told and easy to follow. The characters, while only briefly seen throughout the story, allows you to grow attachment towards them. It's great how it plays out. It took place in Japan!

Gameplay:
It was well done! The combat felt too easy, however. Fire fights felt too video-game-y as in, there are a bunch of bad guys pointing guns at you and you're able to easily pick off each one one-by-one yet they can't kill you. By the time I beat the game, Lara easily had been shot hundreds of times and had killed hundred of bad guys all by herself. Lara comes off more of someone like Batman or another superhero instead of a human. She is able to just beat all odds and feels immortal. It's also really fun having the option to be stealthy in order to try and avoid getting attacked.

The parkour elements are fun and throughout the game I'm just in awe of how Lara is able to be so fearless and cheat death so many times and still survive.

There are many collectables to be found, adding to the replay value. Also, the RPG elements are a nice touch and it's fun to progress Lara, even though the combat is already easy enough.

Sound:
Well done! Good sound track and effects.

Overall:
It's a great game! Lots of fun. My biggest complaint is the combat is too easy and unrealistic, even on the hardest combat setting.

Very good, but not without it's flaws.  The animations are a bit glitchy, but all the mechanics work well.  The dialogue isn't super well written, sometimes the characters seem to not realize things that have already been established for a long time, and their methods of conversing seem... well like they're having their own separate conversations at each other.  Some of the supporting characters are pretty annoying as a result, and others were annoying from the start, or lacked depth enough to make them so.  That being said, Lara's voice acting and the overall story is very good.  The game play is super fun, and the leveling systems are really well done.  Honestly the way the different sections of the map connect back together later in the game reminds me of Super Metroid, and considering that that is my favorite game that's high praise.  There's also a TON of stuff here for completionists to do, and the story is a fair length (Though on the topic of story at the end it is revealed the Storm Guard still live on the island, which makes the existence of the Oni confusing, as I was under the impression they were the ghosts of the Storm Guard, but whatever).  Over all it's a good game with some flaws that bring it down.  I recently purchased Rise of the Tomb Raider, and am excited to see how it improves on the original.  I would warn anyone who has motion sickness that the camera in this game really enjoys shaking around.  8/10

(Edit: It also has the same "once you reach this point you can't go back" issue as Super Metroid, and seeing as I didn't realize I could have multiple save slots, I got locked into the end game without 100% and did not have the option to go back.  This would be forgivable, but when you scroll through all the fast travel camps "Sea Cliff Bunker" is not listed, but is an area that has collectibles.  As a result I thought I completed the game 100% and instead got an infuriating 99% completion rate.  I looked back, saw the sea cliff bunker, attempted to head there only to find I was locked in the end game.  This is probably the worst thing about the game.  Docked the final score half a point for this infuriating garbage.)

[quote]If you would like to read more of my reviews, check out and follow the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/27264611/] 𝓕𝓾𝓷𝓴𝔂 𝓙𝓪𝓵𝓪𝓹𝓮𝓷𝓸𝓼 curation page [/url] as well as [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/FunkyJalapenos] joining the Steam group[/url], feel free to say Hello to the community on the Discord server! [/quote]

[h1] ▀▄▀▄▀▄ Tomb Raider ▄▀▄▀▄▀ [/h1]

[u][b]TL,DR Review[/b][/u]

An action-packed re-imagining of Lara Craft which is heavily inspired by the Uncharted series. While the game-play holds up for the most part, this version unfortunately never received the graphical updates of the Definitive Edition on PS4/XB1. It's a huge visual difference so you may want to consider playing that version instead.

[u][b]Full Review[/b][/u]

I'm going to say upfront that Tomb Raider 2013 is a good game, but I need to start by saying that it has bothered me from start to finish on how ugly this game looks at times on PC. I've been running this game in ultra with no problem and certain parts of the game look like I'm playing through an early PS3 title. I highly suggest to consider playing the PS4\XB1 Definitive Edition for a vast improvement on the experience.

Anyway, this is a reboot of the Lara Croft series that many people know from the PS1 era and while the series has had entries on the PS2, PS3, Xbox 360, it was never to the same fanfare as the original entries. Arriving in 2013, this reboot has removed any sort of the 90s sexuality in favor of a survival heroine akin to the characters of The Descent movie and for the most part it works. Lara herself is well written as a character who starts as someone who is just trying to survive to by the end of the game has grown into the Tomb Raider. Environments are varied enough for the setting that the story takes place in and combat is fast-paced with decent puzzles sprinkled throughout the campaign. However, there are a few more elements that I have issues with.

Moving past the graphics situation I mentioned previously, the biggest issues I have with the game is the story and the combat. The story is fine for what it is as a catalyst for Lara as an origin story, but the rest of the characters are really uninteresting. It feels like someone cast a seasoned AAA actress in a summer blockbuster movie and filled in the rest of the character roles with actors from the local community theater. At the end of the day, these characters don't matter.

Combat is....fine, the controls and handling are what you expect from a competent 3rd person shooter. The issue is that there is so much combat. It probably came down to time, effort or perhaps budget but overall there wasn't enough tombs\exploration and way too much combat as a whole. The tombs are also an issue to a lesser extent, it's not like they're bad but most of them don't feel like tombs but more like rooms. They don't always have the sense of scale like they should. This might be because this was made for the 360\PS3 generation, perhaps there was a space or memory limitation behind it.

Multiplayer is fine, standard modes like Team Deathmatch and a typical unlock system for loadouts. Surprisingly there is a small amount of players to find matches here in the end of 2019 so it might be worth trying out to see if you like it.

Some of the issues could be fixed in sequels that were developed for current game consoles while others are issues that many games face and that usually just requires additional polish. Ultimately I should reiterate that I think this is a good, enjoyable game and that these issues standout more to me because how well made it is for the most part. Tomb Raider 2013 gets a thumbs up and is a solid choice if you're looking for a good 3rd person action adventure.

Based on the majority of the reviews you will find here on Steam, you might think this game is a masterpiece.
I’m sorry, but I will have to disagree.

If you look thru the story point of view, yes it’s a great game.
Graphics are good, even for today standards, voice over is great and we got an engaging origin story for a beloved character, but here is where it all stops.

This game didn't age well, by any means.
The excessive camera shaking will give most people motion sickness, and the excess of quick time events not only breaks the immersion, but also gets extremely annoying as the game progresses.
I don’t know who took the decision to add these features to the game, but while I was playing all I could think of was this person should be banned from the game industry for life time.

On the top of these issues, there is also a glitch in the Tomb of the Last Adventurer DLC, which might force you to load a previous game save if you don't know about it.
Have a look at the DLC reviews for more information:
https://store.steampowered.com/app/208812/Tomb_Raider_Tomb_of_the_Lost_Adventurer/
Sad, but it looks to be the way Square Enix works, as there are other games released by them which were never pached to fix its issues.

In the end of the day, is Tomb Raider a 9 out of 10 game? Surely not, most likely 6 or 7.
This is an ok game.
It's unfortunate how blind today's players are when making their reviews, as this will not help anyone. People like this are doing a disservice to the gaming industry, and to other players.

Just finished playing the full trilogy, and the 3rd game (Shadow of the Tomb Raider) made me so upset that I had to rant. I can say overall that this game and the 2nd installment Rise of the Tomb Raider, fight for the top spot(although I'll give it to this game for reasons explained later). The narrative and the game play/skill system really work well to show a novice Lara Croft and her first steps into being the OG Lara Croft. Lara does have a character arc here and if this was a standalone game it does a perfect job being a prequel game to the OG Tomb Raiders.Now spoilers for this game and the rest of the trilogy. [spoiler]  In the last fight Lara uses her signature dual pistols 1 of the pistols being a memento of her mentor who died protecting her. In the follow games Lara never uses dual pistols again WHY??? Doesn't carry that gun around as a memento, and doesn't use any of her multitudes of pistols in combination with each other. Disappointing and a missed opportunity [/spoiler]

Rise of the Tomb Raider is great and is an improvement to the first game I believe its the favorite for most players. [spoiler]Lara deals with her late Father's last quest.She wants to do right by her father and has dedicated her life to finishing his last quest and clearing his name. She struggles with the "ends justifies the means" as the villains will sacrifice everything to get what they want, and Lara teeters on that seesaw for a little while until inevitability doing the good thing. The story/history tells and resolves itself well, and the side characters and the villains(well one of them) are memorable and interesting.  [/spoiler]

Shadow of the Tomb Raider reuses the narrative beats from the first and second game really poorly. We go through sacrifice again, family issues again. I was waiting for a WOW factor and I never got it. It felt like the game was building up for a huge climax, and once that ending came around I felt cheated. Very little payoff, plotlines that heavily relied on reading collectibles and dlc and even then it felt weak. Side characters are pretty forgettable apart from some "badass" moments. The villain was "okay" because I did his dlc. His motivations are understandable but they tried to paint him as ambivalent "nice guy" then he does the "ends justifies the means" thing again and we get atrocities and mass killings. Wrote off the big bad organization in dialogue by a grunt. They heavily invested in tombs this time around(so many tombs), but the rewards were either just old skills from the previous games, or a very minor passive buffs.Nothing truly rewarding or awe inspiring.

Gameplay gripes [spoiler]
My gripes in terms of gameplay is that skills from the previous games do not carry over. Like rolling after falling. It's like we're starting with newbie Lara even though we know she's a badass now. I'm fine with not having a full arsenal like equipment/weapons but having previous learned skills locked away and having us unlock them again feels lazy and makes the previous journey seem pointless, this is especially bad in the 3rd game as skills picked up in both the 1st AND the 2nd game need to be relearned with skill points or are locked away in tombs!!!
Gameplay wise the trilogy has a bad habit of removing Lara of her weapons and having her stealth, and kill her way through mobs of enemies. These enemies generally have guns and knives, Lara does not pick them up?????. An equipment in the 2nd game is called a Combat Knife, it's purpose? To cut rope(and faster stealth kills). So how do you get this marvelous equipment. Do you craft it out of some scrap metal or stone? Nope. Do you loot it off of the enemies who try to run at you with a knife? Nope. You pick it up in an old soviet mine. ???? It's really contrived. To be fair you do make your combat knife in the third game from a piece of scrap metal(WOOO!!!). You can also buy upgrades for this knife! Now you would think buying an upgrade for this knife would be replacing it with an actual knife, maybe one of those spiffy combat knives. Nope, you actually upgrade your scuffed knife. You know why this irks me? Because in the SAME GAME you lose all your items again and you actually pick up a knife from an enemy(wow!!!). And what does she do after that section? Goes back to her scrap knife.  [/spoiler]

Overall, it was pretty fun. New to the Tomb Raider series. I picked this up when it was on sale for like 2 bucks and it's really hard to complain for 2 bucks.

What I liked:
- Visuals are still pretty good for a 9 year old game. 
- Audio quality is fairly good although the dialogue and the voice acting from the supporting characters can be a bit cheesy. 
- Controls are pretty comprehensive from the get go. 
- Combat is pretty fun as well.

However, here are my complaints:
- No run toggle or tap to run. Makes exploring tedious.
- Shaky camera - I had to install a mod to disable the camera wobble since I can't play for 5 minutes without getting a heaedache. It's not just in cut scenes for a more cinematic feel. It's there even in gameplay.
- Stealth seems sorta hit or miss. It's hard to tell when I'm not able to be seen especially without a dedicated "cover" button. There's a section in the forest with soldiers and wild wolves, and it's complete BS. Once you're discovered, everyone knows your location even the wolves. And those wild wolves only go after you for some reason.
- Enemies are kinda BS. Their bullets seem to be able to go through rocks sometimes or they have crazy good aim while they rain bullet hell on you.
- Maps feels pretty linear.
- Voice acting from side characters sometime don't feel very convincing like say after a crazy climax and a character goes "oh thanks, Lara" in a near monotone voice.
- As mentioned earlier, dialogue can get a bit cheesy and ruin the seriousness of the situation.

Although, I listed way more negatives than positives, it was still very fun to play overall. If you have motion sickness, it's probably worth looking into getting the Yamatai mod to disable the camera wobble because it's that bad IMO. Hard to beat for 2 bucks. At 15, it's still pretty cheap but ehhh.

I keep coming back to this game. It's truly a masterpiece. A lot of the time when companies wanna remake a game or completely refurbish the idea, it doesn't live up to it's name. However this one was made spectacularly. The graphics for the year released are stunning. The gameplay is new and exciting. The story is entertaining. I honestly can't fault it for anything and can only applaud Crystal Dynamics for this amazing game

[b]Totally soaked, exhausted and injured, young Lara sits by a fireplace and thinks about what just happened...[/b]

The research ship she was on to search with her colleagues for the remains of a sunken kingdom in the Dragon Triangle has sunk. Her colleagues are probably all dead, Lara is injured and alone on this island. In the middle of nowhere…

Unlike usual with Tomb Raider, exploring burial chambers or caves is not quite as important in the reboot, even if you can still climb around and discover secrets outside of the action levels in extensive areas. But if you keep your eyes open as usual, you can find USB sticks, various artefacts and maps that show hidden extras, treasure chests or flotsam.

[b]And what do I need all this stuff for?[/b]

Tomb Raider now offers a talent system and weapon upgrades, and all you need is enough debris, experience points, and as so often, a campfire.
As soon as you sit down at one of these campfires, the upgrade menu opens where you can exchange the points you have earned so far for new skills or health improvements and also buy weapon upgrades. It is also possible to fast travel to areas you have already visited from here. This saves you a lot of time if you have missed something, such as a burial chamber.
However, the hidden burial chambers cannot always be explored immediately, as often a piece of equipment is missing that is only obtained in the course of the game. But even if you can open a burial chamber, the secret inside is not always that easy to reveal. You often have to find the right switch combinations, cleverly climb to other levels or balance platforms in order to uncover well-kept secrets.

[b]Oddly enough, Lara suddenly drops phrases such as "... I hate graves" during the game.
Eh ? What ? I'm sorry, what ?
For years it has been about nothing but graves, or have I missed something?[/b]

At the start of the game, the still quite “whining brat” who often complains about how bad everything is right now, quickly mutates into a killer bride who does more than just skilfully. Lara automatically seeks cover as soon as she can and shoots at the unclever AI from behind cover. Unfortunately, this means that Lara's transformation is somewhat lost in the actual story in combat and explosion overkill. As the saying goes, "and that's where the dog is buried". Action is by no means bad, absolutely not, especially not in such a spectacularly staged cover shooter. However, without all these explorations through dark caves in an atmospheric world, a Tomb Raider is somehow still not a Tomb Raider as you know it.

However, the strengths and weaknesses are more or less balanced and if you don't really like tomb robber activities and can do without other things like challenging jump passages, you will definitely be rewarded with a pretty good action spectacle.

[b]It's not perfect, but overall a positive feeling still lingers after a few hours.[/b] 
This is probably mainly due to the last third of the game, in which the demands, the puzzles and the tension increase noticeably and Lara just seems a bit more authentic as an archaeologist. Nevertheless, I would have wished for more exploration, less collecting mania and more survival.

I'm glad that I came back to this game after all these years. Started the game on PS3 around launch but never finished it. Picked it up again a few years later on PS4 but didn't finish it there either...

Now, it's 2022 and I'm playing this game in buttery smooth 4K with every graphics setting at it's highest (thank you RTX 3080). The game still holds up extremely well. I don't have any attachment to the older/original Tomb Raider games, so I easily found the reboot fantastic. Particularly, I like how this young Lara has plenty of vulnerable moments throughout her journey. She gets injured A LOT, with plenty of setbacks along the way, but never gives in. Her resolve and grit resonated with me in a way that made me excited to see what happened next. I look forward to finishing this game soon. I've already got Rise and Shadow waiting in my library.

The game that made a spectacular return of the greatest videogame heroine of all time.

A sensational reboot of Lara Croft into the gaming world. This game is an action packed thriller with explosive set-pieces and a storyline to root for.

The Lara Croft we know is absent. Long gone the duel wield weaponry and the unbeatable killer machine of a women we love, instead we get a timid and frightened young lady who is stranded in a japan-ish bermuda triangle.

Hunting for her life are the fanatics led by an intriguing character named Mathias who wants to resurrect the fabled Sun Queen who used to rule the world ages ago. However, Lara is not alone in her journey, she has her mentor & friend along with her best friend Sam and a group of rag tag explorers. 

The atmosphere is beautiful and horrific at the same time. Equally, gorgeous is the lead heroine Lara, who instead of over-sexualized in previous games, is depicted as an average explorer who when faced with the mortal dangers quickly sprangs into action. Camilla Ludington the voice of Lara has done an amazing job!

The puzzles are few but very intelligent and realistic, Lara dont have to push a button to solve everything like in past, here she has to manipulate surroundings in order to solve the puzzles.

This game is amazing, I have already played in 4 times and yet havent explored everything. After playing its sequel (Rise of Tomb Raider) and the series finale (Shadow of Tomb Raider) I conclude that this one is by far the most superior of the trilogy.

For Lara worshipper like me it was a mandatory game to play, however I would encourage every action/adventure lover out there to try this amazing masterpiece.

This game does a good job at rebooting Tomb Raider as a franchise. Lara Croft has been kind of a hit or miss pop culture figure over the years and this game gives her a much needed restart at being what she was designed as a character: a survivor. This game is amazing at some things, especially the story. However, this game is riddled with bugs on PC that from what I can tell have been there since the game launched. I originally played this on both the Xbox 360 and the One, and never had a single bug or glitch the entire time. I immediately had problems on the PC version. Almost every single animal in the game didn't walk and just hovered above the ground, i had many problems where I couldn't interact with items or ledges and had to reset my game, sometimes doors wouldn't open and again, had to reset my game. I had the game just completely close several times when I would alt+tab out to change what I was listening to. The biggest thing that only happened once, but there is only one spot for it to happen was in a cave with a wolf. When the wolf attacks you, you are given on screen prompts to attack it. This took me 18 minutes to get past one wolf. That scene would sometimes not show the prompts, show the wrong prompts, or sometimes show every single prompt all at once and you don't know which one to press. This is one of the bugs that after looking around, it seems that this has been an issue since it launched originally and just has never been fixed.

However, the story in this game is great. Like I said previously i had played this on the 360 and the One, but I had never actually beaten the game, the farthest I ever got was probably about 80% of the story. I am glad I finally came back to finish the game, even if I had a rough time doing so. The open world is very fun to explore and other than the floating animals, which doesn't have an effect on gameplay, worked perfectly. I would absolutely recommend this game, as long as whoever is playing it knows what might happen when they do.

A good game, gameplay wise it is better than first three Uncharted games almost in every aspect. Mechanics are more in depth, shooting is much better, and puzzles are more varied. All aspects of the game intertwine and you get this survivor feeling for which, I think, developers are aimed for. Story is nothing special but it set up well and cast does a good job portraying these personages. As an almost 10 year old game it holds up incredibly well. An adventure well worth playing.

[h1]About[/h1]
[quote=]A reboot to the original Tomb Raider. It was released on March 2013.[/quote]
[h1]Story[/h1]
Lara and her friends goes on an expedition on the ship Endurance, attempting to find the Lost Kingdom of Yamatai, but are sudden struck by a storm. They end up on an island that seems to have dangerous habitants.
It's simple and takes you to what you want: action and adventure.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Adventure third-person shooter. When you are not shooting humans, you will be climbing, running from collapsing places and exploring. The game has certain RPGs elements, like XP, abilities and upgrades (both by exploring or progressing in the main campaign). And according to your progress, you will unlock new weapons.

[h1]Characters[/h1]
While they serve their purpose, most of them aren't enjoyable. They are there sometimes, but you probably won't miss them when you are alone.

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
Okay soundtrack. It fits the moments in the game, it gets the job done... but most of it you won't remember.

[h1]Pros & Cons[/h1]
[quote=][b]Pros[/b]
- Good gun-based combat.
- Good exploration in the main campaign.
- Excellent graphics for its time.
- Okay story.

[b]Cons[/b]
- Most Tombs are optional and aren't appealing to explore.
- Characters aren't memorable.[/quote]

[h1]Personal Score[/h1] 
[b]Gameplay:[/b] [i]10/10[/i] 
[b]Story:[/b] [i]7/10[/i] 
[b]Characters:[/b] [i]7/10[/i] 
[b]Soundtrack:[/b] [i]7/10[/i] 
[b]Overall:[/b] [i]7.75/10[/i]

Tomb Raider is well-written, sympathetic, exciting, beautiful and just incredibly well-made. The single-player rarely makes a mis-step, and though Lara's quick transformation into a hardened killer seems at odds with the narrative at first, the game quickly moves past it. A great game with a nice combination of exploration and shooting parts, both gameplay components are quite simple to play but very entertaining. Traveling around the stages in search of extra experience and crafting details is not boring due to the moderate areas size and limited number of points of interest, there also maps that mark important collectible items. Quite a lot of leisurely puzzles and fast action scenes are also combined in equal proportion. I also really like the setting of an isolated island, where there is beautiful nature, ancient Japanese architecture, military bunkers and the garbage slums of survivors. And of course, especially cute looking Lara, even if she is covered in dirt, blood and scars. Yes, the next parts got bigger, better, more professional in development... But this one - the first one - has a special place in my memory.

I just finished this game at 23 hours, with a 71% completion. I didn't go out of my way to get the collectibles. I thought about how I felt about the game during those 23 hours and I can honestly say I did not like it. I only played it one time and I am never going to play it again. I don't think you should give a review on a game that you played over and over until you know how to beat it in your sleep. Your review should be honest and you should complete the main story before giving your review. Your review should not be based on the fact that other players will be upset you gave their favorite game a negative review. For a game that came out in 2013 it would of had a higher rating, but by today's gaming standards this game would be unacceptable. One thing that makes the game a pain is our monitors have much higher resolutions then they did back in 2013, and the Quick Time Button events are hard to see and react to with these higher resolutions. This causes the scene to be failed over and over and over until the player is ready to just give up and go do something else.
I have to think about telling my best friend if a game is fun and worth playing and I am sorry but I would never be able to honestly recommend Tomb Raider 2013 to my best friend and so I will also not recommend it to you. Good Day.

So many reviews posted over the years that there is not much I can add. I played the original Tomb Raider 'back in the day' and loved it. As an adventure gamer by trade, however, I was never coordinated enough to survive to the end.

After playing Horizon Zero Dawn and improving my stealth/action skills, I was looking for my 'next game' and someone suggested the Tomb Raider series.

I've really enjoyed this first game. I love traveling with the 'new' Lara and exploring a diverse and detailed world. I set the difficulty level to 'Easy' and managed to find collectibles, progress, and survive up to the ending 'big boss' (who I have yet to kill). The platforming does not require perfect precision and I found the controller configuration easy to work with and intuitive. For major battles, I resorted to my keyboard/mouse which gives me better aim.

This is a great game for adventurers who want to try their hand at stealth and combat. There is a story, likable characters,  collectibles, and an occasional ambush.  Survival is based on taking cover and keeping your adrenaline in check.  For those new to the franchise, there is an invaluable set of guides on "Stella's Tomb Raider Site" that provide tips/techniques and survival strategies. Achievements include multi-player challenges so 100% was not on the table for me. This freed me to enjoy the experience without being concerned with perfection!

Gameplay, graphics, voice acting and story are all great. The plot kinda reminds me of the TV series Lost - you and your friends crash on a mysterious island, it's filled with old bunkers and dangerous people, and a powerful force is preventing everybody from escaping. There's good puzzle solving but there's also a lot of emphasis on action, perhaps too much - despite Lara's emotional reservations in the cutscenes, you wind up killing probably about 400 people.

Completely unrealistic in its attempt to be more gritty and realistic. Endless traumas, broken bones, and puncture wounds that would render even the hardest of beefcakes hospital-bound, shirked off with nothing more than a shake of the head and some transient grogginess. Constantly jarring, in terms of suspension of disbelief.

The actual raiding part of this Tomb Raider title is drastically cut back, too, in terms of puzzle intricacy. But everything lost in this regard is more than made up for in general traversal and environmental depth. Nonetheless, a regression for the franchise, that wasn't addressed until Shadow.

All that said, the moment-to-moment gameplay itself is a great riff on the original formula, with better combat, better player agency, and some great cutscene acting. Even the multiplayer is enjoyable, if you can find a match this long after the horse has bolted.

In terms of compatibility and performance, 2013 holds up perfectly, a decade later.

My only real nitpick is the disappointment that comes with Rhianna Pratchett and Jackson Lanzing not getting to portray Sam and Lara's relationship in the manner originally intended. Moreover, that Sam is then relegated to the looney bin, in later titles, because Square Enix lacked the balls to step up to the mark.

A bittersweet, but otherwise enjoyable entry to the franchise.

while this Lara looks beautiful in the opening cutscene of this game, I am not sorry for preferring the old tomb raiders to this. Maybe its because they're more nostalgic... actually NO. I love the old tomb raiders because of the story they had in the first rebooted trilogy. A lot of people online have made a good point that the devs could've continued [spoiler] the doppleganger storyline [/spoiler]. It actually would have been interesting for them to build more on her story and they would've definitely made bigger sales. However, they missed out on that opportunity the moment they chose to throw out the reboot that ends with TR: Underworld & create what is known as "survivor Lara". I perfer Lara in the old games because she's more fierce & a badass. She doesn't wine about shit or cry because she's about to die or whatever. In the old games, Lara is quick to protect herself, take cover, do whatever she has to do to keep herself safe. There's so much of a challenge with the old games & that's what makes them more fun. The puzzles as well.
All in all, it does not matter how good or decent the graphics of a game are because what really matters in the end is it's playability & story, to me at least. 

Yes, this game runs and maybe has a .. mediocre predictable story. I'll give you that. But if I had to choose, I would 100% take the old tomb raiders over this 2013 reboot. 

 I will write more once I have put more hours into the game.

This was my first experience with tomb raider games and I loved it to bits. I like a good, fun single player game and this is one of them. Immediately after finishing this one I bought the newer one's. Graphically this game holds up to today's standards, bug vise, haven't experienced anything game breaking, a couple minor one's. Story is a bit cliche and basic but it get's the job done, puzzles aren't too complicated, so as is platforming, but they are still fun, audio's great, shooting is also decent, there's also stealth elements, or you can just go guns blazing with your modified guns. There's experience points you can spend on improving your skills and scraps you can find to upgrade your weapons. Quite a few collectables to find and secret caves/areas to explore. There's also a multiplayer mode but I'm doubtful anyone still plays, haven't really given it a shot myself. The campaign it self is a bit short, but I'd rather have it short and enjoyable than long and boring, repetitive or grindy. Especially when it is this cheap.

All in all, a very well crafted and optimised game. Worth every penny.

A great reboot from the original Tomb Raider series.

[b] The Positives: [/b]
+ Platforming is smooth and engaging
+ Solid combat with upgradable weapons
+ Puzzles are decent and challenging
+ Lots of Collectables to find
+ Good story

[b] The Negatives: [/b]
- QTEs can be annoying sometimes
- Hunting feels pointless
- Multiplayer is average and uninspired

[b] Final Verdict: [/b] The game is pretty good. Get it if you like platforming, solving puzzles, or just want to see Lara Croft suffering from all the failed QTEs and missed jumping. 8/10.

Slightly better than the average 2013-2018 exporathon open world.
Also started the trend of "Character Torture"="Character development"; might be indirectly responsible for Amnesia:Rebirth, Outlast 2 and RE3:Remake being shit. At least this one had a cool mystery to unearth with the Japanese Monsters.
Still a decent action-story game for it's time.

EDIT:
Have to add that, after playing the next 2 games I am really thankful that this one is way shorter. There is very little padding in between the setpieces of the story and for one the mystery/paranormal stuff is interesting since it's not literally rehashed. Also there are little to no  flashbacks, which helps us feel more immersed in the setting of being trapped on an island.
